TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. As South Australia has had the highest mainland unemployment rate for each of the past 33 months, has the Government any regional economic policies for South Australia designed to give its manufacturing base a new start?
—Yes, return the Tonkin Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take note of what the honourable member for Wakefield just said. I think South Australians would be directing their attention to that factor as they weighed up a question on these lines or on any other line. The honourable member for Grey, representing an area involving the steel industry, of course has asked questions in this House about that industry and has related it to unemployment. The reality is that this Government wants to see a competitive steel industry. What is happening in Australia is not unique to it. Major retrenchments and plant closures are occurring in many countries in world conditions of depressed steel demand. For Australia, export markets have disappeared or are unprofitable. The Australian industry has to adjust to this situation. The honourable member will be aware that quite apart from the specific elements of coal and steel, which were discussed with people yesterday, those representatives raised other matters as well.

ANSWER.PARA: We have not left the steel industry on its own. Since receipt of the report from the Temporary Assistance Authority we have given even more assistance to that industry than was indicated by the report of the TAA. We imposed tariff quotas with 150 per cent duty on any increase over the 1981-82 levels. We have had to consider the impact of increased protection for steel on downstream industries, and we have rejected the proposition that the decision we took is responsible for the restructuring. Indeed, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has indicated that this occurred as a consequence of planning well before any Government decisions were taken. Honourable members well know the measures that have been taken for industry. The package announced by the Prime Minister in July was warmly received by industry and it ought to be giving a fillip, in the area of the investment allowance, which honourable members on the other side would abolish, in the area of depreciation and, of course, in the area of the tax benefits available, to try to get further investment for more jobs in this country. To sum it all up, this Government does believe in development and in providing jobs, in contrast to what honourable members opposite would do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What does the Government intend to do to increase the productivity and profitability of Australian industry? Does the Budget in any way form a basis for co-operation in achieving wage moderation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is obviously concerned for the profitability and the competitiveness of Australian industry. Only through a healthy industry overall-a healthy manufacturing industry is a very important part of that-will we have the kind of future in Australia that everyone would want. That is why we introduced the package on 19 July which, in a very remarkable way, has improved the depreciation provisions available for manufacturing industry. That is why we also introduced depreciation allowances for income-producing buildings generally for the first time, although they had been available to some elements of the tourist industry as a result of earlier decisions. This, of course, provides the opportunity for Australian industry to make sure that it does have access to the most modern and competitive equipment. Without that I doubt whether manufacturing industry anywhere would be able to compete effectively in the modern world. If we are not using the most modern and effective equipment, then certainly industries in other countries will. The new depreciation schedules allow our industries to compete on much fairer terms with their counterparts in other countries.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, there are the general tax cuts which start to flow in November and which are substantial. The housing interest rebate, which is general rather than specific for first home buyers, will also be of significant help. Even though housing interest rates have not dropped to this point, the fact that there have been some significant falls in official interest rates and in some private sector interest rates should take away from potential home purchasers and home buyers the fear that the upward spiral in interest rates is just going to go on and on. Even if families believed that they could afford to enter into a contract to buy or build a house now in a situation of rising interest rates, I have no doubt that a number of them would be concerned as to whether the increases at some subsequent time might put them in difficulty. I think the fact that there have been some significant falls in official interest rates should take that fear away. It is encouraging to note how secondary market rates have held reasonably well in spite of the adverse consumer price index figure released a few days ago.

In addition, many parts of Australian industry are going to be helped by the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program and by a very significant increase of over 20 per cent in general Commonwealth capital works. Small industries are also being helped by the increased retention allowance and by other measures which will encourage greater equity participation by Australians by providing a tax rebate for $1,000 of equity income and also, of course, by measures designed to encourage employee share ownership. The last two measures might seem relatively small steps but they are saying something of very real philosophical importance which I am sure many people would want to support.

The Budget does provide a basis for co-operation, for working together, for wage restraint. A single income family with two children, on $300 a week and paying off an average home mortgage, will be $17 to $18 a week--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. —I was making the point that a single income family, with a dependent spouse and two children, earning $300 a week and having taken out an average housing loan of, say, $25,000, will be $17 or $18 a week better off as a result of the Budget. If they had to get that extra money from their employers that would be, say, $25 or $26 a week. In the current environment, that additional $25 or $26 could be enough to send some firms bankrupt. These matters certainly need to be taken into account in any wage decisions that are made in the period ahead of us. Coupled with the general measures designed to assist industry and with the measures designed specifically to help Australian families and Australian working men and women, there is in this Budget a real basis for restraint and for working together. It is very much to be regretted that, as indicated by calculations made by Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association, the Budget of the Cain Government in Victoria will take $12 a week out of the pockets of every Victorian family. That is in marked contrast to this Budget, which is putting $17 or $18 a week into the pockets of those families I have been speaking about.

INTERJECT.PARA: URANIUM ENRICHMENT FEASIBILITY STUDY

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Deputy Prime Minister received a letter circulated to members of the House by Mr E. F. Herbert, Chairman of the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia? It is stated in the letter:

QUESTION.PARA: UEGA is not proposing at this time to proceed with the construction of an enrichment plant in Australia, nor even with a detailed feasibility study. Whether or not a detailed feasibility study is undertaken in the near future will depend on our joint assessment, with Urenco-Centec, of the extent and timing of future markets.

Will the Deputy Prime Minister therefore acknowledge that the full feasibility study which the Minister for National Development and Energy announced on 3 June this year has now been deferred? Will he also acknowledge that the prospects for a uranium enrichment plant in Australia are receding rapidly and that his efforts over recent weeks to build up expectations in South Australia and elsewhere that such a plant could be operating in four to five years have been deceitful and mischievous?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the letter the honourable member mentioned, but let me remind him of an answer I gave to this House previously. We had received a report from the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia which said that it preferred and had selected the Urenco-Centec technology for the enrichment of uranium and would now proceed with a commercial evaluation of the carrying out of enrichment in Australia. That is the situation at the moment. Until it has done that commercial evaluation it cannot proceed with an enrichment plant. It is very logical and sensible that Australia should move to the beneficiation of a raw material such as uranium so that we get the added value of it. It is part of this Goverment's policy to have the treatment of ores carried out so that there is an added value from which all Australians can benefit.

ANSWER.PARA: We know the policy of the Australian Labor Party. It is quite clear. The Leader of the Opposition said in South Australia only a few days ago that he was against the enrichment of uranium. That is quite clear. Any prospects of uranium enrichment in South Australia are killed by the Labor Party's policies. We know that it will not be allowed in New South Wales or Victoria. The only two States that the Uranium Enrichment Group has selected are Queensland and South Australia. It is not an option in the Labor States. If South Australia were stupid enough to elect Labor to power, then South Australia would not be an option. It is quite clear that under the Labor Party's policies the uranium industry would be killed. There would be no possibility of enrichment or of any further development of the uranium industry. That is quite clear. Nobody in the Labor Party will deny it. It is against the development of uranium. The Leader of the Labor Party sits in his position because of the support he gets from the left wing and the communist union leaders, who are against the development of uranium in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the letter referred to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Prime Minister knowledge of any new requests from the States concerning special measures to alleviate drought problems? Has the Government considered these requests?
—There is a time limit of 15 minutes on this one.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will depend on how many interjections and points of order there are. On a number of occasions Premiers have written to the Commonwealth asking that specific matters be included in the core measures because of particular aspects of drought. This has happened over the years, especially in relation to Western Australia and Queensland but also in relation to the other States. At present there is an outstanding request from Queensland for the construction by local authorities of simple bulk storage facilities for molasses in drought affected areas, in western Queensland in particular. This measure will enable the more efficient bulk transport of molasses to be used as fodder. These measures are being accepted as part of the core measures. They will, of course, have long term benefits which will extend beyond the period of the current drought.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, core measures will be available which will include low interest carry-on loans, which is probably the most relevant of the measures, for horticultural crop growers in the Mundubbera-Gayndah area, where severe losses have been caused by frost damage. That was a request from Queensland. From South Australia there were also requests, because of the particularly severe frost damage suffered in the Riverland area in June. On a one-off basis, because of the overall severity of the drought throughout the eastern States, the Commonwealth is prepared to accept this frost damage as part of the core measures for this drought. It does not want that to be taken as a precedent for all frost damage for all time, but there are particularly severe circumstances at the moment. The combination of drought and frost has put many people under very great difficulties.

The Commonwealth hopes that these measures will be of significant benefit to the people concerned. They are both in response to special requests coming from South Australia and Queensland. I also make the point that I think most States have now accepted that the carry-on loans should be available for small businesses. But New South Wales is still hanging out against that. I make one further plea to Mr Wran to assist small business in the country towns and cities of New South Wales by including eligibility for small businessmen badly affected as a result of drought. Why New South Wales holds out against that particular measure I utterly fail to understand.

—Did the Minister for Transport and Construction cause a Press release to be issued in his name on 1 October 1982 indicating that a contract worth about $11.4m had been let to H.C. Sleigh Aviation Ltd of Melbourne for coastal surveillance? Did the Minister's Press release state that this contractor would be using new Rockwell Shrike light twin aircraft? Was the unsuccessful tenderer for this contract Air Queensland which tendered on the basis of using Nomad 24 aircraft in accordance with what the tenderer believed to be stated government policy to use Nomad aircraft for surveillance work? Was the Nomad subject to test audit on climb performance while the Shrike was not so tested? Has it subsequently been found that the Shrike aircraft contemplated for use are not new as stated in the Minister's Press release and that, subjected to the same audit tests as the Nomad, they did not perform nearly as well? Is it true that the gross weight of the Shrike Commander for instrument flight rules operations has been overstated by 400 pounds, thereby rendering the aircraft ineligible for the award of this contract? How does the Minister explain the gross irregularities continually occurring in his Department in the technical evaluation of tenders and the granting of a tender which, on the face of it, was clearly contrary to expressed government policy?

—The honourable member has asked a very long question. Tenders were called in accordance with normal procedures. Of course, there is a tender board that deals with all tenders. The recommendations of that board were accepted by me as Minister. The technical aspects of the honourable member's question that relate to operational issues are the responsibility of the Minister for Aviation . I understand that allegations have been made by Air Queensland in respect of the technical suitability of the Shrike aircraft to undertake the work. I am assured by my Department that the Shrike does meet the technical requirements to undertake the surveillance operations. However, I will get the details that the honourable member requires and provide them to him as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman is asking for an opinion. That part of the question is out of order.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Trade and Resources relating to the current price negotiations for Newcastle coals for the period beginning 1 April 1983. The Minister will be aware that the prices fixed for Newcastle coals will determine the whole structure of Australian coal prices into Japan in 1983. Is he also aware that the coals produced by the Newcastle group of shippers are very competitive in price on a delivered basis in the Japanese market but progress reports from Japan suggest that Newcastle producers in particular should reduce their price in United States dollars? This is now being followed up by suggestions of reduced tonnages. Will the Minister indicate to Japan that the Newcastle tonnages cannot be replaced from elsewhere at anything like the price at which they can be supplied from Australia and that the mills should not pursue an unreasonable policy in what is already a difficult market for suppliers? Finally, can he assure the House that the Government will stand by the Newcastle companies should the mills endeavour to divide them by using tonnage discrimination against producers leading the negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the difficult negotiating circumstances for the coal industry overseas, particularly with Japan and the steel mills there. The Newcastle colliery owners for a number of years went their own way and endeavoured to negotiate independently with the Japanese steel mills. Last year they joined together as a group and collectively negotiated with the Japanese. This was a much more satisfactory way, rather than six individual people going and negotiating with a single buyer, which put them at a distinct disadvantage. That sort of approach has had my support and encouragement. I hope that the industry sees the virtue of acting as a group and that in the course of the negotiations this year it will put its case as strongly and convincingly as it possibly can. It will certainly get my support in taking that approach. I believe that this is an industry objective that ought to be followed through even more than is being done in the Hunter Valley.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Health. I refer to the Minister's recent statement detailing increases in nursing home benefits in all States. I ask the Minister whether he will explain to the House the seeming anomaly in the $71.75 increase in benefits to Victoria to the amount of $293.30 benefit per week, as against the next highest increase of $35.35 to New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. Finally, will the Minister explain why Queensland receives an increase of $25.20 per week, elevating the new benefits to $168 per week in contrast to the $293.30 per week to Victoria?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Wide Bay for his question. It highlights the very grave difficulties we have with our subsidies to nursing homes because we are dealing, in my mind, with an unsatisfactory system. It is the end result of the Government trying to control prices in every nursing home in Australia over a long period. Basically what we see now is a situation where the individual States can alter the staffing arrangements within nursing homes under State legislation or they can allow inflationary wage settlements to occur . This pushes up the costs of the nursing homes. Under the existing scheme we are obliged to meet those costs.

ANSWER.PARA: The two States where there were the most outrageous increases in costs owing to inflationary wage settlements were Victoria and New South Wales. That led to the situation where we had no alternative under the existing scheme but to meet those rises in costs. One of the very difficult factors in the management of health care is that over the last 12 months or so there have been grossly inflationary wage settlements of the order of 20 per cent, or even more in some cases. This in itself is causing these institutions to look very closely at how many people they can employ. It gets back to this very serious matter of employment. In recent discussions with the Tasmanian Minister for Health Services we looked at our joint problems in this area. We realised that inflationary wage settlements were a very great threat to employment in health care. There is a direct link between the two.

On the more general question about the nursing home situation, the Minister for Social Security, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and I recognise that we face an unsatisfactory system for the control of nursing home costs. We have set up a consultative committee to look into this matter. The honourable member for Grayndler has been chairing a sub-committee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure which has been looking into the matter of nursing homes. I am anxiously looking forward to that report, which the honourable member informs me will be tabled tomorrow in the House. That report will be of great use to the consultative committee which the three Ministers have set up. My aim would be to get us out of this totally unsatisfactory situation, the anomalies of which have been drawn to our attention very directly by the honourable member for Wide Bay.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to his repeated assertions that international competitiveness is crucial to this country's future. Is Australia' s inflation rate of 12.3 per cent nearly double that of our trading partners, whose inflation rates now average 6.6 per cent? What are the consequences of this severe deterioration in Australia's relative inflation rate? What action will the Government now take to reverse the inflationary forces that it has encouraged and to begin to restore Australia's competitiveness?

—I can assure the honourable member for Hughes that I have repeatedly drawn attention to the need for the Australian economy to become more competitive with the economies of the rest of the world. Indeed, if we are to maintain our present living standards and prevent them from falling and, it is hoped, increase our living standards we must become more competitive. The honourable gentleman is quite correct when he says that our inflation rate is now seriously out of line with that of our trading partners. We must, therefore, ask ourselves what the fundamental causes of that uncompetitiveness are. We can make a very major start by recognising the very significant contribution that wage increases have made not only to levels of inflation but also to levels of unemployment. It is no surprise that those very industrialised countries to which the honourable member draws attention with relish in asking his question are countries which have achieved wage settlements equivalent to or less than their levels of inflation over the past two or three years, in stark contrast to Australia, where wages have increased by 3 per cent or 4 per cent in real terms over the last two financial years.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Is it a fact that the Temporary Assistance Authority has carried out an inquiry into the dumping of room air conditioners and parts in Australia and has made recommendations? Is it a fact that some 400 jobs at Kelvinator Australia Ltd in Adelaide are in immediate danger of being lost in addition to the jobs of 300 employees of that company who were given an ultimatum to work a four-day week or face retrenchment? Further, is it a fact that the TAA report has now been in Government hands for some time-I believe a matter of weeks-and that every day that goes by puts more jobs in jeopardy with more imports flooding in? Why is the Government delaying? When will this Parliament be informed of the Government 's decision?

—The answer to the first question is yes. The answer to the second question is yes. The answer to the third question is yes. The answer to the fourth question will be revealed in the course of the next 24 hours. So that there is no uncertainty in the matter, I am prepared to indicate to the honourable member that it is only a minor matter of advising the company of the decision. I would not want uncertainty created in the industry or in relation to the jobs. I will be advising the House tomorrow. The decision has, in fact, been taken.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer to the demonstration by steel and coal workers at Parliament House yesterday which has been described as one of the roughest for many years. Does the Government accept that it has the power to have these people reinstated ? What measures is the Government taking to relieve the effects of the unemployment problem? What is the basic cause of these retrenchments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has already indicated in general terms what the Government has done in this Budget and over the years to create a better climate for investment in Australia, for economic recovery and for job creation. Indeed, the last answer of the Treasurer was very relevant to the question of our international competitiveness. In specific terms we as a government are certainly not responsible for these retrenchments. The matter is before the Coal Industry Tribunal today and has been, in fact, for most of the past month. That Tribunal's hearing has been running parallel with an inquiry of the New South Wales Industrial Commission which brought down its judgment on Monday. Mr Justice Fisher of that tribunal said that because of the state of the domestic and world demand for steel there was no option but for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd to conduct the retrenchments which it had.

ANSWER.PARA: Without prejudging the findings of the Coal Industry Tribunal, I am bound to say that the cause of these retrenchments is the nature of the coal produced. There is no export market for this type of coal. If it were not for BHP's technical ingenuity there would not have been a market for the coal even domestically. The company has blended this kind of low grade coal for coking purposes with other coal. Because of the lower demand of its blast furnaces there is a lower demand for this kind of coal. The company has offered some of the miners other jobs. In fact, the retrenchments represent less than 10 per cent of its coal industry work force at this time. There are other mines in Australia, such as Drayton, where jobs could be found for other miners.

I believe that the mining industry unions, as well as the employers and the tribunals, have an obligation to try to co-operate with this Government. In the end the policies of this Government in respect of investment, retraining and relocation assistance are the only things we can do to assist people to assist themselves. But people need to exercise wage restraint. They need to listen to what this Budget contains to increase real disposable income and not listen to the quite shallow material presented to them yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition. That material has been rightly castigated this morning by a number of economic commentators for misleading people who did not need to be brought here. They did not need to come to Canberra to demonstrate or protest. I have had discussions over recent months with the Lord Mayor of Wollongong and the mayors of Shellharbour and Kiama. There have been continuing discussions between their officials and the officials of several government departments. I have also had discussions with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the steel industry unions and BHP. All those discussions continue as the responsible work of government. We do not need bus loads and train loads of people coming here and demonstrating.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Minister is misleading the House when he says that it was not necessary for the people from the Wollongong area to come here and make their presence felt in order to see the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister well knows that--
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. There is no point of order; it is a point of argument.
—Mr Speaker, can I take a further point of order?
—If it is a point of order, the honourable gentleman may.
—Yes. My point of order is that the Prime Minister well knows, and should have told the Minister, that he refused to see these people until they came here.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.
—He told me last week that he would not see these people--
—Order! The honourable gentleman will resume his seat.

—There is no suggestion of my misleading the House. The question was: What is the work of the Government? What is the Government's role? As one of the Ministers responsible for industry policy, it was appropriate that I saw the miners previously and again yesterday with a colleague. The Prime Minister cannot see every delegation concerned with every portfolio on every subject matter, but in fact he did spend about an hour and a half of his time yesterday with them. The fact is that there are responsible Ministers, of whom I am one, who have been dealing with this problem for a long time and it did not need a public demonstration for that work of this Government to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the right honourable gentleman claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Mr Speaker.
—He may proceed.

—In the House yesterday the Deputy Leader of the Opposition made certain allegations about me based, he said, on claims by Mr Rhys Trevor Volkman that I had interfered with an investigation by the Narcotics Bureau into the activities of Nugan Hand Ltd. The substance of Mr Volkman's claim as quoted by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was that Mr Nugan became concerned at certain investigations by the Narcotics Bureau and approached the then member for Riverina, Mr Sullivan. Mr Sullivan is then supposed to have approached me and I in turn am supposed to have approached the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Fife, suggesting that there may be some slow-down because the investigation was upsetting primary producers in the Riverina region. Mr Fife in turn is then supposed to have issued an instruction or request that led to a directive by Mr Brian Bates of the Narcotics Bureau.

SPEECH.PARA: I am certain that such a matter has never been raised with me by Mr Sullivan and that I have never made such suggestions to Mr Fife. I contacted Mr Sullivan this morning and he stated that he has never at any time raised anything of this nature with me. I remind the House also that Mr Brian Bates has denied that he was directed by any Minister of the Crown to suppress the investigation by the Federal Bureau of Narcotics into the activities of the Nugan Hand banking corporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable gentleman may proceed.

—The House will be aware that I was Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs between 17 July 1977 and 8 December 1979. Yesterday during debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83 the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) referred to allegations which had been made by a former officer of the Customs Bureau and which suggested that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) and I had been in some way involved in slowing down an investigation into the affairs of Nugan Hand Ltd which at the time was being carried out by the then Narcotics Bureau. I do not recall ever receiving representations from Mr Sullivan, the former member for Riverina, concerning Nugan Hand either directly or through the Deputy Prime Minister or someone else. I also cannot recall receiving representations from anyone suggesting that the Nugan Hand investigation by my then Department be terminated or slowed down.

SPEECH.PARA: I have recently asked my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), who now has portfolio responsibilities covering these matters, to have the relevant files checked to see whether any record exists contrary to my recollections. His inquiries to date do not substantiate the allegations that have been made. The implied suggestion that the Deputy Prime Minister requested me to have this investigation terminated or slowed down is false and mischievous . It is also false and mischievous to state that I instructed verbally or in writing Mr Harvey Bates or indeed any other officer of the then Department of Business and Consumer Affairs to terminate or slow down this investigation. On the contrary, because of my concern in respect of this investigation, I repeatedly sought and obtained assurances that the Department was actively pursuing the matter. I also sought and obtained assurances that other law enforcement agencies were investigating the activities of Nugan Hand. I dismiss the allegations that have been made with the contempt which they deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation in relation to the matters just raised by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) and the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife). The matters that I raised yesterday came from the transcript of evidence given by Mr Volkman to the task force dealing with the Nugan Hand Ltd investigation. Mr Speaker, as you are aware, I had to read the evidence to the House because of your ruling that it is inappropriate to try to incorporate documents in Hansard for the reasons which you announced earlier. The significant point, which perhaps both Ministers might like to have investigated, is contained in a further part of the evidence which would certainly clarify the situation. That file of 150 pages relating to this matter-that is, the file of the Narcotics Bureau, which has now been disbanded- has now been reduced to a mere 42 pages. The question asked of Mr Volkman during the Corporate Affairs Commission investigation was: How could he explain the missing 100 pages of the file? He said that he could not. Perhaps the Ministers could help us by making a further statement.
—Does the Minister for Administrative Services wish to respond to what has been said?
—Yes. What I say may quickly clarify the matter.
—Although the Minister cannot claim to have been misrepresented I give him indulgence to speak to the matter.

—I just make the point, in response to the question that was last raised by the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen), that I am advised that all those files are with the Stewart royal commission. If Mr Volkman wants to make that point or if Mr Justice Stewart wants to take up the issues that have been raised here, those matters can clearly be established in the proceedings of the royal commission.

—The matter to which I refer is the Corporate Affairs Commission investigation of the activities of Nugan Hand Ltd, set up in New South Wales, to which evidence was given on 25 March of this year. That file, or the remnants of it, appears to be available.
—I will not allow the matter to proceed any further.

—I indicate that what has now happened is what led me to the statement I made the other day in relation to the incorporation of unspoken material into Hansard which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has very properly acknowledged. The honourable member for Fremantle has indicated to me that he wishes to raise with me a point regarding that statement. I give him indulgence to do so.

—Very briefly, Mr Speaker, I do not want to canvass the merits of your statement but I do not entirely agree with it. It seems to me that we are at a bit of a disadvantage now in relation to the earlier practice. I wonder whether you would at least consider having placed in the back of Hansard a list of documents for which leave to table is given. Every day there is a list of papers which are formally tabled pursuant to statute or whatever. I think it would make it a lot easier for honourable members if, as well as that list, there were another list relating to documents which would formerly have been approved for incorporation in Hansard but which now, because of your statement, can only be tabled. Perhaps a list of those documents could appear in Hansard. It would be very much easier for reference purposes later if there were some permanent record of what papers had been tabled.
—What the honourable gentleman says seems to have merit at first hearing. I will consider the matter and let him know.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I present a Special Report 1982 of the Official Establishments Trust and seek leave to make a short statement about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members may recall that the Official Establishments Trust was appointed by the Government in September 1979 to advise on the conservation, development and efficient operation of the buildings and grounds of Government House and The Lodge, Canberra, and Admiralty House and Kirribilli House, Sydney. The Special Report concerns proposals by the Trust for the future development of Government House, Canberra, and includes a design, floor plans and perspectives for additions in the form of a new wing attaching to the eastern end of the main entrance.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable members will know, the Government recognises the need for progressive improvements at 'Yarralumla' and the other official residences. It has already implemented a number of important conservation and development recommendations from the Trust's long term program, details of which were included in the Trust's Annual Report for 1980-81 as tabled in this House on 4 May 1982. As a result of the work done and time given by the members of the Trust, I believe that the four official establisments are now better maintained and better equipped for their tasks than for many years. We are indebted to the Trust for that. The Government does not, however, believe that substantial expenditure on such a major development at Government House as is contemplated in this Special Report can be justified in the present circumstances. We thank the Trust for the considerable work that has been put into the Report, but it should be understood that the Government will not be proceeding further in the matter.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Independent Review of Plant Capacity and Equipment in the Commonwealth Government Printing Office. I seek leave to make a very brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's decision to establish this review was made in the context of its consideration of the sixth report 1978 of the Standing Committee on Publications. The purpose of the review was to ensure that capital equipment employed by the Government Printer was not excessive and was basically directed towards meeting the printing needs of the Parliament and the urgent and confidential needs of the Government. An independent consultant, Mr H. W. Paterson, was appointed to carry out this review. The Government has considered Mr Paterson's report and has accepted his conclusion that the current capacity of the Commonwealth Government Printing Office is essential to cope with the peak requirements of Parliament and the urgent and confidential needs of government as the needs are presently understood. However, the Government has directed the Department of Administrative Services to discuss with departments, including parliamentary departments, the amount of work required to be processed at the Government Printing Office and to review printing pricing policies.
