DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The threat to Australia's social stability brought about by the collapse of the employment market and the Government's attitude to this problem.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —For some time, by motions in this House-most recently on 18 August, 8 September and 13 October-and by statements outside this House, I have been attempting to warn the community of the increasingly dangerous social implications of rising unemployment in this country. Unfortunately, on most occasions the reaction of the Government to those statements and motions has been one of complacency. I suggest that any complacency for which the Government may have perceived there were some grounds should have been dispelled totally by the events around this House yesterday. I make it clear on behalf of the Opposition that we are not condoning violent action. However we condemn completely what is already emerging as an attempt to paint the events of yesterday as merely the results of some organisation of extremists.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened in the surrounds of Parliament House yesterday, if looked at carefully and closely, as I had the opportunity of doing, reveals the depth of despair that is spreading amongst ordinary decent Australians, who are seeing two things: They are seeing a loss of jobs and a threat to their jobs-that is bad enough-but they are also seeing an attitude of government which, as I have had cause to say before, is one of complacency, avoidance, diversion and, indeed , deception. The combination of these facts-the rising unemployment and the attitude of this Government-is giving rise to the attitudes which we witnessed here yesterday.

I make this point at the outset: There is already evident an attempt by some people to make moral judgments about the action of people around this Parliament yesterday and easily to condemn them. I make the point-I suggest it is irrefutable-that no member of this Government, from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) down, has a right to make moral judgments about and condemnations of the people who came here yesterday unless his own position is impeccable. The Government's position is not impeccable. As I will show, in respect of unemployment the Government has been not only incompetent in terms of its economic policies but also despicable in terms of its refusal to accept any responsibility whatsoever for this emergingly disastrous situation. It simply contents itself with a persistent series of diversions and allocations of blame to others but not to itself.

Very briefly, because I think the dimensions of this problem should be very clearly in the minds of people, I will again try to get into the consciousness of members of this Government and the community just how bad this problem is and how it is accelerating in its dimensions. I remind the House that in statement after statement over recent months I have been trying to point out what these dimensions are and how the problem is rapidly getting worse. On 21 October I had cause to say that Australia is in the midst of a massive jobs crisis. I pointed out that, on the basis of available statistics, the number of people in full time employment in September 1982 was 72,000 lower than it was a year earlier. I pointed out that young people are the major victims of the jobs crisis and that full time employment among teenagers fell by 43,800, or 8 per cent, over the previous 12 months. I talked about the increase in long term unemployment. The facts are that now over 170,000 people wanting full time work have been out of work for more than 6 months.

It will be well in the consciousness of members of this House that recently we have had evidence of an alarming acceleration of unemployment. In the event we saw the adjustment of the calculations made by the Government in the Budget Estimates of the number of unemployment benefit recipients. It went up from 395, 000 to 460,000, which was the last guess of the Treasurer (Mr Howard). In September the number of unemployment beneficiaries had jumped by the remarkable figure of 25,000-24,900, to be exact-to 446,300. That occurred at a time when in seasonal terms there is normally a downturn in unemployment. The figures to which I have been referring in terms of the acceleration of this crisis were confirmed by a statement in the 'Australian Bulletin of Labour' from the Flinders University National Institute of Labour Studies Incorporated. It confirmed what I had been saying just a few days before about the level of unemployment next year. According to that independent institute at Flinders University, unemployment in Australia could reach 638,000 or 9.2 per cent of the work force by the end of this financial year.

If honourable members want other indications, I refer to the recent release of the ANZ Bank, which contains its employment advertisement series. One sees there the remarkable evidence of the total collapse of the employment market in this country. In seasonally adjusted terms, the number of advertisements for employment in the major State newspapers has collapsed totally from a figure of 20,737 in June 1981 to 12,236 in September 1982. In other words, in a period of just over 12 months there has been a 41 per cent collapse in the number of jobs advertised. In the last quarter there was a 21 per cent decline in the number of jobs advertised against a 2 per cent rise in the previous year. In the September quarter, in seasonally adjusted terms, there was a jump of just under 50,000 in the number of unemployed people. I point out, as I have had cause to do in recent Press releases, that whilst we must be terribly concerned about the impact of unemployment on our young people-it has reached the level where one in five of our young people is unemployed-we should not forget that, in the most recent period, the fastest growing category amongst jobless people in this country is men in the prime of their working lives, as it has recently been put. In other words, we have the situation where men in the 35 to 54 age category are out of work for a longer period than anyone else. The average duration of unemployment for male breadwinners in that category is now over 10 months, and that category of male breadwinners has been the fastest rising category of unemployment in the last 12 months.

So much for the dimensions of unemployment. I hope that at this stage we do not have to spend any more time in persuading people about the dimensions of unemployment and about the fact that it is accelerating. We should not have to waste any more time. We have been trying to get this into the minds and consciousness of members of the Government for the last 12 months. On every occasion when I have gone with the evidence the Government has used some diversionary excuse, some attempt to say that unemployment is not as bad as it really is. For God's sake, the Government should accept the fact that we are facing the total collapse of the employment market in this country. Let us go from that to analysing what the Government's attitude has been.

I hope that in the last few minutes that are available to me I will be able to put to the Government that the Opposition and the trade union movement are prepared to work with the Government constructively to do something to improve the situation in this country. We must accept the fact that up until this present time the Government has sought to avoid, to evade and to blame others. Before I say anything else, I plead with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee), who is at the table, not to spend all his time in reply talking about wages and the trade union movement and blaming everyone else. Will the Minister break new ground this afternoon in this House by accepting, on behalf of the Government, that this Government has some responsibility in terms of the economic policies it has been pursuing? Will the Minister concede the possibility that the Government may have been mistaken and that there may be room for improvement in the economic and social policies to be pursued in this country? He should not just give us a dialogue of abuse of the trade union movement. We will concede that what happens to wages is not irrelevant. The trade union movement has conceded that. The Opposition and the trade union movement are prepared to talk with the Government.

The Government has to face up to the fact that very responsible people in this country are expressing a fundamental concern about the stage this Australian society has reached in regard to the question of unemployment, and I will go to just two or three examples. I refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 28 July 1982 and a reference to the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Sydney. The article states:
. . . Cardinal Sir James Freeman, called yesterday for a conference between Commonwealth and State governments, trade unions, employers and welfare groups to grapple with unemployment.

The Cardinal added: 'The figures must surely disturb our entire community, including those who normally ignore the problem of unemployment simply because they personally have not been victims of its totally demoralising effects.
He went on:

There is a challenge here which demands that governments and the public should face up to the situation with more than words or cosmetic treatment, before our worsening economic crisis gets completely beyond control,'

That was said by the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Sydney. I turn next to an article in the Australian of 31 July which refers to what the Chairman of the Australian Law Reform Commission, Mr Justice Kirby had to say. It states:
He cited the Brixton riots in London as a warning of what could happen in Australia if a 'whirlwind of discontent and alienation' was allowed to sweep our unemployed.
He said there was a danger with endemic unemployment that it could undermine the general acceptance by the community of the legitimacy of Australia's legal machinery.

Let me take the matter from those general condemnations to the tragedy of the impact in a personal sense. I refer to an article in the Age of 16 October under the heading: 'Unemployment found to affect the psyche'. The article states:
A West Australian research psychiatrist analysing the link between unemployment and psychiatric disorder among young people under 25 has found three groups to be most at risk.
The article then refers to the work of Dr Finlay-Jones. It continues:
Dr Finlay-Jones found in his study that 49 per cent of the unemployed group suffered severe psychiatric disorders and three-quarters of these were cases of depression.

I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to this House: For God's sake, let us get beyond this simple cosmetic approach of the Government of saying that it is all someone else's fault. We are not saying it is all the Government's fault. But for God's sake, we are saying that there is a very considerable degree of responsibility on the part of the Government. We on this side of the House do not say that we have a magic answer which contains all the solutions, but we do say that we approach this issue with intregrity and not simply trying to score political points. We do not want to come to electoral power on the backs of a growing army of unemployed in this country. What we are saying is that we believe we have available some sensible ideas and some better approaches. We believe that the Australian Council of Trade Unions has shown in the offer that it made a few weeks ago that it has the possibility of a constructive approach. I am not saying that its proposals were perfect-and I doubt whether it is saying that-but it does recognise that what happens in the industrial field can have an impact upon the level of unemployment.

So what have we got? We have the Labor Opposition in this House saying: 'All right, we think there is a better way. We are not necessarily saying we know all the answers'. We have the trade union movement conceding that it has a responsibility; it has a concern and it has ideas. We are prepared to look at this matter now in terms of what I have been trying to say for years and increasingly in recent months-that this is not just an economic problem; it is increasingly a problem of fundamental social dimensions which, if allowed to go unchecked and be faced by the same callous attitude of the Government, will rent the social fabric of this country.

In conclusion I plead with the Minister: Do not give us another quarter of an hour of abusing the trade union movement and abusing the Labor Opposition. Accept the hand of co-operation which is put out and change your course of action before it is too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I defy the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) or any other member to the Opposition to point to 15 minutes or even five minutes of abuse, scapegoating, or blame by me of the trade union movement in its approach to this problem.
—You point to one time when your Government has accepted any responsibility.
—Order! The honourable member for Wills will remain silent.

—I did listen to the honourable member for Wills. He directed a number of questions specifically at me. I am now specifically answering them. He spoke of the simple cosmetic approach. I venture to say that the approach taken by the Opposition consistently on this issue has been open to the accusation that it has been a simple cosmetic approach.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me talk about the issues of co-operation, the attitude of the Government and the question of blame. We have shown-the Budget which has just passed through this House is a very good illustration of this-great concern for the individuals who have become unemployed as a result of the domestic and international recession. We have shown great concern to get industry moving, to retain employment as it now stands, to get longer term investment and restructurings so that jobs can be found. We have shown a series of initiatives with local and State governments and the trade union movement as well as with industrial organisations to try to get some long term, permanent, restructured industrial opportunities for people in this country. Again, consistently, we have produced a package of training programs to provide people with the skills of the kind we will need in this country. This Budget does a great deal in that regard. In fact, it does much more than any of the traditional economists would have thought was possible, given the nature of the economy.

Again, without I hope unnecessary repetition, let me remind the House of the fact that the Budget that is currently before Parliament contains a number of measures aimed at enabling industry to plan with certainty for the future so that it can make long term investment decisions which will give people the prospect of jobs with certainty-not temporary jobs but permanent jobs. The Budget contains also a very great lift in the funding of the training programs which will enable people to acquire skills to be more competitive in the depressed economic circumstances when they apply for jobs. Through the variety of programs they will have a higher level of skill. They will be equipped also when the economic upturn comes so that they can gain employment. The industrial investment will be matched by a comparable level of skill.

In terms of the attitude of the Government, in particular regarding yesterday's events, one would have to say this: As I said in Question Time, discussions were under way which we, as a government, had been having with the responsible organisations, including local government and the trade unions. I think it is very sad indeed that the social problems of which the honourable member for Wills has spoken-which we have all acknowledged-should be capitalised upon in the way in which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) did yesterday. I heard part of what he said. I have read other statements that he allegedly made yesterday. I believe he was using some of those retrenched people as pawns in a political debate. That is a very serious matter of concern. Who would lead them to think that a government has a magic wand? It is not the honourable member for Wills in his remarks today or, as far as I heard them, yesterday. But the Leader of the Opposition talks about guaranteeing the jobs which they have just lost when he knows there are no markets for the coal or for the steel in question. He talks about an Australian Labor Party government telling Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd that it has to do certain things, to make certain investments.

TALK.START.PARA: —No markets? What about the imports, Minister?
—Order!
—Let us deal with that, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am quite happy to do so although I will not be diverted from answering the honourable member for Wills. I will answer this interjection.
—Because the argument you put so far does not hold water, you are descending in your argument to an attack on the Leader of the Opposition. We want to hear what you are going to do about it.

—This is a very interesting diversion as well. Apparently, there are two rules for debate. Apparently the Government always has to indicate what it is going to do; the Opposition never has to indicate a policy. One of the cosmetics--
—It is the Government's responsibility.

—The Government accepts its responsibility. It has said so time and time again. In this Budget it has put its money where its mouth is. It is interesting that whilst the honourable member for Wills and some of his former trade union colleagues make economically responsible statements, the Leader of the Opposition, whose responsibility it is to present Opposition policy, presents extravagant speeches on the Budget, in the week after the Budget speech , on other occasions in this House and again yesterday, which, if costed, could only worsen the inflation rate in this country and could only worsen the employment prospects of other people. He really will reap the effects of the whirlwind but, sadly, so will many of the people whom he was addressing yesterday if he ever comes to power and tries to implement the undertakings that he made yesterday.
—You are completely bankrupt.

—If the honourable member will stop interjecting I will come back to answering what one has to take as a serious debate and serious questions raised by the honourable member for Wills. We have not sought a dialogue of abuse of the trade union movement, which was the phrase used. On the contrary, from the time of the tripartite conference in particular we have sought to work with the trade union movement. Our one area of disagreement with the trade union movement at this point is that the concession that it believes it has made-that it will press only for the maintenance of real wages-is not a concession which is sufficient in the present economic circumstances to be sure of retaining jobs and laying the foundations for the economic recovery for which we all strive.
—You mean you want to reduce real wages.

—Exactly. I am reluctant to say it but I have said it before and I will say it again: There is no option at the moment other than for those people who are in employment over the next few months to take what amounts to a real reduction in wages; to take the money which is due on 1 November, next Monday, by way of the effect of this Budget, and to recognise that, by seeking to get more than the capacity of the economy to pay, they worsen the employment prospects for those who are currently being disemployed and actually accelerate the rate of disemployment. I understand that the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions was on Channel 7 this morning and, in fact, was arguing that really there are 93 per cent or 94 per cent--
—He said 92 per cent.

—I bow to the honourable member for Lalor, who watches all these programs. The President of the ACTU said that 92 per cent of persons are currently in employment. One could be forgiven for feeling that he, unlike his predecessor, has not yet got the message that people making up that 92 per cent cannot just press for the maintenance of their current level of real wages except at the expense of some of their 92 per cent and certainly in a way which is prejudicial to the prospects of re-employment of some of those who have been shed in the last few months. I accept the social consequences to which the honourable member for Wills has rightly referred. The Government certainly accepts the ultimate responsibility for trying to get the co-operation of people . But beyond jawboning it is difficult to know what we can do to induce the President of the ACTU to understand that at this stage there is an obligation to tighten the belts and to have what virtually is a wages freeze for the next few months.

SPEECH.PARA: We accept that the dimensions of the problem are very serious. Not for one moment have I run away from the kinds of descriptions the honourable member for Wills has given here today and elsewhere. However, I do not think that such descriptions ought to be so dramatically overstated that they actually create an even more pessimistic psychology in the community than that which now exists. It is important for people to get an understanding of the gravity of the situation so that they will moderate wage demands or take more serious approaches to productivity improvement. But I do not believe that the situation should be so overdramatised that, in fact, it deters investment and deters people from taking advantage of employment and training opportunities.

One thing which is most disturbing about the nature of these seven debates-this is the seventh matter of public importance on this subject which has been raised since the Budget; it is an important subject and I do not deny that it is appropriate to debate the matter seven times-is that one would have thought that in those seven debates, six of which have been led by the honourable member for Wills, we would have actually had an outline of the alternative policy, if there is one, of the Labor Party in respect of this matter or acceptance of an invitation such as we extend today for the Labor Party to work with the Government to try to find a bipartisan approach. In fact the honourable member for Wills-I suspect that it is because of embarrassment caused by some of the wide and rash statements of the Leader of the Opposition-has tried, as a substitute for not having a policy in that regard, to pretend that the Labor Party has a monopoly of concern about these matters.

Nothing could be further from the truth. If there were a magic wand we would certainly wave it. There is not. One cannot, in the end, get away from fairly orthodox economic management. In the end one cannot get away from the fact that if the markets are not available for what is dug out of the ground, grown or manufactured and these products cannot be sold, one cannot go on employing people to do those things. For the steel industry there has been a drop in export markets at the same time as a drop in domestic demand. So the imported steel products are those we do not make, do not make in volume or cannot make competitively. But if we were to put up all the barriers against imports of some of the things we cannot make competitively, other people would put up other barriers against some of the things we do make more competitively and sell. That would disemploy a whole range of other people. It is no easy solution to say that we will put up more protective barriers or that we will put on this or that protective device without running the risk of retaliatory action which can only worsen the employment situation for someone else somewhere else.

I submit again that the Government has shown a consistent approach in trying to take a longer term view. Parts of primary and secondary industries have already undergone a very major restructuring. The fact that we hear nothing about them now is probably a result of the fact that good news is not reportable news. It is regrettable that the steel industry was one of those industries which did not undergo a restructuring when times were more buoyant. Had that not been so we would not have in fact had the problem with which we are now faced. The repetitive amalgam of statistics from the honourable member for Wills, quotes from his and other previous statements of the Opposition, readings of editorials and all the rhetoric we are accustomed to are no substitute for ideas. We have not received any ideas from the Opposition. In fact, there has been no rebuttal by the Opposition of the assertion I made in the debate on 13 October. There has been no rebuttal by the Opposition of the National Times article I quoted then at some length, to the discomfort of the Opposition, stating that in fact the Labor Party was working from an interim employment platform and had overlooked the preparation of a final platform for the biennial conference of the Labor Party.

Let us not deal with this subject by saying that what is happening is all the Government's fault, that there is no social concern, that this is a callous government and that the attitude of the Government led to the displays of yesterday. I wonder who paid the fares for some of those people who came to Canberra yesterday. I wonder who induced them to come. I wonder who thought that they should come here and demand action from the Government. Any reasonable economic adviser-the Labor Party has such people available to it-would have told those people that this was not the avenue for achieving what they want. People were received by me here a week or so ago as part of a delegation. There were other people who can-

TALK.START.PARA: —You had nothing to say to them.

—As the honourable member for Cunningham would know-the honourable member and I debated this matter in the debate on the Estimates in this Parliament the other day-the market position speaks for itself. I defy the honourable member for Cunningham to advance any policy which would work in respect of his constituents and which would not at the same time provide a worsening of the employment prospects for someone else somewhere else in Australia. The Government has shown its concern time and again. It asks for the support of all the people in Australia, including the trade union movement, the State governments, the tribunals and the Opposition. We are concerned. We are doing all we can within our power. We now ask people to take long term, realistic views of what is a grave situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At last we have had from the lips of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee), in all its naked truth, as far as what it means to the workers and trade unionists of this country, what the Minister is about. The Minister has admitted that what he is really about is effecting a massive cut in real wages in this country.
—I did not say 'massive'.

—The Minister implied that that was the only thing that would work. I point out to the Minister that recent levels of real wages have risen very sharply in most of the successfully managed economies throughout the world. I cite Japan as the best example of that. In Japan inflation and unemployment levels are both at less than 5 per cent. That gives the lie to the Minister's suggestion as a remedy. The fact is that after seven years of Fraser Government economic vandalism we have an inflation rate of 12.3 per cent and an unemployment rate of over half a million people in true figures. A Budget blow- out of about $1 billion is on the cards. When the Minister talks about what the Budget will do to alleviate unemployment of course he neglects to mention the fact that the Treasury estimates were at least 70,000 too low and that, in fact, the Government will be paying some $300m or $400m more in unemployment benefits than it set out in the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: After seven years of fight inflation first policies by which this Government has destroyed centralised wage fixation and expanded unemployment, as I have said, to half a million plus, we have reached the position that workers have to come to Canberra as they did yesterday to see the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Jobs are being lost in heavy and manufacturing industries at an alarming and accelerating rate. We are witnessing as a direct result of this Government's actions-or should I say inactions-the deindustrialisation of Australia, the rapid and rocketing collapse of manufacturing industry in Australia. It is all very well to speak of restructuring manufacturing industry, of opportunities for new and viable industries and of new opportunities for high technology industries. That is all very well and supportable but many existing modern and previously viable industries are collapsing around us because of the policies of this Government.

For instance, let us look at the list of jobs that have been lost or will be lost in the near future by retrenchments announced by the companies. International Harvester Ltd has already run down its work force by 1,600 and has announced a further 600 jobs to go at Geelong and Melbourne. Qantas Airways Ltd is threatening the loss of 1,000 jobs. At the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd, a run down of 500 jobs has already occurred. The other day 254 retrenchments were announced in Australian Motor Industries Ltd. General Motors-Holden's Ltd has run down its labour force by 2,000 in the last two years and has threatened a further 350 retrenchments. Ansett Airlines of Australia has retrenched 350 people. In Tasmania Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd has threatened to retrench 350 people in the next three weeks. Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd at Burnie has already announced 190 retrenchments. The Electrolytic Zinc Co. of Australasia Ltd at Risdon has run down 150 positions and 350 retrenchments have been announced. Rossarden has announced the loss of 91 positions and 109 retrenchments have already occurred.

Retrenchments are occurring all around Australia. Even as we are talking, the rate of retrenchments is accelerating. It has rocketed in the last few weeks as a result of this Government's policies. The situation is worst in steel and ancillary coal mining industries. Already at the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd steel division at Port Kembla we have seen a run down of 2,700 jobs and 1,730 jobs at Newcastle. Some 950 are to come plus another 260 fourth-year apprentices , for whom the company does not have work are to lose their jobs. Another 1,750 people will go in Newcastle and I will come to Whyalla in a moment. Some 800 people will be sacked at Port Kembla along with 260 fourth-year apprentices, 250 at Newcastle and, of course, the 440 miners. At Whyalla 500 jobs at the steel complex have already been shed by attrition. In November 340 more jobs will go, it is hoped by attrition and voluntary retrenchment schemes but, of course, voluntary retrenchment will dry up in today's economic climate when it is so difficult to get employment. We all know that at Whyalla it will eventually come down to retrenchment-sacking-just as has occurred at Port Kembla and Newcastle. These job losses have been effected so far by attrition, or voluntary retrenchment schemes. But eventually it comes down to compulsory redundancies or retrenchments which is simply a nice way in which to tell people that they have got the sack, that there is no further employment for them. When attrition dries up as a means of effecting job shedding the sackings follow. That is what will occur at Whyalla, at Lysaght in Westernport if the economy does not not pick up and unless there is some relief from imports.

BHP steel division can well afford to withdraw these retrenchment notices. While it lost $12.6m on its steel operations in the last financial year, it made $105m the year before. Last financial year its total group profit was $365m. The reason for all of this is, of course, primarily the domestic depression, the falling consumption rate of steel in Australia, import penetration, and to a certain extent belated technological changes in the industry or changes to the steel-making process. Production is falling. Last year raw steel production fell by 24 per cent or 561,000 tonnes compared with the year before. Consumption is slotted to fall, according to BHP's assessment of a couple of years ago, from 5. 6 million tonnes to 4 million tonnes next year. That is a tremendous drop in projected domestic steel consumption.

I turn to the reasons why people came here to see the Prime Minister yesterday. Mr Speaker I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter which I sent to the Prime Minister last week asking him to meet these people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's request cannot be granted . It is inconsistent with the Speaker's ruling on the incorporation in Hansard of material.

—I wrote to the Prime Minister last week asking him to meet a combined deputation of unionists representing people to be sacked. He refused to meet a deputation. He changed his mind early yesterday and told my office that he would meet a deputation from the Illawarra Development Corporation and one trade unionist only, the General President of the Miners Federation. After a concerted demonstration yesterday afternoon, he gave those people two hours. Yet the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations had the audacity to say today in this Parliament that there was no need for those people to come to Canberra and demonstrate in the way that they did because they could have achieved the same result by way of a deputation. I repeat that they were knocked back by the Prime Minister until they came here and made a fuss.

SPEECH.PARA: What did the Prime Minister tell our steel people yesterday? Apparently they were told that the Government would support another hearing before the Coal Industry Tribunal and that BHP's steel division would be invited to put up another application to the Temporary Assistance Authority. This infers that the decision made on 26 August to peg import levels at the ridiculously historically high level of the 1981-82 financial year was wrong in the first place. Of course , that was a mistake and the Government has now admitted it to be a mistake. Imports have doubled in the last two years. In certain categories of steel production consumption, imports are running at 32 per cent of domestic consumption. What can we do, the Minister asks? We can do a lot, a damn sight more than what this Government has been doing. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) put a temporary plan before the House yesterday which I do not have time to repeat. However, I go further and say that this Government must offer temporary protection against imports from countries such as Korea in return for a pledge of no sackings in the short term by BHP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The honourable member for Cunningham unwittingly has the habit of addressing the Chair, regardless of the incumbent, as Mr Speaker. Whilst that form of address falls very kindly on my ears I am bound to request the honourable member to be a little more attentive of the precise form of address.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit that I have been bitterly disappointed with the speeches that have been made in this debate by the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) and the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke). Both of those honourable members have told us how bad the problem of unemployment is and appealed to us not to bash the unions. That is about all their speeches contained. I can assure both honourable gentlemen on the other side of the chamber that they do not have a monopoly on concern for the problems of unemployment in this country or the social effect that it is having and likely to have in the future. We on this side of the House have for quite a long time been concerned about the growing problems of unemployment and the effect that they are likely to have on the future of Australia. We have been trying to persuade honourable members on the other side of the chamber and people outside this chamber what could and should be done to protect the jobs to provide opportunities for our young people in the future. Unfortunately some honourable members and people outside this chamber have not been listening or responding to the requests that have been made by the Government over quite a number of years.

SPEECH.PARA: I assure the honourable member for Wills and other Opposition members that we are concerned not only about the growing problems of unemployment right now; we are also concerned to provide opportunities for our younger people and the workers in this country on a permanent, long term basis. We are not concerned about the short term, band-aid measures that are being put to us by the Opposition. We want long term, constructive and productive jobs. The honourable member for Cunningham in his speech said that, to try to protect the jobs of workers at the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, protective barriers should be raised a little higher than they are now. I remind the honourable member that Australia is a trading nation. We depend for our prosperity, for our opportunity -creating prospects, on selling products on the international market. If we put up protective barriers we are not only protecting those products that are sold within Australia but we are also preventing products from being sold outside Australia. So we would not be creating jobs; we would not be protecting jobs; we would destroy jobs by doing that. I ask the honourable member not to leave the chamber. I am sure he is most interested in my speech. Our policies need to start at the point of creating jobs. We must accept that Australia is a trading nation. We must sell our products on the world market. We need industries which are buoyant and are thus able to sell products on world markets. That is where jobs are created in this country; that is where long term employment will be sustained.

In selling our products on the international market-be they rural or manufactured products-we must look at the factors that the international customer is looking for. That is what will determine jobs in this country. Our customers are looking for a quality product, for cost-competitive product, and for the product to be delivered on time. To create jobs in this country-I urge this on honourable members on the other side of the House-we have to look to satisfying our international customers. We should look at the quality of our products, and particularly at the cost of our products. The Government has been saying for years that we cannot continually push up the cost of production and expect to be able to compete on world markets. Unfortunately, Opposition members , the trade union movement and people in industry have not been listening. They have not taken notice of what the Government said. They have now forced Australia into a position where we are uncompetitive and pricing ourselves out of jobs. Who do we blame for that? Do we blame the Government for being perceptive and telling us years ago, or do we blame people who simply did not listen?

Let us look at the cost of our production. We all agree that wages are a major component. All of us would agree on that point. The honourable members for Wills appeals to us: Do not bash the unions. I assure the honourable member for Wills that I will bash anyone; I will direct any criticism where I think it is deserved. If the unions deserve one up the bracket, they will get it from me. I remind the honourable member for Wills that over the last financal year the hourly cost of wages rose by 20 per cent while the consumer price index rose by 10 per cent. If that is not a cost impediment to our selling products on the international market, what is? Whose fault is it? Is it the Government's fault? The Government consistently went before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to argue for wage moderation. The Commission did not listen; the unions would not listen; industry would not listen. Now we have priced ourselves out of markets. We have priced ourselves out of jobs. Now members of the Opposition, the unions and industry are saying: 'It is the Goverment's fault'. It is not. What rubbish! The Government forewarned everyone that this situation would develop, but no one listened.

I remind the honourable member for Wills that he claimed in his speech that the unions were now prepared to co-operate with the Government to try to improve the situation and to provide job opportunities. Unfortunately, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) did not see the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions on television this morning, but I did. I was disgusted with the President of ACTU because, without even cracking a smile or being in the least concerned, when asked about the rising rate of unemployment he said: 'Well, if unemployment reaches 8 per cent it means that 92 per cent of people are still employed. We in the unions are not concerned about the 8 per cent; we are concerned only about the 92 per cent'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say that.
—He did, I am afraid.
—Did he say he was not concerned about the 8 per cent?
—He did.
—You are not telling the truth. I bet he did not say that.
—Did you see the interview?
—I bet he did not say he was not concerned about the 8 per cent. You are misrepresenting him.
—Order! The honourable member for Wills will remain silent.
—Did you see the interview?
—Are you asserting that that is what he said? If you are, you are a liar.

—I remind the honourable member that the next question asked of Mr Dolan was: 'Will you moderate your wage claims in order to bring down the cost of production in Australia and to provide job opportunities?' He answered: 'Well, the workers, the 92 per cent, realise that there are CPI increases. We have to pursue their claims to sustain their standard of living'. Mr Dolan, on behalf of the trade unions, was saying: 'We are not concerned about unemployment. We are concerned only to try to sustain the standard of living for those people who are lucky enough to have jobs, and to hell with those who have not'. Is that a responsible attitude from the trade union movement? We accept that the problem of unemployment and the creation of jobs cannot be solved by any one group within the community. It is not the fault just of government, of unions or of industry. It has to be a total community problem. Everybody must be prepared to bite the bullet and pull in the same direction to get over that problem. But we will not get over it while one group-unions, industry or government-is not prepared to bite the bullet or do the right thing to create job opportunities for the whole community.

SPEECH.PARA: I hate to disagree with my friends on the other side of the House. I wish we could have some co-operation. I remind my friends on the other side of the House that 75 per cent of Australians work in private industry and 25 per cent work in government employment. So a recovery in the Australian economy has to come from the private sector. The vast majority of jobs provided by the private sector are provided by those firms we can broadly consider as small businesses-those that employ less than 100 people. Not all employment is provided by organisations such as BHP or the large mining corporations; it is provided by the small industries, the small businesses. That is where we have to direct our policy. One of the unfortunate things for small business over recent years has been that we have had a succession of sweetheart agreements between big companies and big trade unions which have said: 'We can give you a shorter working week and increased wages'. What has that done for small businesses? It might be convenient for big business and trade unions, but it forces small business to lay off workers. That is the root cause of unemployment. We must get away from these sweetheart deals so that small business can compete, survive and sell their products on the international market. We will not do that while we have a negative, head-in-the-sand attitude coming from honourable members on the other side of the House, from the trade union movement, or from big business.

TALK.START.PARA: —The discussion is concluded.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHILD; DUFFY; JENKINS; JONES; MILDREN; MILTON
PETITION.TITLE: Australian Postal Commission
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Australian Postal Commission
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:
1. That Australia as a sparsely populated continent requires the maintenance of a high quality postal service as a vital means of communication.
2. That the Australian postal service meets the needs of all Australians.
3. That any reduction in Australia Post's monopoly power to carry letters for reward will destroy the concept of the national postal service and result in:
Increased rates for mail carried outside the capital cities;
A reduction in mail delivery and collection frequencies in non-profitable areas ;
The closure of post offices.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the powers of the Postal Commission to carry letters for reward should be strengthened to ensure that the national postal service is retained in the interests of all Australians.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mr Duffy,Dr Jenkins,Mr Barry Jones,Mr Mildren and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Postal Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That Australia as a sparsely populated continent requires the maintenance of a high quality postal service as a vital means of communication.
2. That the Australian postal service truly meets the needs of all Australians.
3. That any proposal that Australia Post's monopoly power to carry letters for reward be dimininshed will destroy the concept of the national postal service.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the powers of the postal commission to carry letters for reward should be strengthened to ensure that the national postal service is retained in the interests of all Australians.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHILD; CROSS; HAWKE; HOLDING; JENKINS; MILDREN
PETITION.NAMEIDS: HF4; YF4; YD4; CH4; XF7; AI4
PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mr Cross,Mr Hawke,Mr Holding,Dr Jenkins and Mr Mildren.

PETITION.TITLE: South Australian College of Advanced Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This humble petition of citizens of Australia showeth that :
Members of the Community are concerned and alarmed at staffing cuts within the South Australian College of Advanced Education.

Members of the Community are concerned and alarmed at the consequent deleterious effect these staffing cuts will have on the quality of educational programmes and the access of persons to these programmes at the South Australian College of Advanced Education.

We the undersigned citizens of Australia by this humble petition respectfully pray that the Australian Government provide additional funding to the South Australian College of Advanced Education to enable 1982 programmes and staff levels to be maintained and where needs exist, the resources of the College to be expanded to meet the requirements of the community of South Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett and Mr Hurford.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania: Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members in the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the taxes of all Australians will be used to finance a dam that would flood the Lower Gordon and Franklin Rivers in South-West Tasmania. Your petitioners declare that the intrinsic values of this area, and the provision of funds from the taxes of all Australians, for the destruction of this area of the National Estate and of world heritage value, does make this a national issue. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government take all possible steps, including financial and legal steps and fulfil its responsibilities under the Australian Heritage Act to prevent the destruction of this area of the National Estate, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fry and Mr Sainsbury.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Marine Mammals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whale Protection Act 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale byproducts, and
2. the Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the international banning of whaling,
3. then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal byproducts, including the harp seal of Canada, and

4. through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal byproducts and support an international ban on slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Humphreys and Mr White.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully complied with in respect of Natioinal Estate Areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That allowing the tax deductibility of donations to only the RSPA, is a form of discrimination against equally worthy animal welfare and rights organisation whose work undeniably benefits animals and the community. Their financial resources are severely impaired by this restriction of not having tax deductibility on donations made to them.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House allow tax deductibility on donations made to Australian animal welfare and rights organisations, approved by the Federal Treasurer's Department.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that Australia Council funding for the Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland has been entirely cut for 1983.

The Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland has made an important contribution to the cultural and artistic life of the Australian community for the past eight years taking innovative and original theatre to sections of the community who would not normally attend live theatre performances.
The Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland is the only theatre company in Australia which consistently presents theatre of social comment and tours nationally every year.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will resolve to ask the Australia Council to reverse its decision in respect to the Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned by the Government's failure to act to relieve the plight of many Australians who are being financially crippled by high mortgage repayments.
That we protest on behalf of all those seriously affected by the current crisis in rising mortgage repayments and those facing the near impossibility of obtaining housing loans.
That your Government's policies are forcing a downward trend in the percentage of Australians striving to achieve the 'Great Australian Dream' of home ownership.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should resolve to demand immediate Government action to institute policies which recognise our grave problem and will preserve and maintain the 'Great Australian Dream' of home ownership rather than continue to destroy that dream.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industry Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed mining leases against the advice of conservationists and a State Government sponsored Public Enquiry.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require:
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purpose; and

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research Laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That record high interest rates are:
(a) Destroying the prospects of most young families seeking to purchase a home;
(b) Destroying the chances of national economic recovery;
(c) Contributing to the record number of business bankruptcies;
(d) Contributing to the highest unemployment since the great Depression;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia immediately reverse its policy of high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Student Loans Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the introduction of a comprehensive student loans scheme will:
1. Restrict Access to Education

People from poorer backgrounds will be deterred from studying by the prospect of incurring large debts. These people, if they enrol, will be forced to amass loan debts. Richer students do not face this handicap.
2. Undermine the Teritary Education Assistance Scheme

TEAS should cover the basic living costs of students. Currently the scheme only assists 38% of full-time students and the maximum level of TEAS is a mere $49.67 . Government statements indicate TEAS will be further downgraded if loans are introduced.
3. Disadvantage Women
Women students would be disadvantaged by a loans scheme as they have a lesser ability to repay loan debts, because on average women earn less and have a higher unemployment rate.
4. Disadvantage Mature-Age Students
Usually mature-age students forego income to study and already have large financial commitments. They could not return to study if it meant incurring substantial debts.
5. Distort Educational Choices
Mounting loan debts would force students into studying shorter courses or not continuing with post-graduate study.
6. Result in Massive Attrition Rates

Students will attempt to undertake extensive part-time work or overload courses to minimise their loans. Increased failure rates will result forcing students to 'drop-out' rather than continuing study and increase their debts.
7. Cause Administrative and Financial Difficulties

Overseas experience shows high default rates will occur on student loans. Government money will be channelled away from TEAS to paying off banks. The government will also bear the administrative burden of pursuing defaulters.
Therefore, the proposed student loans scheme will have disastrous effects on tertiary education, which we believe benefits the whole community, not just the individual student.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject the introduction of a student loans scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fretilin Representatives: Ban on Entering Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:

That we strongly condemn the ban on Fretilin representatives entering Australia . We point out that this ban is preventing Jose Ramos Horta, Fretilin's spokesperson on Foreign Affairs and speaker at the United Nations, from giving evidence in the current Senate investigations into East Timor.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth Government take immediate action to lift its ban on Fretilin representatives entering Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Brisbane respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
(1) planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin,
(2) closing country telegraph offices,
(3) increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service,
(4) withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices,
(5) generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff,

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30% of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
