PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Nixon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides for implementation of proposals put forward by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation and the Australian Wheat Board for variations to the existing wheat marketing and pricing arrangements embodied in the Wheat Marketing Act 1979.
Overview

In June of this year I announced that the Government had agreed to proposals by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation aimed at improving the efficiency and flexibility of Australian Wheat Board operations. The proposals empower the Board to operate on wheat futures and financial futures markets, to establish financial reserves, and to introduce options in arrangements for the payment of the guaranteed minimum price-GMP. They also cover machinery aspects of the existing arrangements. The Bill also accommodates a proposal put forward by the Australian Wheat Board, in the context of current severe drought conditions, that the Board be empowered to import and market domestically foreign wheat, should the need arise. Additionally the Bill enables the Australian Wheat Board to act on behalf of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau to secure foreign wheat for Australia's food aid program.

The opportunity has also been taken to introduce modern standard provisions into the Wheat Marketing Act relating to disclosure of interests by members of statutory bodies. The existing marketing and pricing arrangements rely on complementary Commonwealth-State legislation and each of the States intends to amend its legislation to put the revised arrangements into effect. The revised arrangements will apply for the 1982-83 season, beginning on 1 October 1982. The marketing of Australia's wheat will experience particular difficulties in the period ahead. The drought has drastically reduced the national crop and will compound the difficulties of the Board in supplying the requirements of food aid ; the regular and major markets that have been developed over past years; and the domestic needs for human consumption, industrial usage, feed compounders, and feeding of livestock in drought affected areas. The revised arrangements, particularly the authorising of the Board to import wheat and to hedge transactions on futures markets, will give it increased flexibility in its complex marketing task.

The wheat marketing and pricing arrangements to apply beyond the 1983-84 season are currently the subject of inquiry by the Industries Assistance Commission, which is expected to report by 30 September 1983. Experience with the revised arrangements embodied in this Bill will be taken into account in considering new arrangements which might apply beyond 1983-84. Consideration will also need to be given to the views expressed by other interest groups, notably the Flour Millers Council, concerning the appropriateness of existing arrangements including existing domestic pricing arrangements for wheat for human consumption . I now turn to the specific proposals encompassed by this Bill.
Futures Operations

The Bill will empower the Board to hedge wheat and financial transactions on futures markets thus enabling the Board to secure price assurances for its unsold wheat. The Government accepts the view of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation that the Board should be authorised to hedge on futures markets at this time. The authorising of the Board to hedge transactions on futures markets will enable it to use a marketing mechanism that is accepted in international commercial trading of grain. Experience has shown that the hedging of transactions on futures markets facilitates grain trading.

Under the proposed arrangements the Board will be able to hedge on wheat futures markets, currency futures markets, and financial futures markets to protect its wheat sales and also its commercial borrowings used to finance payments to growers. However I emphasise that the Bill carefully defines what is meant by hedging purposes in order to preclude any suggestion of speculation on futures markets. It also provides that the various types of futures transactions will be subject to separate guidelines approved by the Minister for Primary Industry.
Reserves

The Bill enables the Board to deduct moneys from the proceeds of the sale of wheat and wheat products and create reserves that can be used for specific purposes, consistent with the powers of the Board under the Act. The Board will be required to disclose the details of each reserve in its financial statements which will be published in its annual report to parliament. Provisions have been made in the Bill so that the Government's financial liability under the guaranteed minimum price arrangements will not be increased as a result of deductions made for reserves.
Advance Payment Arrangements

Under the existing legislation the Board is required to pay the guaranteed minimum price to growers on delivery of wheat at the beginning of the season. As growers may not always wish to receive the payment at that time the Bill provides for deferment of all or part of that payment until later in the season. Payment of the advance payment to growers will be on the basis of arrangements worked out between the grower and the Board, subject to equity being preserved between growers. Any additional costs arising from the optional payment arrangements will be excluded from the excess commercial borrowing cost reimbursement arrangements.
Allowances and Charges

The advance payment made to growers on delivery of the wheat consists of the guaranteed minimum price adjusted to take account of quality allowances and certain transport, handling, and storage charges. These allowances and charges can vary significantly between growers and States and appropriate deductions for individual growers can be difficult to determine at the beginning of the season. Accordingly, the Act is being amended to ensure that provisional and final adjustments can be made for these charges and allowances and that the full amounts will be brought to the account of individual growers.
Finalisation of Pools

Presently the Board is obliged to hold wheat against the season for which it has been received until its ultimate disposal. This can delay the finalisation of a season's pool and impair the efficient management of the Board's operations. The cost cannot be justified on equity grounds when the volume is small. The Australian Wheatgrowers Federation has proposed that when the stock of wheat held in respect of a season is reduced to a residual level the Board should be enabled to transfer it from one season to another. The Bill provides that the Board should transfer residual stocks from one pool to another only when it has priced the wheat and such a transfer could not potentially cause or add to a call on the Government's commitment under the guaranteed minimum price arrangements. I will be taking up with the Board the desirability of it determining and announcing each season its policy in respect of the residual stock which is intended to be transferred to a later pool.
Redeliveries

Sales of wheat by the Board for stockfeed use are provided for under section 26 of the Act. It is proposed that the section be broadened to enable growers to take redelivery of a quantity of wheat delivered by them during the season at a price determined by the Board. The price charged for the redelivered wheat will be equitable between growers and will be based primarily on recovering the guaranteed minimum price plus any adjustments for quality and storage and handling costs. The redelivered wheat will only be able to be used for stockfeed purposes and may be of a different quality from that delivered initially by the grower.
Remuneration of Authorised Receivers

The Australian Wheatgrowers Federation has proposed that the existing legislative provision be removed requiring the Board to negotiate agreements on the rates of charge with its authorised receivers for services they provide. Accordingly, it is proposed that the Act be amended to provide for the Board to make payments on the basis of rates determined by the authorised receiver in each State and in accordance with the remuneration agreements in force at the time.
Approval of Progress Payments

The Bill also removes the legislative constraint that advance payments by the Board, other than the initial advance, be approved by the Minister. Should the occasion arise where growers are dissatisfied with the rate at which progress payments are made then the appropriate course of action will be for the Minister to take up any representation with the Chairman of the Board.
Consistency of Season and Accounting Year

The Australian Wheatgrowers Federation has proposed that the Board's accounting year be brought into line with the crop year. The Bill provides that the accounting year be brought forward three months from 1 December to 1 October which will be consistent with the 'season' used in other sections of the Wheat Marketing Act 1979. Following on from this change it is intended that the Board' s annual report be submitted to the Minister for Primary Industry by 31 March of each year instead of 30 June, unless a later date is approved by the Minister. In the next reporting period there are likely to be practical problems for the authorised receivers and the Board in fitting in with this new schedule, and it may be necessary for me to extend the Board's reporting period.
Authority to Import

The Bill enables the Australian Wheat Board to import and market domestically foreign wheat, should the need arise. Any specific proposal by the Australian Wheat Board to import wheat will need to comply with quarantine restrictions and will also be subject to the Minister's approval under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. Requests will be considered on a case by case basis and an import need will have to be substantiated. The domestic marketing of Australian wheat is subject to the Wheat Marketing Act 1979 and any foreign wheat marketing on the domestic market will need to be consistent with the provisions for Australian wheat, especially in respect of pricing.
Agency for Australian Development Assistance Bureau

In the context of the current reduced wheat supplies, the Board will also be empowered to act on behalf of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau to secure foreign wheat for Australia's food aid program. The Board's expertise will be used in negotiating shipments of foreign wheat direct to Australia's food aid recipients.
Conclusion

The amendments contained in this Bill arise essentially from proposals put forward by the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation and the Australian Wheat Board . The revised arrangements take account of changed circumstances for the marketing of wheat since the current five-year plan was introduced in 1979. These proposals, especially in respect of imports and hedging, will assist the Australian Wheat Board in its complex task of marketing the Australian crop to the best advantage. Experience with the revised arrangements will be reviewed in the context of consideration of wheat marketing arrangements beyond 1983-84. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr West) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW BUILDING FOR THE AUSTRALIAN FILM AND TELEVISION SCHOOL, NORTH RYDE, NEW SOUTH WALES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of new building for the Australian Film and Television School, North Ryde, N.S.W.

The proposal is for the provision of new facilities on a site of 3.6 hectares of land at Macquarie University, North Ryde. The elements of the work comprise television and film studios, seating for 250 in two small theatres, a dubbing theatre, two radio studios, an administrative library, training areas, workshops and research and technical support areas, landscaping and carparking. The estimated cost of the project at September 1982 prices is $12.85m. I table plans of the proposed works.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT BILL 1982 [No. 2]
Second Reading
Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: Bill 1982, the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax-Promoters) Bill 1982, the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1982 and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Additional Tax) Bill 1982 as they are associated measures. Separate questions will, of course, be put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate.
—Is it the wish of the House to have a general debate covering these five measures? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill ( No. 2) and associated Bills now before the House, far from being the triumph over tax dodgers which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has so proudly proclaimed, represent only the latest chapter in the greatest tax scandal which this nation has ever known, a chapter which again demonstrates the Government's weakness in dealing with tax dodgers. It is a scandal which has encompassed negligence and culpability on the part of senior Ministers, inexcusable government delay, bureaucratic bungling and incompetence, protection of tax dodgers in the Liberal Party's own ranks, irreparable government splits and prime ministerial hypocrisy and inconsistency. The smell of this scandal has tainted not only the entire government but also has reached far into some of the previously most exclusive sections of the Australian establishment. Most of all, however, this scandal has encompassed a massive rip-off of the vast majority of honest Australian taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordinary wage and salary earners and other income earners have had to bear the brunt of record tax levels under this Government to make up for continual government neglect and failure to take prompt, effective and tough action against tax dodgers. For years now ordinary taxpayers have struggled under ever increasing taxes while the Government either refused to act or dithered over what action to take to stop the haemorrhage of tax revenue through tax avoidance and evasion. The Government has continually placed the interests of ordinary Australians second to the interests of persons indulging in a wide variety of tax rorts, an approach necessitated by the Government's knowledge that most of those using these rorts are squarely in the ranks of its own supporters. Now that the Government is belatedly acting to recover some of the taxes stolen, to use the Prime Minister's own word, through bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, ordinary taxpayers can feel little comfort.

The legislation currently before the House is weak and does not go anywhere near far enough to recover the full amount of stolen funds. Whilst the Australian Labor Party does not oppose this legislation we regard it as inadequate in these respects and accordingly will propose amendments to strengthen it and to ensure a strong attack on tax dodgers. The package of legislation before the House to deal with bottom-of-the-harbour type tax evasion schemes, or straw company schemes as they are otherwise known, is in five parts. The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2] is the principal Bill. It sets out the basic conditions under which promoters of these schemes and former share owners in companies dumped under the schemes become liable to repay evaded company taxes and undistributed profits taxes. This so-called recoupment tax will apply to promoters and all shareholders in companies involved in such schemes since 1972.

The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax-Vendors) Bill and the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax-Promoters) Bill formally impose tax on the promoters for 20 per cent of the tax liability and on the shareholders' shares of the unpaid company tax established under the first Bill while the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) ( Consequential Amendments) Bill amends other Acts to fit in with this legislation . Finally, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Additional Tax) Bill amends the income tax laws to increase late payment penalties from 10 per cent to 20 per cent, effective two months after the Bill becomes law, and also restricts the power of the Commissioner of Taxation to remit penalty tax to circumstances of genuine hardship.

This legislation has been hurriedly brought forward by the Government in the face of the extremely damaging revelations made in two government instigated reports-the McCabe-Lafranchi report, which was instigated by the Victorian Liberal Government and had nothing to do with this Government, and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, which was instigated by this Government and the Victorian Liberal Government. Both reports vividly illustrated the incredible growth of the tax avoidance and evasion industry in Australia. Both are stunning indictments of the Government's failure to take decisive action in these areas. These reports concentrated particularly on tax evasion involving the stripping of untaxed company profits through bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. These schemes have spread at an amazing rate. McCabe and Lafranchi gave details of 900 companies, of the total of some 3,000 companies they investigated, which they alleged were involved in all States. The Australian Taxation Office now admits that up to 6,000 companies may be involved. The New South Wales Government reportedly has a list of about 4,000 companies involved in New South Wales. So it is impossible to tell exactly where the schemes stop.

Bottom-of-the-harbour schemes developed out of the so-called dry Slutzkin dividend stripping schemes which were legitimised by a 1977 High Court decision. Dry Slutzkin schemes basically involve the following steps: First, the target company with accumulated profits on which all company tax has been paid is liquidated so that all assets are held in cash. Next, the shareholders of the target company sell their shares to the scheme's promoter for a price close to the full value of the cashed-up company. As far as possible, they avoid any knowledge of the promoter's intentions. Income received in this way by shareholders is a tax free capital gain. Finally, the promoter, through a series of transactions, declares a dividend to milk funds out of the company so that no further tax is paid. An example of the scheme might involve a company with accumulated after tax profits of $1m. Assuming that 40 per cent is distributed to shareholders so that undistributed profits tax is not payable, tax on the $ 400,000 dividend in the shareholders' hands would be $240,000 if the shareholders are on the top marginal tax rate. In this case the true worth of the company, after allowing for tax liability, is $760,000. However, under this scheme the company is sold to the promoter for, say, $900,000-that is, well above its actual value-which represents a commission to the promoter of $100,000 and a tax free profit to the shareholders of $140,000. In effect the shareholders and the promoter have split the tax payable between them. These schemes were subject to amending legislation in 1978 but, as usual, the Government went only half way and further legislation was required in 1981 to stop these activities finally.

So far I have been describing the dry Slutzkin schemes. The bottom-of-the- harbour or so-called wet Slutzkin schemes are a particularly insidious development of the dry variety. They usually involve the target company with current year profits on which company tax has not been paid. Again, the target company is cashed up before being sold to the promoter for a price approximating its full value with no account being taken of the outstanding tax liability. Once again, vendor shareholders are advised to ask no questions. As in the dry Slutzkin scheme, the promoter and the vendor shareholders effectively split the amount due as company tax between them. At this point the essential similiarities between the two schemes end. Whereas in the dry Slutzkin scheme the promoter puts the company profits through some form of tax avoidance scheme to get out of paying taxes, under the wet Slutzkin scheme the promoter merely walks away with the assets of the stripped company in most cases and then transfers its shares and directorships to derelicts, criminals or men of straw with no money and fake addresses, or the company records may literally be dropped in the bottom of the harbour. Either way the company has no assets and it is virtually impossible to trace. Using a similar example to the one I used earlier, a company with untaxed current year profits of $1m would have total taxes owing of about $590,000, including company tax and tax due on dividend distribution to shareholders. In this case the true value of the company is $410 ,000 but it is sold to the promotor for a price well in excess of this value, say, $900,000. This represents a rip-off of public funds to the tune of $590,000 -$490,000 tax free to the company shareholders and $100,000 commission to the promoter.

It can be seen from this example that wet Slutzkin or bottom-of-the-harbour schemes involve straight out tax evasion through the illegal misappropration of funds from the company as well as an element of the so-called dry Slutzkin schemes, which are, in a strictly technical sense, legal tax avoidance schemes which worked within the letter of the law which operated at the time. In the view of the Opposition, there is no way, however, that there is any justification for either aspect of such schemes. They were little more than a highly blatant and artificial device designed to abuse the intent of the tax laws and avoid huge amounts of tax for the greedy few with access to such schemes. Both varieties of this scheme have in common the aim to avoid liability for tax on dividend income paid out of company profits which, when distributed to shareholders, should have been taxed at the shareholders' marginal tax rate. While such distributions in the dry Slutzkin scheme are paid out of already taxed profits, the bottom-of-the-harbour variety goes further, as I have shown, and also evades the tax which should have been paid on the actual company profits before a dividend is paid. So the reason for the higher tax loss from such schemes in the example I gave earlier is that they dodge company tax on company profits and undistributed profits as well as personal income tax on dividend incomes.

The Government has decided to attempt to recoup only that portion of the tax lost under bottom-of-the-harbour schemes represented by the evaded company tax and undistributed profits tax. No effort is being made to recoup the tax lost which should otherwise have been paid on dividends distributed to shareholders. The tax lost from this personal income tax component of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes could be half as much again as the $580m which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) now says the Government hopes to reclaim through this legislation. We have asked the Treasurer, in a letter which was sent to him a month ago, to give us a calculation of the exact or approximate amount which he thinks would be involved in the loss of personal income tax through the use of the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. To date we have had no response. He clearly does not want to give us an answer to display to the Australian public how much revenue in the form of personal income tax was ripped off by this scheme which he is not bothering to pick up in this recoupment tax process. Quite clearly the Government is embarrassed about any publicity of the amounts involved. But there is no doubt that they are substantial. As we understand it, about two-thirds of the 4,600 companies which the Commissioner of Taxation has so far identified as being involved in this scheme had accumulated profits. Therefore, an element of the loss of personal income tax is involved in two-thirds of those companies. We can therefore reasonably presume that several hundred million dollars may well be involved in personal income tax ripped off by the use of this scheme-tax which is not being recouped by this legislation. There is absolutely no reason for this exclusion other than the Government's desire to tread a soft line against tax avoiders and restrict the scope of the legislation so severely. Labor regards the legislation as inadequate especially because of its failure to act in this area.

Basically, these Bills will attempt to recover evaded company tax by establishing a liability to recoupment tax for shareholders and promoters where an arrangement has been entered into to put a company in a position so that it is unable to pay its tax and where the total consideration received for the sale of the company's shares exceeds the net assets of the company, including the outstanding tax liability. In this situation an assessment for company tax due will be issued to representative shareholders, who will then have a period of 60 days to object, if they so desire, to the company tax liability. However, there will be considerable incentive to the shareholders not to object on frivolous grounds, as 20 per cent penalty tax will commence to accrue 30 days after the issue of the initial assessment, unless they can take advantage of another clause which I will mention later. After 60 days each shareholder in the company will become liable to pay recoupment tax equal to a proportion of the unpaid company tax determined by reference to the proportion of total proceeds received for the sale of his or her shares. Again, 20 per cent late payment penalty will begin to accrue where recoupment tax is unpaid by the shareholder after 30 days.

Should the shareholders decide not to contest the assessment they will, on paying a 25 per cent deposit, be able to pay the tax liability in instalments over a 12-month period. This is a provision of the legislation to which we strongly object. In addition, the promoters of these schemes will become liable to repay 20 per cent of the total tax outstanding, this amount being determined on the basis of the average 12 per cent commission charged by promoters on the total value of the stripped companies. Shareholders will still be able to repay the full amount of tax owing and any money recovered from promoters will be refunded to the shareholders. This is the main structure through which the Government proposes to recover some of the total tax lost through these schemes. The legislation is to apply to schemes entered into between 1 January 1972, which is just prior to the date of the first known use of those schemes, and 4 December 1980, the date on which the Crimes (Taxation) Offences Act was proclaimed to outlaw such schemes specifically. There are many other provisions in these Bills to which I will not refer because of lack of time.

While the Australian Labor Party is not opposing these Bills as a whole, we do however have serious reservations about them and about the whole series of events surrounding them. In the first place, these Bills should not have been necessary. Had the Government acted promptly when the existence of these schemes was first discovered, the schemes could have been quickly strangled and revenue losses drastically reduced. The report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union vividly illustrated the history of government inaction against bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Initially some 50 companies were found to be operating these schemes in Perth in 1973. After close examination of existing laws, a decision was made by the Commissioner of Taxation in late 1975 to prosecute the persons involved in this case. Prosecution was to be launched under the Crimes Act for conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth and liquidation proceedings were commenced to recover tax owing. As we know, and has been discussed in debates in this House on several occasions, no such prosecution was ever launched for reasons which I will not go into now because of lack of time. But certainly an important factor to bear in mind in this debate is that although a decision was made in 1975 to take such prosecution no such prosecution was launched in subsequent years and no such prosecution has yet been launched.

A result of this inaction was that no action was taken against the schemes until 1980. The Attorney-General's Department dithered around until that time when it informed the Australian Taxation Office that insufficient evidence existed for criminal prosecutions. Despite the overwhelming weight of earlier evidence to the contrary, the Attorney-General's Department inexcusably delayed this case for five years before deciding that it could not proceed. Absolutely no effort was made to test existing laws. Had a test case been launched under the law as it stood, this would have been a tremendous disincentive for other potential users of this scheme. We in the Opposition strongly feel-in this we are supported by Costigan and several legal opinions-that action in this area stood a very good chance of success.

The Taxation Office was not without some fault during this debacle. While the investigative officer in Perth did a good job in uncovering the initial examples of the scheme, setting up prosecutions and pushing the Crown Solicitor's Office to follow through with them, he was let down by a seeming lack of resolve on the part of head office. Certainly the Taxation Office in Canberra, having been presented with the facts from Perth, made the initial decision to prosecute. But from this point on it apparently lost interest in pursuing the case through the Attorney-General's Department. According to the Costigan report by 1979 the Taxation Office in Canberra had become discouraged by delays within the Crown Law Office. While the Taxation Office began to press the Treasurer for legislative action in 1978 the fact that it failed to follow up on the initial prosecution decision is a poor reflection on its efficiency.

The Treasurer has claimed that the Government was not informed of these schemes until early 1978. In our view the Taxation Office should have gone straight to the Government at least two years earlier immediately the delay within the Crown Solicitor's Office became apparent. However, once it went to the Government in 1978 and stressed the need for action it got little response from the Treasurer or the Government for two and a half years. The Treasurer has made various excuses for the delays, citing the heavy workload of taxation matters, the need for careful scrutiny of criminal penalties, the secrecy provisions of the Tax Act, internal opposition within his own party and the fact that strong public attitudes to taxation avoidance were not then evident. None of these excuses holds water. The simple fact is that the Government and the Treasurer were totally negligent and unable to stomach the tough action which was necessary to end these abuses.

The Treasurer has claimed that he was not made aware of the full implications of these schemes until 1979 or 1980. Yet a brief glance at the so-called ' telephone book of documents' which he tabled in Parliament a few weeks ago gives the lie to this claim. Right from the outset the Taxation Commissioner stressed the extent of the problem and the need for urgent action. In the middle of 1979, following upon extensive delays to that time, the Taxation Commissioner told the Treasurer, and I quote from the documents:
. . . the problem of straw company and straw trust evasion is already very serious and growing. It is my considered advice that the situation needs to be remedied urgently and with stern measures.
Such warnings continued to flow to the Treasurer with the Taxation Commissioner claiming at the end of 1975:
. . . this activity is occurring on a large scale daily.

By the last months of 1980 the Treasury Secretary was backing the Commissioner, stating that the situation had reached an alarming stage. Finally, after some 18 calls by the Commissioner to the Treasurer for action, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was passed outlawing such schemes. This eventual passage of legislation in no way absolved the Treasurer from blame over his failure to act decisively at an early stage over this issue. When he was first warned of the urgency for action he should have acquainted himself fully with the case and demanded all available material on the matter. In this way he would have become acquainted with the Perth fiasco. He should have ensured that existing laws were tested to the full or he should have announced immediately that action was pending and that such action, as it occurred in numerous other cases, would backdate to that time. He took neither course and therefore ensured that the schemes carried on unhindered for a further two and a half years. In saying that he should have taken action to backdate action to that time, I am not referring to criminal penalties.

It is absolutely clear from the events that have unfolded that both the Treasurer and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) have been guilty of culpable negligence in the administration of their departments. Had either Minister acted promptly and efficiently there is no doubt that the current tax scandal would not have reached the stage it has. Despite the overwhelming evidence against both Ministers, the Prime Minister has steadfastly defended them against demands for their resignation. The Prime Minister's action in this situation sits completely at odds with a statement he made in 1972 when he said:

. . . if a major blunder occurred in a Department of real importance to Australia, and if the Minister were unaware of it, the Minister should accept responsibility for the mistakes of his Department and offer to resign.

There could be nothing clearer than that statement from the Prime Minister. Yet we have come to expect the Prime Minister to renege on earlier undertakings and to twist his previous statements to suit the particular situation in which he finds himself. Certainly this trait has come to the fore during the current tax debate. When the Government finally brought itself to act against bottom-of-the- harbour schemes at the end of 1980 it made no effort to recoup the hundreds of millions of dollars already lost through these schemes. Certainly it knew at that time of the massive extent of lost revenue but it was content merely to boast about stopping the schemes while at the same time allowing users of these schemes to keep their spoils. If it had not been for the public outrage stirred up by the combined impact of the Costigan and McCabe-Lafranchi reports the Government would not have taken any action whatsoever in this recoupment area. The Government was compelled by the strength of the revelations made by these reports to take action to recover some of the taxes owing.

Finally, almost two years after the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, the Government has now presented Parliament with legislation to recoup these lost taxes in an effort to defuse public outrage over its abject failure to act at an earlier date. However, this legislation is weak and inadequate and is further evidence of the Government's lack of nerve to tackle the problem head on. The weakness of the legislation is a clear product of the lack of support within the Liberal Party at large and the divisions within the parliamentary Liberal Party over the provisions of this legislation. During the past few weeks the Australian public has been treated to a bitter display of infighting within the Liberal Party over this issue. The Prime Minister, under threat from his back bench, called a meeting of the Liberal Party's national executive to give him so -called unanimous support for the stand taken against the tax dodgers. Yet the very next day the Western Australian Branch President of the Liberal Party went public, saying that his organisation did not support the Prime Minister. It was significant, of course, that the Western Australians were the initial source of opposition. It is not difficult to speculate as to whom they are trying to protect.

In following days we were treated to the spec- tacle of most State branches expressing their opposition to the legislation and of Government back benchers appearing on national television to voice concern for so-called innocent parties and Liberal principle. In truth their opposition smacks more of a desire to protect their own rather than of any concern for principle. The result has been legislation which in the first place was inadequate but which has been progressively watered down to cater to the demands of the party to such an extent that it may be ineffective in many cases.

Let me remind the House of the changes made to the measures since they first became public. Initially, the companies involved were to be subject to penalty tax for failure to lodge tax returns and for late payment from the time that they were initially assessed. These provisions were dropped. Next, the proposed late payment penalty was reduced from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. Last week the original Bills were withdrawn and replaced by a more sanitised version which allows tax dodgers 12 months to pay without penalty, a provision much more generous than anything available to ordinary taxpayers. Next, a provision that the Commissioner of Taxation could name persons involved in these schemes in his annual report was dropped, presumably to protect well known Liberal identities from disclosure. Finally, a very odd clause exempting certain companies has been inserted. We now find that where companies were put into a tax avoidance scheme after sale to the promoter with a reasonable expectation that the scheme would be successful, but which scheme subsequently fails, the companies and the vendors and promoters associated with that scheme are exempted from this legislation. In our view, this clause opens up wide scope for up to 700 of the 4 ,600 companies officially admitted to be involved to escape the legislation, with considerable revenue consequences.

Labor is strongly opposed to this particular provision, as well as to the 12 months to pay clause, which, as I said, is far more generous than anything available to ordinary taxpayers. We will oppose these clauses in the Committee stages of the Bills, and I will outline our objection in more detail at that stage. In addition, we shall move during the Committee stage to reinsert the provisions which allow the Commissioner of Taxation to name in his annual report the people who have failed to pay the recoupment tax. In our opinion, there can be no justification for protecting the identities of such persons, who deserve the fullest weight of public condemnation.

Clearly, the original intentions of the Government have been extensively watered down to adopt a softer approach to participants in this scheme in response to pressures from within the Liberal Party. I am sure that although the Bills are now before the House we have not yet seen the end of attempts to emasculate the legislation. Last week the Treasurer admitted during a Press conference on the steps of Parliament House that further change could be expected. What a ludicrous situation. Obviously the Government is on the back pedal, and all the tough rhetoric from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer about the activities of the tax dodgers and the need for fairness in the tax system can be seen for what it is-just so much hollow rhetoric. There has been nothing more pathetic in recent weeks than the Prime Minister's defence in Parliament of persons using dry Slutzkin schemes which, according to the Prime Minister, were all right because they were tax avoidance rather than evasion schemes and had been approved by the High Court. Yet only weeks before the Prime Minister had condemned them. He stated:
. . . those high priced lawyers and accountants who have devised and promoted tax avoidance schemes . . .
He continued:
do more damage to the basis of this society than a thousand Gallaghers in this world, or a thousand Builders' Laborers Federations.
The Prime Minister also called for an ethical approach to financial transactions , not just a strictly literal approach to the law. He said:
. . . if we have to legislate for every wrongful act . . . then we will be so subsumed in legislation . . . every judge in the land would have to work overtime.

There can be no clearer condemnation of tax avoidance practices than those, yet the Prime Minister quickly forgot those sentiments when forced into defending one of his own. His selective righteousness is contemptible.

I have already indicated that Labor will move in the Committee stage to strengthen this legislation in several important ways. In addition, we wish to move a second reading amendment on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill (No. 2) expressing our deep concern at the total inadequacy of the Bill in several respects. In our view, the legislation is deficient in two key respects. Firstly, it makes no attempt to recoup personal income taxes avoided under bottom-of-the-harbour schemes which should have been paid when accumulated company profits were distributed as dividends to shareholders. I have already shown how these schemes involve loss of revenue from both tax on company profits and undistributed profits and tax on dividend income. These Bills attempt to recover only the first element of evaded company tax and undistributed profits tax and still leave shareholders in an advantageous position, having received a tax-free amount for what would otherwise have been taxable income. There is, in our view, absolutely no justification for delineating between these two aspects of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The Government does so on the basis that the loss of company tax represents tax evasion, which is in some way more objectionable than the loss of personal income tax through what is meant to be tax avoidance. I have already illustrated the Prime Minister's views on the subject, but I will again quote his words. In May 1981 he stated:
'There is no real difference between the person who finds an artificial loophole to slip out of tax and the person who falsely declares his income.'

There we have the Prime Minister saying in 1981 that there is no real difference between tax avoidance and evasion. Yet in this legislation the Government is making that distinction very clearly indeed and justifying not pursuing hundreds of millions of dollars on the basis of a distinction which last year the Prime Minister said did not exist. We on this side of the House reject that distinction in respect of this scheme. Whichever way it has been achieved, either through straight out tax evasion or through the use of some totally artificial and contrived device to exploit the letter of existing law, there is no dispute that a tax benefit has been gained and gained at the expense of ordinary taxpayers. Particularly is this so given that these two components are an essential part of the one scheme and, indeed, are involved in the one transaction. So action against the scheme should clearly encompass both elements . I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-

(1) condemns the abject failure of the Treasurer and the Government, knowing of the existence of straw company tax evasion schemes since at least 1978, to respond quickly and effectively to the massive tax evasion occurring through the use of such schemes;
(2) is of the opinion that the Bill is grossly inadequate in that:

(a) it deals only with company and undistributed profits tax remaining unpaid on current and prior year profits and does not recoup personal income tax lost in relation to accumulated after-tax profits disposed of by vendor shareholders in the same transactions,
(b) fails to recoup sales tax evaded by the use of straw companies,

(c) allows for non-recovery of a substantial proportion of the company and undistributed profits tax lost by use of the scheme because of the deliberate exclusion of an important category of use of the scheme, and
(d) provides for more leniency to tax evaders in respect of the time allowed to pay their assessed tax irrespective of the degree of hardship being experienced;
(3) notes that because of the Bill's deficiencies the sum to be recouped will be far less than that which has been lost through straw company tax evasion schemes; and
(4) calls on the Government to amend the Bill and associated measures so as to ensure that all the tax lost through straw company schemes will be recouped.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired . Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —To an extent the honourable member for Gellibrand ( Mr Willis) is in fact accurate. There is a scandal in this matter. It is a scandal of personal abuse by the Australian Labor Party, of left wing McCarthyism, and of guilt by association as the Opposition has sought to use the Government's effective measures against tax evasion and avoidance as an excuse for transferring the bottom of the harbour into the bottom of the gutter. Let us recognise that the schemes to which this legislation is addressing itself are schemes that were blocked totally by this Government in 1980. The whole tax avoidance debate relates to a remarkable success story by the Government in which $3,000m of claims under avoidance schemes have effectively been blocked by the Government's anti-avoidance legislation-let alone the evasion schemes that have been stopped. So the bottom-of-the-harbour action represents probably no more than about 10 per cent of the total effective action taken against the whole of the tax avoidance and evasion industry. Lest anyone think that that money is lost, there is no doubt whatsoever that a very large proportion of it will be and is being recovered. The present legislation simply seeks to recover the evaded part of that tax liability.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer (Mr Howard) mentioned the other day in Question Time what was happening about the pursuit of many of the avoidance schemes that people may wrongly think they had got away with simply because the Government, to provide surety in this matter, had specifically legislated against these avoidance schemes. The fact is that in all of these avoidance schemes that have received some publicity, and which, as I say, were knocked off many years ago, the assessments are still outstanding and the Commissioner of Taxation is pursuing them slowly through the courts, as the legal process requires. The taxpayer has every right to pursue the matter to the final court.

I put it to the House that the general thrust of what the honourable member for Gellibrand presented was, in fact, nonsensical. I put it to the honourable member that what has happened in the tax avoidance industry is very simple. As the High Court of Australia effectively diminished the usefulness of some of the previous legislation against tax avoidance and in some of its judgments declared that that legislation was, in its view, at the time deficient then, of course, tax avoidance grew rapidly. It grew so rapidly that, in fact, by 1977-78-shortly after the Slutzkin decision and the Cridland decision of the High Court of Australia-claims for deductions generated during the year involving tax avoidance reached an horrific total of $1,860m. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table from the Commissioner of Taxation outlining these particulars of claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The table clearly demonstrates that as the level of avoidance fell as a result of the Government's very successful campaign, the level of illegal evasion rose dramatically until, of course, this Government blocked it. I repeat: This Government blocked it in 1980. One would not know that, of course, if one listened only to the Opposition; one would think it was all still going on. But in fact, that is the reality. To suggest that the Government has been unsuccessful, that it has done nothing, is utter bunkum, and it can be shown to be bunkum. The reason-I must say the reason was totally distorted by the honourable member for Gellibrand-that there have been changes in the current legislation from the legislation that was introduced into this House three or so weeks ago is very simple. The Government was quite properly determined to ensure that the legislation did not extend beyond the limits which were clearly indicated in the Treasurer's statement of 25 July when he introduced the concept of recovery of tax evaded in these schemes to strip companies of untaxed profits. This, I repeat, had been totally blocked in 1980. It was very important, indeed, that the legislation as introduced did not, in fact, extend beyond what the Government had always said it should deal with-that is, illegal evasion of tax. I know that the Opposition finds it impossible to distinguish between what is legal and what is illegal. That reflects its whole approach, I think, to many more things than the tax matter. Members of the Opposition cannot distinguish between illegality and legality but this Government does and, I believe, must, particularly where it is reaching backwards to seek the recoupment of taxes.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been alleged that this is retrospective tax. I suggest that the word is 'recoupment' because what this legislation is doing is not making illegal what was legal at the time; it is recouping the proceeds of something that was always illegal. Surely the Opposition can recognise that very significant difference. We are recouping the proceeds of what was always illegal. The problem is that the people who perpetrated the fraud were not the people who benefited from it. There was always a fraud. What the honourable member for Gellibrand is demanding now is that we go far beyond recouping the proceeds of fraud, which the Government has continually said this legislation is all about. The honourable member wants to recoup the proceeds of quite legal activities, activities in fact that the High Court had held in some instances were legal. The honourable member wants to go back into time and, in fact, to introduce genuinely retrospective legislation that will make illegal something that was legal at the time.

As I have said, what this legislation is seeking to do is simply to make certain that the proceeds of fraud are recouped. I recommend to the House and, I might say, to the parliamentary Press Gallery, that they reread the Treasurer's statement of 25 July to see exactly what the Government has always been about in this matter. There has been no change of direction, no withdrawal, no softening of the thrust of the Government's objectives. The Government has always said, as the Treasurer said, 'having regard to the fraudulent nature of the scheme' and so on. The word 'fraud' has always been the essential element of every statement that the Treasurer and, I might say, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) have made about this legislation. The recent changes have ensured that it does not extend beyond those clear limits that were quite properly set in the Treasurer's initial statement. So there is no need for the Government to be defensive on this matter. There is no need for it to have to justify the caution with which it approached the whole matter of introducing, in the first place, in 1980 criminal liability in a tax matter and of course, in this matter seeking to recoup the proceeds of fraud because of the special problem created by the fact that the person who perpetrated the fraud did not receive the benefit of that fraud.

I stress that this legislation is doing no more than recouping the proceeds of that fraud. It seems to me that the matter of penalties, which was raised earlier, goes beyond that matter of recoupment of fraud. I believe the Government has done the right thing by clearly stating that the past failures by the directors who acquired these companies will not be visited upon the vendors- after all, it was not the vendors who failed to submit a tax return; it was the new owners. The vendors had no control over the actions of the new owners.

It seems to me that there has, of course, been a determined campaign on the other side of this matter-many people feel that this law goes too far-to try to denigrate this law, to say that it is retrospective and against various principles. I submit that that campaign is wrong. I am glad to see that the Government is not dissuaded from pursuing this law by that campaign. I concede that there have been some areas where the need for clearly distinguishing between what the Government was seeking to do and what some people held that this law, in fact, enabled to be done should be cleared up. It seems to me to be quite right that the Treasurer, while sticking clearly and firmly to his 25 July statement, should have made these alterations. This recoupment legislation will, as I said, do no more than recover company tax that was evaded in bottom-of-the- harbour strips of untaxed company profits.

I understand that many people in the Parliament wish to discuss this matter today and that we should seek to limit our remarks. However, I want to stress that the revenue involved in all these matters has not been lost. The allegation by the Opposition that $35 a week has been lost by the ordinary Australian taxpayer is, in fact, a fraudulent claim. If there is any fraud in this matter it is fraud on the part of the Opposition. Its claim is absolute nonsense. The loss of $35 a week suggests something like $10,000m worth of evasion a year which, of course, is absolute nonsense. The total of all the private company profits in Australia in one year is $2,000m. Is the Opposition seriously claiming that five times the total revenue of all private companies has been evaded illegally in this way? It is arrant nonsense.

Let me tell honourable members one bit of reality about this matter of evasion. Something like $3,000m has been estimated as being the proceeds of evasion of a manual kind-the evasion brought about by the cash economy. That is not evasion by big business. That is not evasion by the silvertails. That is, in fact, evasion by ordinary Australians. I would suggest that this is the area in which big evasion now takes place. That costs every Australian family taxpayer something like $10 a week. That is why I commend the Treasurer for the next bout in his incredibly successful campaign against tax avoidance and evasion. I refer to the campaign he announced in his Budget Speech in which he said that he would be introducing measures during the year which would allow for the collection of something like $500m next year out of the cash economy. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) I would like to raise a few matters. I start by mentioning the fact that this Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill ( No. 2) is again a belated effort by this Government. It is a reactive measure against tax avoidance. If one goes back over the government's record, despite the fact that we have repeatedly heard Government members in this House talking about the great record of the Government on tax avoidance, one can see that it is appalling. This legislation is another indication of how long the Government has taken to act on matters which were known a long while ago. The schemes we are talking about, bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, were first detected as far back as 1973. In relation to that I refer to page 27 of the report of Mr Costigan where he said:

SPEECH.PARA: This scheme was first detected in a wide spread manner by the Australian Taxation Office in 1973.

That is a long while earlier than 1978, the year to which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) alluded. In fact, in November 1975 authority was given to launch prosecutions, but that matter was put in the too hard basket by this Government. That is the way the Government has continued to act in this area ever since. According to the Government, nothing could be done until the passage of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of November 1980. That matter also has been canvassed at considerable length in the debates on taxation in this Parliament, particularly in the debates involving the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Again the Government failed to take action to prosecute people who were ripping off the system in a most outrageous way. There was no excuse for this Government not spelling out clearly to people in the community the fact that it was not prepared to tolerate the sort of behaviour which has gone on in the tax avoidance industry over a long period. Numerous opinions were available but I do not propose to go over them again. They have been mentioned so regularly in debates that we are probably all a bit sick of hearing about them. The fact of the matter is that if this Government had taken action, by prosecuting people years ago, we would not be in the hopeless situation in which we are now in relation to tax avoidance.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—I thank the honourable member for Lilley for that interjection because it is right. The argument that from a legal point of view it is difficult to prove conspiracy or fraud is an interesting one. In these circumstances nobody denies that it would be difficult. But I put an example to honourable members: Suppose somebody proposed a scheme, highly organised and sophisticated-it has been going on all the time in the tax avoidance industry-whereby people could rip-off the system at the expense of wage and salary earners of this country. Suppose that the person receiving the scheme discovered a few weeks later that someone had in fact been prosecuted by the Federal Government for conspiracy. I find it very difficult to understand how the Treasurer or anybody else could argue that that would not have had a very great effect on the whole tax avoidance industry. It would not be of particular interest to people to know whether the person was convicted. Is it said that somebody would be prepared to go through a trial on that sort of issue, regardless of whether they were convicted, in view of the expense and the fact that it was a criminal proceeding ? Such a prosecution would have knocked the scheme on the head.

SPEECH.PARA: But this Government did not have the will to do that. Despite the opinions that were available the Government continued to hide behind the view that nothing could be done until legislation was introduced. That legislation was the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of December 1980 which was passed almost two years ago. The claim that existing laws were inadequate is a contradiction of numerous legal opinions which were given prior to that period. But no action was taken by this Government.

It is worth looking at the sorts of people involved in these schemes and the attitudes they adopted. After the Government acted in relation to amending the Income Tax Assessment Act and Part IVA was inserted, a seminar was held in Melbourne on 23 June 1981, at which papers were presented. Those papers indicated the type of mentality of this Government in dealing with tax evasion and its total failure to understand the matter-it is probably more correct to say that it did not want to understand it-is demonstrated by looking at some of the papers given at that seminar. I would like to refer to one in particular. It was a paper given by Mr Neil Forsyth, a Melbourne Q.C. At that seminar referring to Part IVA, he said this:

If Part IVA applies, if there is a scheme, etcetera, and the Commissioner has brought it into operation and has assessed some tax by reason of it, then section 226 sub-section (2A) provides that there is an automatic penalty of 200 per cent of the amount of that tax, but of course the Commissioner and the board of review have power to remit all or part of that penalty.
I myself think that the maximum penalty is too high.
I think the Treasurer ought to listen to this because it indicates the sort of mentality with which we are dealing:

It equates artificial but honest arrangements with fraudulent and dishonest steps taken by taxpayers. It blurs the distinction completely between what is clever and tricky on the one hand and what is dishonest and cheating on the other. The distinction is drawn between being clever and tricky on one hand and cheating and dishonest on the other.
Mr Forsyth went on to say:

Not everybody might agree that there should be a distinction but to me there is a distinction between saying ''That is what I've done, I say it works, I think it's clever, it may not be playing fair by the community but that's a different matter' and saying alternatively ''I'm just going to put this money into my pocket''.

In the taxation avoidance industry people have publicly stated that it is okay if one says: 'That is what I have done. It works. I think it is clever. It may not be playing fair by the community and that is a different matter.' That is the mentality that the Government has had to deal with. One must have some sympathy for the Government in that regard. But one cannot have any sympathy for a government dealing with people of that mentality which then takes no action to prosecute people. As I indicated earlier-I think it is worth repeating-the argument that it is difficult to prove that conspiracy or fraud has been committed is accepted. But the fact of the matter is that if the Government had sent some people for the big jump it would have certainly slowed them down. However the Government did absolutely nothing. In November 1980 it trumpeted the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill as if it were the greatest invention that had come into being in relation to tax avoidance, but still there were no prosecutions. We are told that it has all stopped. Eminent authorities have been quoted by representatives of some firms, such as members of Coopers and Lybrand. At Question Time one day the Treasurer announced that a member of Coopers and Lybrand had said that taxation avoidance in this country was dead. No prosecutions were launched after the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill was passed and none before. The mentality of people whom we were dealing with and whom this Government was dealing with is as I have indicated. If people thought that something was clever they did not care whether or not it was fair by the rest of the community. As long as they got away with it that was okay. This Government sat back and watched it happen. We have now got to the stage where, if it had not been for the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, this legislation would not be before this Parliament today. Again nothing would have happened. The Government is totally reactive all the time. No positive action has been taken by this Government unless it has been of a reactive nature.

In March 1980 the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) and I drew to the attention of the Parliament a scheme operating in the assignment of debts in Melbourne. It was an enormous rip-off of the tax system. Nothing was done about that until the matter came into this place and then some action was taken. It will be interesting to see how much action was taken. That is a matter we have not put away as something we do not intend to continue to explore. However it is again an indication of the way in which this Government reacts. The tax avoidance industry just goes along. The Government yaps at its heels like a dog and the tax avoidance industry it just kicks it away until something else crops up and then the Government puts its finger in the hole to see whether it can stop the flood.

It was interesting and delightful to hear that the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) supports the Bill but there seemed to be a certain amount of apology in his speech in that he kept talking about the fact that this Bill will recoup company tax already avoided. Therefore there was an apologetic nature about what he had to say in respect to retrospectivity. We ought to make it quite clear that we on this side of the House do not make any apology with respect to retrospectivity of legislation where it is directed at artificially contrived taxation avoidance schemes with no commercial value whatsoever. I think it is about time that people faced up to that issue. There is no need to be apologetic about it. I draw to the attention of the House a decision in the Victorian Supreme Court as far back as 1960 in the case of Doro and the Victorian Railways Commissioners by Mr Justice Adam, a very highly respected member of that court. The reference is 1960 Victorian Law Reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, your honour.

—The Treasurer interjects: 'Thank you, your honour'. Of course that is a classic example of his somewhat inane attitude at times on these matters. He indicated here one day in reply to a question that I seemed to take everything that Frank Costigan said as being some sort of holy writ. That is something that I am pleased I have the opportunity to clarify. I do not think what Frank Costigan says necessarily takes on such a high standing. But what I am saying is that what he said in his report confirmed opinions of Queen's Counsel and other senior barristers in this country over many years. The Treasurer has never come into this House and put an opinion which contradicts those opinions and said that they were wrong. Until he does he should take some notice of opinions given by people over the years, people such as Frank Costigan and numerous others before him. Even in my 20 minutes I do not have time to go through them but there are plenty of speeches in which they have been listed and it would not be a bad idea if the Treasurer read them. In that decision Justice Adam stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The strength of the presumption against retrospectivity in any particular case, and accordingly the ease or difficulty with which it may be overcome, must, I would think, depend on the nature and degree of the injustice which would result from giving the statute a retrospective operation.
He later said:

On the other hand, where to give retrospective operation to a statute might be considered to work some injustice to one party, but is clearly required to rectify a manifest injustice to others, there would, on principle, seem little reason for giving much weight to the presumption.

That is a classic case with respect to retrospectivity, and I am pleased to see that the Treasurer agrees with that. The manifest injustice that comes about because of what these people have done to the detriment of the rest of the community clearly justifies retrospectivity in this type of case. What are we dealing with? We are dealing with tax avoidance which has become big business. Schemes were devised and commercially marketed by specialist companies whose principal or only activity consisted in the sale and operations of such schemes. That is all they did. It was a growth industry under this Government. They were only commercially marketing and operating tax avoidance schemes. In return taxpayers incurred a fee, usually calculated as a proportion of the tax that it was hoped would be saved and payable at the outset. Schemes tended to be very complicated, required the participation of numerous parties and the circulation of substantial sums of money. That is the sort of operation that we were faced with.

Fortunately, there has been a change in attitude in relation to the whole question of tax avoidance. To a large degree that has come about because of the reconstituted High Court of Australia. Under the present leadership of Chief Justice Sir Harry Gibbs, far from showing an appetite for mobilising the Barwick brand of pedantic literalism, it is now looking at these cases in a far more sensible way. That was demonstrated in the case of Cooper Brookes (Wollongong) Pty Limited v. Federal Commissioner of Taxation. In that case the High Court showed quite clearly that it was prepared to seize upon the House of Lords decision in Ramsay Ltd v. the Inland Revenue Commissioners of 1981. In that case the House of Lords dismissed two appeals involving artificial tax avoidance. The House of Lords in that case quite clearly spelt out that it was not prepared to tolerate any further this totally contrived effort to avoid the contribution that people should make to taxation.

One thing about the Treasurer that has always surprised me is that he has said time and again in this House that there was a change in community attitudes to tax avoidance, as if that was an excuse for not taking any action. It is true that there has been a change of attitude, but to a large degree it has come about because we on this side of the House during this Parliament and the previous Parliament, through spokesmen such as the honourable member for Gellibrand and various other honourable members, have spelt out the situation over and over again. Tonight honourable members opposite will talk about the great record of this Government, so in closing it is worth referring to two sets of statistics of the Commissioner of Taxation. In 1979, 655 individuals were identified in tax avoidance schemes which involved an amount of $317m. The number of companies involved was 1,603 and the amount involved was $107m. By 1981 the individuals numbered 17,957, involving $620m and companies-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many honourable members want to speak in the second reading debate on these taxation Bills. Therefore, I propose to confine my remarks to a few points. Certainly in my electorate and in many parts of this country my attitude to this legislation is well known. I have always made it clear that as a member of the Liberal Party, as a person who believes in the rule of law and in the things for which our forefathers fought, I do not see retrospective legislation of this nature as being in the long term interests of Australia. Nevertheless, I want to make one or two other points. I am acutely aware of the concern in the Australian community about the tax evasion industry and also about the more artificial forms of tax avoidance. I am also very much aware that almost every Australian tries, legitimately and properly, to minimise his tax in the normal course of events-'minimise' meaning to avoid paying unnecessary tax. I am aware of that concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware that, largely due to public efforts by people such as the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and me telling people that under the present arrangements there is an unfair shifting of the tax burden from certain groups to other groups, there is now an awareness in the community that that shifting of the tax burden by artificial schemes of tax evasion is downright unfair. As I said, we have been saying that for a long time. We are saying that, of course, not only in the context of the more illegal or unfair practices such as artificial schemes, but also in the overall context of determining who ought to pay tax; in what form it should be paid; whether there ought to be more indirect taxes or less; whether we ought to be double taxing dividends, as people tell us we do; whether we ought to be raising a lot of tax through Customs and excise; and whether we should have regressive forms of tax spending, such as the raising of money from people in the western suburbs of Sydney to subsidise people on the North Shore to go to the opera. There are many things in the tax system with which many people would disagree.

If I had the time this evening I would launch into some ideas about how we could genuinely reform the tax system so that, for a start, there would be less possibility of evasion and less possibility of artificial tax schemes and, in addition, there could be a more efficient taxation system that could add positively to our potential as a country. It also needs to be said with regard to community concern, that individuals often speak with two hats, depending on the aspect of taxation to which they address themselves. I have no doubt that many of the people who have quite openly said that we ought to legislate retrospectively to catch the people who have been called knaves and thieves must have aided and abetted at some time in their lives an evasion through the cash economy. For instance, any person who pays cash for a job which somebody does in his house and any person who shops in a market where no receipts are given probably have a fair idea that a percentage of that payment might be going to somebody who withholds knowledge of that transaction from the Commissioner of Taxation or does not declare all of the transactions at the end of the financial year. It is well documented, certainly overseas, that the cash economy is a major economy. It is the one in which most tax is evaded. The so-called bottom- of-the-harbour schemes are particularly nasty, but all in all in a single year more tax would be evaded through the cash economy in Australia than was probably ever evaded in the so-called bottom-of-the-harbour schemes since they have sprung up. I am told they started to spring up at the end of the 1960s.

I also register the fact that members of the Australian Labor Party, who very self-righteously today have said that they will do all sorts of things about getting money from people who in all fairness ought to have paid it, when given the opportunity did nothing about it. During their period of power between 1972 and 1975, to my knowledge, they did nothing. During this period officers working in the Australian Taxation Office-on the evidence that we have heard recently- began to find out about some schemes. This was the period when there was a famous court case relating to the Curran scheme. I reiterate that members of the Labor Party did nothing. They seem absolutely ridiculous when, instead of supporting the present Government, which has done a lot, they criticise it. They ought to look at their motives and wonder why they could not do anything during that period.

I want to address myself for a minute or two to the problems I see in starting off a retrospective tax campaign. Even if the present Government sticks to what it has been saying-that is, that this is an absolutely special case-it is possible to assume from what the Labor Party has had to say already in this debate that, should it gain power in Australia again, it will re-examine all the tax rules. Perhaps on its definitions of fairness it will pick out those areas in which it believes the legislators have legislated unfairly previously and will change those laws back to what they were. If it does so, it will be saying that the Government ought to be able to override the rule of law and that the right of the individual people to act with certainty within the law ought to be thrown out of the window in favour of a government which rides roughshod over people's rights. I remind the House that not many hundreds of years ago our forefathers had to fight the king. It can be said that in our present system, we are the king, but then the ordinary people had to fight the sovereign king to get very simple rules of law established in Britain. It was a matter of great historic moment when our forefathers stood up against the king and said: 'You cannot ride roughshod over our basic right. There ought to be rules that are certain'. It was from that that our Westminster democratic system sprang. It has proved to be the best system of rule ever invented. Certainly, it is the most lasting and the most democratic.

All I am saying is that this legislation introduces a great fear in my mind. There is a great fear in the minds of many of the people in the community who support it that if this method is used again and again they will not know where they stand and the police state, the state where governments can come back and change the rules, will have come into this country. That is the attitude of the Australian Labor Party. It sees government as being above the law. It sees many tax schemes it would want to attack in the future. I have just heard the term: ' We ought to get at all schemes that have no commercial value'. What does that mean? Does that mean that an ordinary trust arrangement has no commercial value? Does it mean that an ordinary private company arrangement has no commercial value? Does it mean that an ordinary partnership arrangement has no commercial value? I just do not know what it means, but no doubt if Labor should ever get back into power the ordinary people of Australia will find out well and truly what it means. I simply say that the tax which was owing ought to have been collected under the law. No doubt other speakers will talk about that.

I should say in conclusion that this legislation as it is presented, in the sense that it expresses the aim of the Government, which in turn expresses the concern of the community, is better legislation than it was a week or so ago. There have been some changes, but still some other changes are required, and one of those changes is absolutely required. If vendor shareholders in all fairness sold their shares without reasonably knowing that the company was to be used for one of these terrible, so-called bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, at least those people ought to be protected under the law. I hope to raise that matter later. I hope that I can get widespread support for that basic principle of Australian justice. I recognise the problem facing the public. We have a perception amongst the public that those who might vote against this legislation are simply the friends of the tax dodgers. Nothing could be further from the truth. As far as my record goes, I point out that the first time the issue of tax evasion was debated in this House-I emphasise, debated in this House-it was raised by me as a matter of public importance. It was not raised by the Labor Party, and that ought to go on the record. I will not say any more about this legislation at the moment, except that it is bad legislation brought forward to fill a perceived need by the public. No doubt the public ought to be pleased with what it is getting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I found incredible some of the comments that were made by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury). The honourable member for Macarthur suggested that the Government and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) could take credit for the approach they have adopted in relation to taxation avoidance and evasion . Let me just refer to some headlines in connection with the Government's approach to this question.
