First of all, the Australian Financial Review on Monday, 28 June 1982 bears the headlines: 'Multi-Million Dollar Losses to Tax Evaders' and 'More Names Promised but No Money'. The front page of the Sydney Morning Herald on 23 September this year bore the headline: 'Government Inaction on Tax Lurks Dates to 1977'. On the front page of the Australian Financial Review are the headlines: 'Extraordinary Government History of Inaction' and ' Tax Evasion-New Disclosures'. We have as well a reference to the companies of Mr Denis Horgan, a leading Liberal in Western Australia and former Chairman of the Western Australian Liberal Party Finance Committee. The headline states: 'How Horgan Company Avoided $7m in 5 Years'. We have from the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Malcolm Fraser) a request to the same Mr Denis Horgan-who has been appointed to all of these government authorities at an income of something like $30,000 a year; this tax dodger, this crook-please do stand down. It is no good the Treasurer shaking his head when I use the word 'crook', when newspapers in Australia are referring to the fact that this same character's companies avoided $7m in five years. It is no good, either, for the honourable member for Eden- Monaro to come in here with all of his offended virtue and offended morality and suggest that retrospective legislation is not appropriate. The position in Australia at present is that through tax evasion and avoidance the Treasury, the Commonwealth Government, and all of the taxpayers in Australia who meet their responsibilities are being ripped off to the extent of probably $7,000m every year. Of course those figures cannot be refuted. They have been supplied by much more eminent authorities than I would ever claim to be. What does that represent ?
—Who?

—Russell Mathews for a start, first of all in connection with tax avoidance and now in connection with tax evasion; the research department of the Commercial Bank of Australia, and the research department of the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Treasurer should not ask me who is responsible for these assertions. Whenever I say anything in this House I will be able to support it. When the honourable member for Eden-Monaro and anyone else on the Government side cross the floor and vote against this legislation-that is apparently honourable members' intention-I hope that all of the households in their electorates become aware of the fact that because of all these smart tax dodging lurkmen and crooks around the place every household in Australia is paying to compensate for that at least $30 extra tax a week, and every pay-as-you-earn taxpayer is paying an extra $25 a week to make up for all the tax dodgers, all the tax avoiders and all the tax evaders.

SPEECH.PARA: The smell of death about this Government has become a sickening, oozing stench. Nothing better illustrates that than the background to this piece of legislation . It involves incompetence and procrastination by the Government in relation to these matters, and of course the obvious and definite measures that have been taken by it in order to protect wealthy crooks, especially if those wealthy crooks belong to the Liberal Party. We have people such as Brian Maher. The national community has seen this 'gentleman'-I ask Hansard to show that word in inverted commas-portrayed on television driving around in his Rolls-Royce, with all his luxury cars in his garage, and living in retirement in a magnificent mansion on the Gold Coast, sailing around the waterways of the Gold Coast in his yacht, and going to see his bloodstock, his line of racehorses. I hope that when the people of Australia saw that wealth on television they understood who provided it for Mr Brian Maher. They did.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pensioners who didn't get their rise one year.

—Including the pensioners; anyone in Australia paying taxes-the taxpayer who paid the extra $25 a week, the householder who pays the extra $30 a week to keep people like Brian Maher and all the rest of the rip-off merchants in their opulence and affluence.
—He should have been caught up with years ago.

—Exactly. Let the Australian people be perfectly aware of that. We have all this nonsense from people such as the honourable member for Macarthur and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro. Let them cross the floor and let their names be recorded! McCabe-Lafranchi indicated 923 companies that had been involved in these bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The Australian Taxation Office has indicated possibly 6,200 companies that have been involved. The New South Wales Government has indicated that in New South Wales alone the number is probably something like 4,000, and so it has been going on. We know it has been going on since the early 1970s. The Treasurer himself admitted that the Government knew about it as early as 1978. Every conceivable excuse has been sought and advanced by the Treasurer and the Government for their personal and general procrastination. The most incredible claim made by the Treasurer was that action could not have been taken earlier because the community was not sufficiently aware, the level of public concern was not sufficiently high. For that reason the Government procrastinated. I say to the Treasurer, through you, Mr Deputy Speaker: That is an incredible statement to make. We surely should be allowed to expect more from the Government and responsible Ministers in the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the very serious deficiencies in this legislation is that no provision is made for the recovery of tax from unpaid dividends. I know that the Government has used as an excuse for this legislation and for the reversal in its attitude towards retrospective legislation the fact that this legislation is designed to recoup tax which was not paid under various types of evasion practices. The point is that if this assertion by the Government and the Treasurer is in fact correct, if this legislation is designed to recoup tax which was not paid as a result of evasion practices, of course the legislation is not necessary because tax evasion is illegal. If it was illegal when these practices were undertaken it is quite obvious that there were laws in existence at that time which could have been and should have been applied adequately to deal with them. The Government is introducing retrospective legislation in order to recover tax which was lost under various types of avoidance practices. So the practices at that stage must have been legal.

I am delighted-the Opposition and the Australian community are delighted-at this change of attitude on the part of the Government. Let us not hear this nonsense from the Government that it has not reversed the position which it previously adopted. Of course it has. It is legislating retrospectively to collect retrospective taxes. The type of scheme which is not being legislated against, as I said, relates to unpaid dividends. They are the dry Slutzkins. Sir Garfield Barwick, when he was Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, presiding over the original Slutzkin case indicated that that type of practice was legal. What a legacy Sir Garfield Barwick has left to this nation! What a legacy that incredible man-that shameful person-has left to this nation!

TALK.START.PARA: — Order!
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member should be directed to withdraw that statement. It is a most grave reflection on a former Chief Justice of this country.
—Order! The honourable member may resume his seat. The Chair was in the process of requiring the honourable member to refrain from making remarks of that nature.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Whilst I do not agree with the remarks, the Standing Orders provide for certain positions to be protected by the Chair. In respect of a position I formerly held, the Chair ruled that former office holders are not covered by that Standing Order and that therefore withdrawals cannot be required.

—The honourable member for Corio is quite correct. He will note that the request from the Chair to the honour- able member for Hunter was that he refrain from making the remarks. He was not required to withdraw, nor was he prevented from making the remarks, but he is requested, in the interests of the dignity of the Parliament, to refrain from making remarks of that nature.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, on the same point of order, is it competent upon a member of the House, under the present Standing Orders, to describe somebody as a crook when in fact that person has not been convicted of any criminal offence?
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Of course there is no point of order, and the Treasurer knew it. If the Treasurer is talking about whether any action has been taken against Horgan, I might ask the Treasurer how many prosecutions have been launched anyway. We know the answer: No prosecutions. We know the performance of the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth. We remember too the Treasurer referring to the fact that he was disappointed that he had not been informed by the Crown Solicitor's Office and by the Commissioner of Taxation about some of these things that had been going on. But the evidence tabled in this place just recently indicated that since 1978, at the very latest , it was well and truly known. It is now 1982. Rather belatedly, as a result of justified anguish on the part of the Australian people about just what direction was being taken, the Government is being forced into a position in which some type of action has to be taken.

SPEECH.PARA: I was referring to what the Chief Justice-that shameful man, Barwick-said in connection with the original dry Slutzkin case. He said:

. . . the choice of the form of transaction by which a taxpayer obtains a benefit of his assets is a matter for him; he is quite entitled to choose that form of transaction which will not be subject to tax, or subject him only to less tax than some other form of transaction might do.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an old devil!

—A devil! There are any number of reasons for us to be concerned about the role of that 'gentleman'. The Prime Minister, on earlier occasions, and particularly in his electorate talk on 31 May 1981, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that there is no real difference between the person who finds an artificial loophole to slip out of tax--
That is like the dry Slutzkin scheme, the one against which no action has been taken under this retrospective legislation-
and the person who falsely declares his income.

They are the tax evaders. They are the people who offend against the law and who are guilty of illegal acts. Of course, in connection with that I suppose we could include the wet Slutzkin. Why did the Prime Minister change his attitude from May 1981 until more recently when he has been defending the dry Slutzkins? It is because one of his mates, John Reid, has been into dry Slutzkins up to his neck. Everyone knows that the only reason John Reid disposed of those companies to the Brian Maher group was that they were then going to engage in dividend stripping operations. There should have been provision in this legislation to deal with those.

In 1975 the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth was supposed to take action under the Crimes Act against the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Of course, the claim now is that legislation existed. No action was taken. David Solomon, in an Australian Financial Review article of 18 October 1982, said:
Tax avoidance as an industry is a comparatively recent phenomenon . . .

Of course it is a recent phenomenon. It has mushroomed only since 1975, under this Government. The figures prove it. The annual reports of the Commissioner of Taxation indicate the extent to which it has blossomed under this Government. David Solomon went on to say:
. . . and it was able to blossom because of the destruction of Section 260 of the Act by the Barwick court.

That same 'gentleman' is one of the knights of the realm. Would we expect anything other than that from one of the knights of the realm whose names have been mentioned in connection with these provisions? The same article by David Solomon led off in this way:

The Barwick High Court during the seventies effectively put a time-bomb under both the Australian taxation system and the Liberal Party. That bomb has exploded, leaving the tax system in a shambles, and the Liberal Party nearer to splitting than it has ever been in its history.

The only member of the High Court during the period of Sir Garfield Barwick's chief justiceship who showed any concern or guts in connection with these shysters was Justice Lionel Murphy who argued for a purposive interpretation of the Income Tax Assessment Act instead of a literal interpretation. In conclusion , I will read into the record part of a minority judgment by Mr Justice Murphy. In connection with the Westraders case he said:

In my opinion, strictly literal interpretation of a tax Act is an open invitation to artificial and contrived tax avoidance. Progress towards a free society will not be advanced by attributing to Parliament meanings which no one believes it intended so that income tax becomes optional for the rich while remaining compulsory for most income earners.
Justice Murphy continued:

If strict literalism continues to prevail, the Legislature may have no practical alternative but to vest tax officials with more and more discretion. This may well lead to tax laws capable, if unchecked, of great oppression.

That is the position in which we increasingly find ourselves. I have mentioned before the possibility that the whole of the taxation system could collapse. All of the changes that have been introduced increasingly are showing themselves as being incapable of achieving what the Australian people are increasingly demanding not only from the Parliament generally but also particularly from this Government. We give this assurance: That whenever the election is between now and the end of next year, when there is a change of government, for the first time an honest, courageous, successful and determined attitude will be taken towards the whole question of tax evasion and avoidance. We will not allow ordinary wage and salary earners in Australia to continue to be ripped off in the future as they have been in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2], the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax-Vendors) Bill, the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax-Promoters) Bill, the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) ( Consequential Amendments) Bill and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment ( Additional Tax) Bill. I say that after having given a great deal of thought to the legislation, as I know that so many members on the Government side have done . I record my appreciation to those who have led the concern that has been expressed about the legislation since the beginning of this Budget session. That concern has caused the Government to continue to re-examine the provisions of the legislation, not only in the preliminary drafting stage but also since the legislation was originally introduced into the House and since its reintroduction after its withdrawal. I believe that the reconsideration has resulted in much better legislation which will do what it seeks to do, to recoup unpaid company tax from those who benefited from a totally artificial and illegal scheme designed to evade that company tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret that I will not be able to support the amendment which will be moved by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury). I have considered it closely but in conscience cannot support it. This gives me cause for concern because I have a great respect for the honourable member for Eden-Monaro and for many of those who will support his amendment. My early reaction was that if I am in disagreement with my valued colleagues, my reasoning is probably faulty. That is why I have looked closely at the amendment to see whether I could support it. My difficulty is that I believe it is the duty of the Government to ensure that the taxation in question is paid. Very few argue about that now. What is sought to be recovered by the legislation is the benefit, the unpaid tax, that the vendor-shareholder received by way of premium on the sale of shares in a company which was bottomed, nothing else. The vendor-shareholder has been effectively holding the tax, albeit in the guise of a premium. This legislation will require him to pay it, to hand it over. He does not lose something that was rightfully his, even if he thought it was. He will not be poorer in terms of what his position may have been before he sold his shares. He will lose a windfall that came to him as a result of the way in which he sold the shares. In this context there is no question of fairness; there is no question of innocence or guilt. There is simply the recovery from vendor-shareholders of money which they received from promoters in a way that was fraudulent on the promoter's part. In a sense the promoter did not give the vendor-shareholders good title to the money. Because the tax is illegally evaded it must be recovered even though it is in the hands of people who may not have acted fraudulently or illegally.

I regret the necessity for this legislation but I acknowledge that it has been made necessary only by the devious schemings of promoters who are prepared to go to any lengths to create artificial devices that will enable people to evade their legitimate taxation obligations. Such actions must be countered with legislation of this kind. In a sense the Government must fight fire with fire to protect the common good. A year or two ago we passed interpretation legislation in this Parliament which was designed to guide the courts towards giving consideration to the clear intent of legislation when it went through the Parliament rather than the strict letter of the legislation. That legislation should significantly reduce loophole arguments and decisions. Clear sidestepping in an illegal way of the intent of the law by the promoters led to the bottom-of -the-harbour concept and led in turn to this legislation. This legislation will restore the intent of the law. I regret that it has been necessary to deny the benefit to which vendor shareholders thought they were entitled, but the action of the promoters has left the Government with no choice.

I am very pleased to be able to acknowledge that these practices have been stopped. The legislation that was introduced by the Government at the end of 1980 has ensured that no more activity of this kind is being undertaken by promoters and that companies are not being handled in the way they were. The problem which has been left for the Government to deal with is the problem of outstanding assessments and the recovery of tax that was assessed and was legally payable by companies which promoters sent to the bottom of the harbour. Essentially, the arguments about this legislation reduce to arguments which deal with the conflict between two principles. In the final analysis, we have to determine whether retrospectivity is a better principle than fairness and equity or whether the reverse is the case. My examination of the issue has led me to come down in favour of the principle of fairness and equity as opposed to the arguments that have been advanced about retrospectivity and other arguments which have been put forward.

There is no doubt about the power of this Parliament to legislate in matters concerning taxation. Equally, there is no doubt about the powers that this Parliament has to pass retrospective legislation. In Kidman's case the High Court of Australia held that it was within the legislative competence of the Commonwealth Parliament to make provisions of the Crimes Act retrospective. That judgment has been used in other areas to enable the Parliament to legislate in a retrospective fashion. There is no doubt whatsoever that the Parliament has the power. What is interesting about this legislation and the debate which has been taking place is that there is no retrospectivity concerning the taxation liability or obligations of people who are concerned. Tax assessment and liability provisions remain exactly the same as they were. What this legislation will do in a retrospective way is remove the protection of limited liability from shareholders in proprietary companies and, as a result of having done that, make them liable only for the taxation which those companies had a responsibility to pay and which was not paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —And from which they benefited.

—And from which they benefited. Only in this single instance are they liable. We are doing what we are only because we have been forced to do it by the schemings of the promoters and the illegal and blatantly artificial actions that were entered into.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not have a great deal of sympathy for shareholders who were involved. I think the magic trick argument that ignorance would be a valid excuse in later challenges does not really hold as much water as they believed it might. Most of the people who were involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes as so-called innocent shareholders had to remove from their company structure all the assets, liabilities, plant, shareholders' funds and all that sort of thing. They had to leave the company with nothing other than the current year's profits and the liability for the tax that was supposed to be paid on those profits. In most cases the promoters requested that the money being left in the companies be left there simply in the form of a bank cheque.

I believe that anybody who was involved in a scheme that involved that amount of complexity, conniving and contriving, must have realised that there was a little more to it than simply a bit of legal tax avoidance. There is no doubt in my mind about people's expectations when they were told further by the promoter that they would get not only what the company was worth after the taxation liability had been taken away from the accumulated profit, but also a significant premium. It was not just the sort of premium that a promoter might have paid if he was going to put the company through some legal tax avoidance scheme or offset the profits against some losses that had been bought fairly cheaply somewhere else. I do not believe that the sort of premium that was being offered, and actually being accepted by shareholders in companies that were going to these promoters, was a reasonable expectation. People who accepted from promoters a premium equivalent to 80 per cent or 90 per cent of the tax that would otherwise have been payable, in all fairness, really deserve to have their credentials checked if they are going to argue that they are innocent, that there is no liability on them or that this legislation will treat them unfairly. Had it been a normal commercial transaction, those people would not have expected anything like the sort of premium that the promoters were paying for those profits. If the people concerned had no knowledge that the taxation that was due and payable by their company was not going to be paid and, for the most part, was going to be redirected to them in the form of a premium on the shares that they were selling, then they were ignorant or stupid, or both.

An argument has been put to us about the fairness. I think the fairness argument is a compelling one. Before I deal with that matter I just want to say that a few other arguments have been raised about retrospectivity. Firstly, it has been said that it creates a precedent that will enable the Australian Labor Party, should it ever achieve government, to legislate retrospectively. That has been of grave concern to this Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —We will.

—I acknowledge that the honourable member for Hunter says that the Labor Party will do this. That has been a matter of grave concern to this Government. We do not wish in any way to set precedents for Labor governments to take advantage of. The Australian Labor Party is not concerned about that and it will legislate retrospectively. We are acting in the way we are, only because these matters have been forced upon us. From the point of view of those people who were involved in schemes I think the only question to be asked is whether they will pay their taxation under this Government or at some later date under a Labor government, should there ever be one. The ground of precedent is not really an argument against retrospectivity. The Labor Party has made it perfectly clear that it will legislate retrospectively whether or not we have given it a precedent for doing it. That needs to be understood. A lot of waffle has been talked by people on my side of politics who believe that that is a valid argument. It is not.

SPEECH.PARA: Equally, a lot of waffle has been talked about certainty. I do not accuse the people who use that argument of being in any way ungenerous or wrong. But the fact is that they do not understand what it is about. If they looked at the situation closely they would see it as it is. Certainty about taxation remains. The Australian Labor Party is the party that offers uncertainty. It has a commitment to legislate retrospectively in terms of tax. We are only transferring the liability to pay the tax. What is important in this issue is that the liability to pay the tax is being transferred from the company which has been rendered unable to pay the tax to the people who have gained the benefit.

Fairness is important. Millions of taxpayers pay their tax week by week and month by month through the pay-as-you-earn system. They have no alternative but to do that. They do not have available to them options that may be open to other people in the community, whether they are among the smarties in the top income bracket or among those operating in the cash economy. The pay-as-you-earn taxpayers are paying their tax. This Government has a responsibility to those people to make sure that they do not carry any more of the burden than they ought to be carrying. Whether it is through the recovery of this tax which has been assessed but not paid, or whether it is through an attack on the injustices of the cash economy, this Government has a responsibility to the honest, genuine , fair dinkum taxpayers in Australia to recover tax and to ensure that people make their contribution.

If we do not accept that argument about fairness we are doing two things. Firstly, we are not only allowing those people who received a benefit to keep a benefit which really should be a benefit to the taxpaying community of Australia and to Australians as a whole, but also allowing those vendors who contrived and schemed to rip off the community to get away with it. That is one thing which I cannot tolerate. Whatever else I might be prepared to argue, discuss and be reasonable about, I am not prepared to be reasonable about those promoters. Promoters have engaged in the most scurrilous activity. They have gone against everything regarded as proper in the administration of taxation.

As I understand it, although I do not necessarily agree with it, people are entitled to try to organise or arrange their affairs in such a way as to reduce their liability to pay tax. But that is not involved in this situation. What is involved in this scheme is an arrangement whereby people act totally illegally. They go out and they find men of straw-aged pensioners or people on their death beds in nursing homes-and give them $100 or a bottle of scotch and say: 'Sign this document'. As a result of having signed that document-although to them it would not make any difference-they become the owners of a company for which there are no documents and for which there is a taxation liability. I am not prepared to be a part of a government or a party that accepts that as fair and proper.

We have taken action in this legislation to recover the funds from those who have benefited. We have also dealt with the promoters through the Special Prosecutors legislation. I would say that such action is welcomed by 99.9999 per cent of Australians. I include in that the people who probably got involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes at the behest of promoters. They probably wish they had never done it now. They would like to see the promoters skinned also. There are not harsh enough words for those promoters. They have skinned hundreds of millions of dollars off the taxation pool that should be available for the general services of the Government in this country so that the Government does not have to take quite so much money off the taxpayers who pay their proper tax. I feel very strongly about that matter. I am very pleased that the Government has acted in the way it has.

I also want to say very briefly that those people who are hiding behind the argument about the decisions which were taken by the High Court of Australia in Slutzkin's case in my view do not have an argument. That was a decision which dealt with the fact that if one did not know, then the procedure was going to be all right. In the bottom-of-the-harbour scheme, the principle has been transferred to a totally different scheme. I believe that although the principle may be okay, there is no argument for saying that the scheme is one which has been approved by the High Court. A lot of the argument has been centred around that point.

I support the legislation. I have enormous respect for those who have carried the argument to the Government to ensure that the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2] is in the form that it now is. I believe it is a far better Bill. As I said earlier, I regret that I cannot agree with the honourable member for Eden-Monaro and so many of our colleagues who will be supporting an amendment to the legislation. In my view and in the view of the National Party as a whole, we strongly want to support this legislation. We believe that it is in the national interest and that it must be passed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 5.58 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2] and the associated Bills, and particularly the amendment moved so ably by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). This Government's policies in areas of taxation and corporate law can best be summed up with the simple dictum: 'Incentives for the rich to get richer are good, especially if embedded in the tax system. Welfare for the poor to get less poor is bad'. It is worse if they actually do; that destroys character. This nation has witnessed an extraordinary saga of ineptitude and inequity in our taxation system. Every week the media reveals more examples of tax avoidance and evasion. Despite utterances from honourable members opposite, the saga is not over yet. By and large, the culprits are those who can afford the advice that allows them to evade or avoid perhaps all of their tax. One witnesses the sad spectacle of two of our leading professional groups-lawyers and accountants-being dragged into tax schemes that everybody knows are blatant, artificial and contrived.

SPEECH.PARA: At whose expense do the better off sectors of our society score because of the exploitation of the appalling gaps in our law? Only now are Australians, perhaps feeling the economic pinch as never before, getting a glimmer of the depth of corruption and amorality reached by some of the wealthier members of society. Wage and salary earners and small businessmen and women pay their income tax to provide the social benefits that revenue pays for. For years their income tax load has escalated. They may have raised families, built homes and businesses, run farms, yet still they have paid their allotted tax. Now they discover that many companies and wealthy members of society do not contribute any tax at all in many cases. To these people tax has become optional. Persistent is the carping phrase that very little of what has been done over the years was actually illegal. Some sections of our professional people argue that they should not make moral judgments about what they or their clients do, that they should be able to turn a blind eye. How many groups in history have used that sort of reasoning to try to escape moral blame?

Some honourable members opposite try to excuse the actions of avoiders and their advisers. They claim that, because when vendors sell companies the companies owe no tax at that time, the vendors are blameless. They cannot plead ignorance of corporate accounting practice. Is it that they cannot differentiate between the wet and dry Slutzkins? Let us take the dry Slutzkin. It occurs where companies are stripped of accumulated profits after primary company tax has been paid. In receiving the proceeds of sale in the form of capital what was avoided was the secondary tax that would have been payable by the shareholders if the accumulated profits had been distributed by way of dividends. The disposal of a company in this manner was held to be effective by the High Court of Australia, and such cases are not covered by the legislation. Yet anyone knows that the vendors either knew or ought to have known that the tax was being avoided and that they were profiting by such avoidance. In contrast, cases popularly known as wet Slutzkins involve the stripping of profits before the primary tax liability has been net. After the profits have been stripped the company records are disposed of. In these cases there is a clear and undisputed liability for payment of tax on untaxed profits of the company at the time of the strip. The liability still exists but cannot be collected as the companies have been stripped of their assets and dumped.

The legislation seeks to recover tax from vendor-shareholders on the basis that , considered in the light of the amount received for their shares, they should have been aware that the tax would not be paid by the company. They ought to have known that most people sold their companies just before the end of the financial year deliberately to avoid paying company or other taxes. Certainly many of the companies did not actually owe taxes at the time of the sale, but everyone knew, especially the vendor shareholders, that liability for the current year was soon to be assessed and that, morally or in equity, the company did owe taxes when it was sold. Of course the vendors knew that they were avoiding taxes. Did they think they got high prices for their shares simply because they had struck a good bargain or because the purchasers were stupid? Were the vendors so ignorant of tax and commercial matters that they did not know these things? Of course not. It is utter nonsense to claim otherwise.

The wet Slutzkins are morally worse than the dry Slutzkins but they are both avoidance tactics. Both are shonky and contrived. No one is fooled by the blustering and humbug of interested pressure groups. Their attention is better directed to making sure that this tax fiasco never happens again. I do not intend to talk about the part that the High Court has played in this fiasco. One can say this though: The members of the Court have endorsed the decisions in cases such as Europa Oil No. 2, Cridland, Curran, Slutzkin, Isherwood and Dreyfus, Westraders and Commonwealth Aluminium and they have much to answer for. They should have known what their reasoning would lead to. They should have known better than to encourage artifical schemes of tax avoidance. No other court in the common law world would have entertained for so long this sort of nonsense and artificially that our top court did. One can hope only that recent cases show a permanent change in the High Court's attitude.

This legislature for years has made its intentions plain enough. Judicial sabotage has gone on for far too long. It is time our leading professionals showed some leadership. Society expects them to act as professionals and not as greedy amateurs. The efforts of the Ethics Committee of the Victorian Bar and the Australian Society of Accountants to do something about it are long overdue. The Accountants Society proposes to introduce regulations to prohibit members from engaging in or promoting artificial tax practices and charging fees based on the amount of tax avoided. That sort of action is at least a step in the right direction. One hopes that it will go further. How much more should we know and will perhaps never know because the witchcraft of accounting and legal jargon deprives society of the information? The battle is only starting. Our common aim ought to be to make sure that the tax system is fair and enforceable. We owe a debt of gratitude to McCabe and Lafranchi and the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union for their honesty, integrity and leadership.

Let me turn to another culprit in all of this. Nobody has touched on this yet, and I want to devote my remaining time to it. Australian company law provides relatively little protection to small shareholders or small trade creditors. Similarly, the administrative and judicial machinery for enforcing such laws is complex, cumbersome and unsuitable to the effective combating of corporate malpractice and crime. Regrettably, the existing so-called national company laws provide a breeding ground for the spiv, the charlatan and the corporate crook. They were eliminated in Europe a decade ago. It is a scandal that the so-called lawmakers of this country perpetuate ineffective law. What the Costigan Royal Commission has done is to underline the link between organised and corporate crime. There is no longer a clear distinction between Mafia-type drug rings populated with foreign names and shyster company behaviour. Costigan revealed how big crime touches diverse sections of the community. Blue collar thuggery is married to white collar crime by seemingly respectable celebrants. That investigation has uncovered serious breaches of integrity and gross incompetence at the very centre of law enforcement and the judicial system.

There are many abuses in relation to company affairs. Nobody can any longer deny that. For example, the sale of many companies through the so-called wet Slutzkin schemes was helped by the easy creation, manipulation and destruction of straw companies. It is a very simple process under present law to establish such a company. All one needs are two shareholders prepared to put forward sufficient capital, namely, $2, sign certain papers which have usually been prepared well in advance and are sitting on the shelf in the office of a shonky accountant or solicitor, pay the registration and stamp duties and presto, one has a limited liability company. In the wet Slutzkin situation, companies were established with false directors or fictitious persons; there was no ability on the part of the corporate affairs commissions to check out the details of the companies. Certainly there was no capital backing.

This practice has been exacerbated by the failure of the Government to close effectively tax avoidance loopholes which have existed for years. The ease with which trusts can be set up using $2 nominee, sometimes straw, companies for the purposes of reducing tax has been brought to the attention of governments time after time. We have failed to provide better protection for prospective shareholders from the offering and transfer of shares by unscrupulous manipulators. Having become shareholders, they are subject to other abuses and mismanagement by the controllers of companies. Under present laws, shareholders have no effective say in the way their money is used and have, in effect, no control over directors. Company meetings are an empty charade. Such provisions as the present law makes for the expression of shareholders' opinions are inadequate and easily by-passed.

These laws cannot be taken seriously when compared with laws being applied throughout most European and Scandinavian countries. I was delighted to see the former Minister in the House yesterday talking about the need to do something about proprietary companies. It is a pity that he did not say that during the debates that took place 18 months ago. If one contrasts the laws with the laws in New Zealand one finds that they are a joke. If one contrasts them with the laws in Europe one finds that they are laughable. In Europe or Scandinavia it is impossible to register and operate a limited liability company with a share paid up capital of $2. Much larger sums have to be lodged and therefore there is a much greater risk by shareholders. In Great Britain a public limited liability company must have an issued paid up share capital of at least 50,000 pounds whereas in Australia such a company can lawfully have an issued share capital of 5c. Because of the larger sums injected into European companies creditors at least have some safeguards. In Australia the absence of a significant minimum share capital requirement for limited liability companies means that there is no disincentive to the use of such companies on a massive scale for tax avoidance or other nefarious purposes. The Government knew that at least 10 years ago. In Australia the winners are the accountants, the lawyers and the sharp operators. The losers are the creditors of the alarming number of such companies that become insolvent every year and the taxpayers at large. Any government which is serious about the fairness and efficacy of a tax system must look further than the tax laws for the reasons for Australia's massive tax evasion and avoidance schemes. The parlous state of our company law is inextricably linked with the tax problem, and the Government has failed to grapple with it.

A minimum share paid up capital requirement would not be an answer in itself. It would have to be supported with shares issued for non-cash considerations, transactions between companies and their directors or shareholders, discount share issues, and the payment of dividends. Here again reform is needed to protect both the creditor and the public. If the business community knew enough about reforms it would recognise their merit and at least support them. Instead, in deliberate ignorance we leave unchanged our very imperfect system to the detriment of our business community, investors, shareholders and the public. Our blindness to the abuses of corporate law and our unintelligent approach to even the most cautious reform have branded Australia as the dunce of corporate law. This is not a matter for party politics or vested interest groups. The issues are too important for that. Our company law is riddled with deficiencies. These can be remedied only by a federal companies Act and not the charade of national legislation we have today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to Mr Walker.

—Yes, I would say it to Mr Walker. Thus, for example, what Queensland wants Australia gets. It is a national tragedy that we have the lowest common denominator approach to corporate law. We have company laws with no single government bearing political responsibility for them. In future changes to the laws may be made by a mere majority vote of the Ministerial Council. But it is still likely to be a case of too many cooks spoiling the broth. Solutions will continue to be compromise solutions. The result-company law broth-will be both weak and insipid.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two current difficulties with law enforcement. The first concerns the ability of the National Companies and Securities Commission and the State corporate affairs commissions promptly to investigate breaches and, where warranted, launch prosecutions. The second is obviously the inability of courts in this country to handle complex corporate matters. Just as the Australian Taxation Office appears to be both understaffed and lacking sufficient highly trained officers to carry out the necessary investigative and prosecution work, there is considerable evidence that the NCSC and its State delegates are likewise hampered. It is an appalling indictment of this Government's priorities . If we are to take the regulation of corporate crime seriously we ought to be prepared to pay for it. There is a substantial link between the proper regulation of companies and tax avoidance. Thus the return to the public from its investment in resources in the corporate area would at least be cost- effective.

Company and commercial matters are often beyond the understanding of the common jury. It may be that the expediency adopted in the Bankruptcy Act of making all offences triable summarily unless the court itself commits for trial by jury ought at least to be considered. Under the Bankruptcy Act summary trial leads to a lesser penalty than may be imposed on conviction or indictment, but certainty of conviction is certainly a great deterrent. It is high time also that the superior court provided a permanent commercial division for the rapid untangling of corporate problems and corporate misfeasance.

I say to the Government that if we as legislators fail-as we certainly have-to give the community the laws it deserves, the laws it needs, but above all the laws it ought to respect, the backlash by the people in this country will be predictable and inevitable. Public cynicism at the genuineness of concern by governments for fair and efficient business dealings will inevitably increase. As the current atmosphere surrounding tax avoidance clearly indicates, sooner or later the chickens will come home to roost. We ought to remember that-each and every one of us. When the law is allowed to be disregarded and brought into contempt public acceptance of the legitimacy of the entire authority of the state is jeopardised. For five years the Government has brought the tax laws and the corporate laws in this country into contempt. When that happens the Government has a real problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not do that.

—Yes, the Government did. The Government has failed to act over the last five years. When it comes to corporate law the government has had the complicity of Labor governments. They are as much to be indicted as this Government when it comes to the matter of decent federal company law. It is a charade.
—You are talking about tax.

—The biggest problem the Government has with tax avoidance is the sheer exploitation of the inefficiencies and ineffectiveness of the company law. If the Government had tidied that up the Government would never have been in the position it is in today. The Minister argued against me 18 months ago on ex- proprietary companies with the claim that they were the cornerstone of capitalism. They are the cornerstone for the spiv, the charlatan and the corporate crook. That has been proved beyond any doubt. This Government has been warned by the revelations of the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. That has been compounded by a long litany of revelation of corruption, collusion and malpractices in a whole range of critical areas that have seriously damaged the credibility of this Government, the judiciary, the corporate and some professional bodies. If we are to sweep away this appalling legacy and clean it up there must be major surgery and reform in these areas. If the Government fails to do that it will be back in this Parliament going through the same exercises as it is tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradfield Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The five taxation Bills before the House at the moment could well be described as the most effective and certainly the most important legislation presented to and passed by this Parliament since the election of this Government to office in 1975. I say the most important legislation not because I regard other legislation in a lesser way but rather because this legislation, above all, will put to rest tax evasion and the tax avoidance industry. Those few Australian people and organisations which have conducted campaigns against the introduction of this legislation have endeavoured to promote uncertainty amongst the many genuine taxpayers who have been contributing their tax in a lawful manner. By their action they endeavour to give their campaigns a degree of credibility that they do not deserve; they tend to hide their blatant schemes amongst other legal arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak as a member of this Parliament who, over the last few months, has received 70 or 80 letters from different people. They are conducting a most professional campaign; a campaign which, when one analyses those letters, has obviously been organised by people who have a strong vested interest in the matter. The effects of the legislation that we are now considering can be stated simply. This legislation is designed to collect tax legally due from a company which has been rendered unable to pay its assessed commitments because its assets have been stripped in a most artificial manner. This legislation seeks payment from those who have unfairly gained from a contrived situation. I refer to vendor-shareholders and the promoters of the schemes. This legislation is not the result of a government's greed for revenue, as suggested by some, but rather a strong and continuing desire to ensure fairness to all sections of our Australian community. It is our responsibility to shoulder the taxation burden in an acceptable ratio to our reward for effort and initiative. It would therefore follow that additional revenues now collectable as a result of this legislation will enable a future reduction in other federal revenue raising matters imposed on the Australian people. In other words, those who may have been disadvantaged through their honesty and a sense of community responsibility will be relieved of this unfair burden.

If we look at tax collection statistics we will see that they clearly show the growing burden that has been placed on those persons who have their tax deducted from their wages and salaries. I refer to pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. This can be seen particularly when one compares such collections with tax collected from companies. If one looks at a 12-year comparison-1970-82-in the statistics provided in the Budget Papers one will find that revenue from companies expressed as a percentage of pay-as-you-earn tax has declined from 55 per cent in 1970 to 29 per cent in 1982. To highlight another statistical comparison, I express as a percentage of total Budget revenue collections the statistics of company tax collections. In 1970 company tax collections, as a percentage of total Budget revenue, represented 17 per cent, yet in 1982 the figure had fallen to 13 per cent. It is clear that both of these comparisons show the declining value of company tax.

I realise that by making these statements I may offend many people operating companies which fairly meet their company tax obligations. Obviously the decline in these company tax collections results from a minority of company people practising tax evasion on a large scale. I apologise to honest operators of companies which have fairly contributed tax over the years. If we study the statistics relating to pay-as-you-earn tax collections-they appear in the same Budget Papers I mentioned earlier-no decline emerges. In fact the trend is reversed. In 1970 PAYE collections provided 32 per cent of total revenue; yet in 1982-12 years later-they provide 46 per cent of total revenue collections. Surely this is a trend that is very unwelcome to wage and salary earners. It is a trend that is unfair to the community and it is a trend that will not be tolerated by this Government. That is the reason why we have this legislation before the Parliament at the moment. It is not surprising that community reaction against such practices has been growing. Rectification of the anomoly is very much justified. To allow such a situation to continue would eventually place the Australian democratic system in jeopardy.

Perhaps I should say in passing how disappointed I am that a small number of my parliamentary colleagues have apparently seen fit to indicate their opposition to this legislation. Although I have some understanding of their reasoning, based on their principles, and in particular their objection to retrospective legislation, I feel that in these circumstances the actions by a minority group have been so damaging to fellow citizens and our country that I have no hesitation in forgoing my dislike for retrospective laws in supporting this legislation. What has been done is not legal. People just distance themselves from action under the law. These actions and schemes have been far from the spirit of the tax legislation and normally accepted taxation practices.

Those participating in the schemes must have always realised the risks involved . Perhaps some thought it was Christmas and they deserved a present. In my past occupation as an accountant I could only liken these schemes to fantasy and fairy tales. Perhaps the only other words that one could use to describe them are completely unrealistic. In reviewing the legislation, which is obviously quite comprehensive-some 40-odd pages supported by two sections of explanatory notes-could I first clearly restate that it is designed to collect unpaid tax legally assessed. It does not, as some would want us to believe, attempt to illegalise retrospectively that which is legally allowable; nor does it interfere with that which is legally disputed. Such disputes are for the courts and the taxation boards of review to determine. The legislation provides for payment of tax by vendor-shareholders as well as the architects who organised arrangements whereby companies are unable to meet their tax payments, the people described in the legislation as promoters. These people have benefited at the community's expense and they now have to pay.

Another major point of importance addressed in this legislation is the 12 months period allowed to pay. Although I have no sympathy for those who have benefited from payment not made, it must be realised that the money is not lying around in someone's bank account just waiting to be paid to the Commissioner of Taxation but may be in some form of investment providing goods and services to the Australian people and possibly providing employment for many Australians. Under these circumstances a reasonable time should be provided so as to create circumstances least liable to disrupt. I am pleased that the 12-month period to pay has been allowed in this legislation. I know that many other honourable members tonight wish to express their opinions on these five Bills, but before I cease this speech I wish to congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Howard). There has been tremendous pressure in the build-up to this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —In seven years he has done nothing.

—There has been tremendous pressure within the party. We have entered a period of Parliament following the 1972-75 rule of the Labor Party when nothing was done. There is pressure, particularly against the legality of retrospective Acts. I am pleased to be associated with a strong Treasurer who is prepared to carry this legislation through, because it is for the good of the country. At times he has carried this legislation through under considerable pressure. It is my pleasure to support this legislation. It will benefit the people of Australia. I am happy to see it introduced into this Parliament. I certainly support it. I look forward to the benfits that support of this legislation will provide in future to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation is not only far too little-it is far too late. It catches some of the cheats, but it protects a lot more and allows them off scot-free. The Government has deliberately narrowed its scope to apply only to schemes where company tax, or undistributed profits tax, was payable and an illegal evasion of tax took place. Tax avoidance-however blatant and contrived, however much it has cost ordinary taxpayers-is exempted from this legislation. This shows how hollow has been the political posturing on this issue by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). He has been forced to do just enough to try to satisfy outraged public opinion-but nowhere near enough to catch all those hundreds of Liberal Party supporters who have been ripping off the tax system ever since this Government came to office.

SPEECH.PARA: For most of the last 18 months the Prime Minister has been insisting that there is no difference between tax avoidance and tax evasion. Suddenly, now, the Prime Minister discovers there is a difference, and a big difference. His professed moral outrage is replaced by a mealy-mouthed rationalisation why this Government will do nothing to bring to account a lot of wealthy Liberal Party supporters who have been into the lucrative business of tax avoidance for years. So the tax avoiders are to be allowed to go on bludging off the rest of the community. This legislation does nothing to stop them, and it does nothing to recover the thousands of millions of dollars lost in tax avoidance.

The Prime Minister's extraordinary political expediency on this issue is perfectly demonstrated in the Government's insistence on catching only situations where illegal evasion was involved. That is the Government's argument today. Yet for months, if not years, senior Ministers have been arguing that the Government's hands were tied in taking action against bottom-of-the-harbour schemes because the existing law did not make them illegal.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer cannot have it both ways. If the schemes were legal at the time, why is the Government now going to such lengths to distinguish them as different from other legal tax avoidance rorts? If they were illegal, why did the Government not do something about them for almost five years? If they were illegal, they could have been illegal only because they transgressed existing law. Why the massive delay? If we ask the Prime Minister for an explanation, we get a rambling, meaningless diatribe that simply ignores the question. The Prime Minister does not want to know about the relationship between tax evasion and tax avoidance, and he will say just about anything, however incoherent, to try to fudge the issue. But the fact remains that a lot of people, a lot of wealthy Liberal Party supporters, who should be caught by this legislation and forced to pay the millions in tax they have avoided for years, are going to get away without paying a cent. This Government, and this bowdlerised legislation, is going to protect them.

How tax evasion and avoidance have grown under the Fraser Government. The third interim report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union late last year on tax avoidance and evasion said:

This industry has developed in Australia, particularly over the last 5 years, at a rate far in excess of any other industry and has brought with it profits comparable only to the heady days of the Victorian gold rush . . . the impact on the community has been very serious.

The Commissioner of Taxation's annual reports between 1975-76 and 1980-81 reveal a 2,500 per cent increase in the number of identified participants in tax avoidance schemes. Australian companies are avoiding hundreds of millions of dollars a year through use of tax havens due to the Treasurer's abandonment of a foreign tax credits scheme. The Opposition, without any apology at all, proposes to take this issue up in greater depth a little later.

Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association estimates that $7,000m for annual losses in tax revenue are due to avoidance and evasion. In very simple terms that means that the average Australian household has to pay over $ 35 a week extra tax to subsidise the tax cheats. As Professor Mathews said in 1980:
. . . personal income tax is a voluntary tax for the rich non-salary earner.

That is the sort of achievement of the Fraser Government. The wealthy decide as an option whether they will pay their taxes while those less well off, the middle income earners, the modest income earners, have no choice at all. More than that, they have to bear an unfairly high tax burden to subsidise the tax parasites who have been evading and avoiding in this one persistent growth industry under the Liberal Government.

The history of Government inaction has caused a massive shortfall in tax revenue. The Government has sought to make good those losses, not by making sure the tax cheats pay up, but by hitting low and middle income wage and salary earners. The Government just is not fair dinkum in its fight against tax avoidance and evasion.

Bluntly, the Government has failed. It has failed to commit itself to fully retrospective legislation against blatant avoidance schemes back to the time they were first used. It has failed to launch prosecutions under the new general anti-avoidance legislation-Part IVA-or under the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. Neither of these weapons has been tested although available for eighteen months or more. It has failed to take action to recover tax avoided under bottom-of-the -harbour schemes until shamed into doing so by the disclosures of the McCabe- Lafranchi report, which the Treasurer initially sought to deride as a stunt. Some stunt! It has forced the Government to retrace its steps and to introduce this legislation.

Apart from the dimensions of the actual loss in tax revenue that has taken place, perhaps the worst aspect of this whole affair has been this Government's procrastination against closing off the so-called bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Let me remind the House that sections of the Australian Taxation Office, and the Attorney-General's Department have known about these schemes for nine years. In 1975 the first prosecution was about to be launched in Perth-a prosecution which would have closed off this licence to make money for a lot of greedy and unscrupulous people and saved literally thousands of millions of dollars in tax revenue.

But then this Government came into office and, quite mysteriously, the file on the prosecution itself went not to the bottom of the harbour, but to the bottom drawer for the next six years. The Treasurer, by his own admission, has known about these schemes since February 1978. Almost five years ago the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr O'Reilly, told him. He not only told him; he also warned him that there was a need to make directors and shareholders personally liable for a company's tax on current year profits after they had been stripped and the records sent to the bottom of the harbour. The Treasurer should have-he certainly could have-there and then declared that remedial legislation to stop this scheme would be enacted and, further, would apply from the date of announcement.

Commissioner O'Reilly urged the Treasurer on 11 November of that year-that is 1978-to adopt a general principle of this nature. The Treasurer did so a week later, but it was never applied to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. That is incomprehensible in view of the evidence presented to the Treasurer by the Commissioner of Taxation. Earlier, in May 1978, Commissioner O'Reilly recommended that a new criminal offence should be created to catch those involved in current year profit strips. Then began an extraordinary period of backing and filling between the Treasurer, the Australian Taxation Office and the Attorney-General's Department. It went on for 2 1/2 years before finally the Government enacted its Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act in December 1980. Throughout this period nothing was done, except that letters got written, interminable meetings were held, people pondered, papers were shuffled, delays occurred and the responsibility was passed backwards and forwards. Tens of millions of dollars went on draining away in the hands of the greedy evaders and avoiders who were milking the tax system at a furious rate.

Then, after the new legislation was enacted in 1980, still nothing was done to catch anyone or to recover any of the lost tax for another two and a half years. Now that I find intolerable and inexcusable. Nothing was done until Mr Costigan turned up with his now notorious report just 3 months ago and touched off the panic in the Prime Minister's office that has now produced this latest Bill. At last something is being done, but only after seven years. We still do not have a single Minister who will accept any responsibility for the appalling delay which has gone on for so long and which probably would have continued until the Labor government was returned to office if it had not been for the diligence of Mr Costigan.

Let us look at some examples of where the Government has deliberately allowed tax avoiders to escape. We have all heard the Prime Minister defend tax avoiders who have cost the taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars through straightforward uncomplicated dry Slutzkin schemes. In addition, many dry Slutzkins were part of the same transactions as wet Slutzkins. If honourable members require elucidation on dry and wet Slutzkins, I suggest that they should have listened to my colleague the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) who dealt with this in considerable informed detail earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —He understands it a good deal better than you do.

—That may well be true. The Treasurer was generous enough to say that the speech of the honourable member for Hawker was more informed and interesting than mine, and I freely acknowledge it. That would still allow my speech to be well ahead of the Treasurer's. This second type of dry Slutzkin has cost about half as much again as was lost due to current year profit strips; that is about $300m. In total, losses due to dry Slutzkins were about $600m. The Government has no plans to recover that money or any other part of the $3 billion lost under the schemes that had subsequently been outlawed. What is the distinction? In the past the Treasurer has made none. Nor has the Treasurer sought to distinguish between types of schemes when resorting to his harsh rhetoric against tax dodgers. About the part IVA amending legislation in May 1981 he said :

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of this further legislation (i.e. a penalty tax of 200%) is that the persons who stand to profit most by company stripping activities-the vendor shareholders-also stand to pay heavily for any involvement in such activities.
He added:
That proposition applies both to bottom of the harbour strips and strips of tax company profits.

He puts them on an equal footing. He does not distinguish. He condemns both of them as being equally improper and equally inexcusable but in this legislation he acts against one only. Nor was Commissioner Costigan in any doubt about the qualitative equivalence of the two types of schemes. In Costigan's fourth interim report, volume 1, he describes the scheme to which chapter 3 'Fraud on the Commonwealth Revenue' is directed. On pages 72 to 73, Costigan describes the implementation of the scheme. In sub-paragraph (c) it is clear that Costigan does not distinguish qualitatively between current year profit and accumulated profit schemes. He says:
The assets and liabilities of the target company were then transferred to the new corporate entity, leaving at the end of the day, a target company with only cash in the bank.
He goes on:
The amount of cash in the bank was equal to the accumulated profits, plus the current year profits (if any).
The cash in the bank reflected that equation, and it was on that amount that the percentage constituting the promoter's commission was calculated.
The total amount of cash in the bank was the money that was then used to finance the purchase of the shares.

The point, however, is that he does not make any distinction. He refers to accumulated profit schemes and those schemes which have additional current year profits, if any. He makes no distinction. He puts on equal footing the accumulated profits or dormant company schemes which are resorted to as part of tax avoidance and which until recently were excoriated by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. What happened in the interim? They discovered that senior officials of the Liberal Party and prominent establishment figures from the corporate sector who they had favoured with appointments had been involved in these sorts of schemes; so they immediately established a distinction to save those people from embarrassment and themselves from shame. But those tax bludgers have ripped off millions of dollars, they have become greedy and unscrupulous millionaires at the expense of the rest of the community. McCabe and Lafranchi had no doubt about this either. Only the Government makes this false distinction. The reason is simple. Wet Slutzkins were usually operated by the new rich who made quick killings-the sort of person the Prime Minister would blackball from his Melbourne club. Dry Slutzkins, on the other hand, involve pillars of the establishment-old money-and are therefore untouchable.

Perhaps the most important change between this version of the Bill and the withdrawn Bill is the insertion of a completely new clause 3 (12). This provision waters down an already limp wristed Bill to such an extent that at least one in four of affected companies will now be exempted from liability for recoupment tax that they would have paid under the first draft of the Bill. This amendment, which we should call the Baume amendment after the honourable member for Macarthur, means that where a company, after being stripped of its assets, entered into a post-sale tax avoidance scheme to reduce or eliminate tax liability, it has now been exempted. This provision is crippling for the legislation. Many promoters, after stripping the company and paying the vendor shareholders, entered into a variety of tax avoidance schemes to eliminate the tax liability-for example, Curran schemes, pre-paid interest schemes or complex differential interest rate schemes. In these cases the vendor shareholders will escape scot-free even though they got an unrealistic and inflated price for their shares.

Another major problem with the Bill is its great complexity. The Government has been so concerned to narrow its scope, to write in exemptions, and to soften its effects that any half-way decent lawyer should be able to ensure that his clients either pay no tax under the Bill or at least do not pay tax for many years. My attention has been drawn to a number of what might seem to be technical problems with the Bill. If these problems are real, the chances of the Government recovering much money quickly seems small. Some important examples include clause 3 (2), which excludes as directors persons acting:
In the proper performance of the functions attaching to his professional capacity or to his business relationships with the directors.

The effect of this is that the mastermind behind the schemes may be able to get off the hook. Clause 3 (11) protects taxpayers from paying an additional back tax in respect of the tax avoided. This means that the vendor-shareholders will have the use of all this unpaid tax for years to invest and on which they can make a profit. Vendor-shareholders should at least have to pay as a penalty a reasonable interest on the unpaid tax.

Clause 4 (8) may seem to be no more than a technical provision for the service of notices. Its effect, however, is that the promoter who skips the country will be able to evade service of assessment notices and will therefore be able to evade his liability, despite the fact that he may have assets back in Australia more than sufficient to pay the tax. Already one promoter has disappeared overseas, and although the Government is more than willing to refuse passports to those it persecutes under social security legislation, it will not do the same to tax avoiders.

Clause 5 (1) (j) is a most unusual test. Any imaginative promoter should be able to pump out of his word processor structured evidence to prove that the business was in fact carried on after the last sale. Clause 5 (1) (m), when read carefully, has the effect of giving the vendor-shareholder a tax deduction for the fee he paid the promoter-that is, the taxpayer is subsidising criminals.

Clause 5 (1) (g) and clause 5 (2) (g) have the effect that when a company was stripped and at the same time, or just before the strip, the company entered into a tax avoidance scheme, the vendor-shareholders could argue that at the time the company was sold the company did not have a liability to unpaid tax- another loophole. Again the imaginative evader can get to work to fake the evidence.

Clause 21, of course, is an outrage. Pay-as-you-earn taxpayers have been bearing the burden of these rich speculator tax evaders for years, but when PAYE earners come to pay their tax they do not get any time to pay. What is so special about taxpayers under this Bill is that they get a 12-months instalment plan, and interest free. It sounds more like an advertisement for a shady finance company than a serious tax Bill-an entirely appropriate metaphor for this Government.

This Bill is better than nothing-but only just. It is a typical product of this Prime Minister. He has trumpeted about what tough action he is going to take, but his mates in the Melbourne Club and in the Western Districts have given him his orders: 'Do as little as you can to save your political skin. Make sure it is full of loopholes and so complicated that, at the best, it will be years before any of these rich parasites on society have to take the unprecedented step of actually paying what they owe in taxes.' I serve warning on all the millionaire speculators who believe they have a divine right to rip off ordinary decent Australians. After the next election we will get it back, we will get it all back, and we will get it back quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of my colleagues also wish to speak in this debate, which is being conducted within a limited time, so I will attempt to state my position as briefly as possible and hope that I will be able to make some further detailed comments tomorrow in the Committee stage of the consideration of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill (No. 2). I oppose the Bill. My opposition is based on a fundamental belief in the rule of law, a concept already introduced into this debate by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury). One need not be a lawyer or resort to detailed and complex jurisprudence texts to understand what is meant by the rule of law and to appreciate its vital importance to our society. I believe the rule of law is well understood by all who value the concepts of freedom, liberty, justice, fairness, impartiality, regularity and certainty. These concepts are relevant to the legal ordering of our relations between one another as citizens equal under the law, and they are certainly central to the governing of the relations between the individual and the state. The rule of law is built on and embodies these concepts, underpinning the very foundation of our society. The rule of law safeguards freedom and liberty whereby a citizen is free to do as he pleases so far as he is not prevented by the force of law. It is the rule of law which demands, where freedom and liberty are so limited by law, that the law be administered in accordance with the precepts of natural justice.

SPEECH.PARA: Under this legislation the clock will be turned backwards to make taxable today what yesterday, in the hands of the vendor-shareholders, was non-taxable. Within constitutional limitations I do not challenge the power of the Parliament to make or unmake any law whatsoever, but I should have thought that the injustice to persons who are affected by retrospective laws is so obvious as not to require elaboration. Resort to retrospective law fundamentally affects our society because it is contrary to and destructive of the very basis of our system-the rule of law which I mentioned briefly. Once any form of retrospective legislation is accepted the decision as to where to draw the line is totally subjective, and through its use we move, as my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro stated, from a situation in which there is 'government under the law' to one in which there is 'government above the law'.

It is being argued that this overturning of the rule of law should be supported on some subjective understanding of fairness. It has been put to me that the principle of fairness should overrule the aversion to retrospective legislation on this occasion. I considered that argument, firstly by focusing on the nature of taxation under the rule of law. I think in the main it will be accepted that the taxation system is a revenue raising instrument providing for government expenditure by describing in the tax Act various classes of taxpayers, goods and categories of action which will attract a taxation liability. Predominantly, tax is neither a punishment nor a fine, and the absence of a tax is not a reward. Everybody believes that the tax Act and the taxation system should be fair. Undeniably, that is the principle upon which the provisions of the taxation legislation should be based.

It is obvious, then, that under the rule of law certainty of the tax laws is essential if the tax system is to operate fairly. Fairness must be inserted at the outset so that at any time all can know by definition or description whether they will be liable for tax. However, to assert a concept of fairness after the event which imposes a liability on people who acted in accordance with the law at the time is, in reality, not fair but extremely unfair. Let us remember that taxation is an Act of Parliament and not an act of God. Taxation liability is determined by objective criteria contained in the tax Act. If we are now to override these objective criteria by the retrospective application of a moral judgment about what is fair, the very need for the tax Act is negated. We might as well replace it with a single-section Act which could state: 'A person shall pay the amount of tax which is deemed by the Commissioner of Taxation at any time to be appropriate or fair'.

I have also considered the argument of fairness in the light of what the vendor -shareholders actually did. Vendor-shareholders legally sold shares for a capital non-taxable sum. They were supported by the provisions of the tax act which provided that a taxpayer's taxable income is determined at the end of the year of income, meaning that there is no tax liability in respect of the current year of income at the time of the sale of the shares. Vendor-shareholders were supported by another provision which stated that the taxpayer is liable only for his or its tax which, in the case of a company, is the company's liability and not that of the shareholder. They were supported by decisions of the Full High Court of Australia and the Supreme Court of South Australia, and the apparent governmental acceptance of these decisions that shareholders who sold their shares to dividend strippers were not personally liable for income tax on the capital proceeds they received on the sale of their shares.
