They were supported in the belief by legal opinions that purchasers would take legal steps to reduce the companies' current year taxable income.

It is history now that the McCabe-Lafranchi report showed that in many cases of such sales of shares no legal steps were taken by the purchasers, and the companies were in fact sent to the bottom of the harbour, the outstanding tax liability not having been reduced or paid. It is history too that the Costigan report revealed that in 1974 the Commissioner of Taxation was advised by Mr Brinsden Q.C., as he was then, that criminal and civil proceedings could be taken against persons who had stripped a company of its assets and put it in a position of being unable to pay its tax. It is further history within the same report that in 1982 it was discovered that instructions to proceed on the matter had been sitting in a bottom drawer of the desk of an officer in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth for five years.

Fraudulent and illegal evasion of tax took place in the sale of share arrangements which are the subject of this legislation. Of that there is no dispute, but it was fraudulent and illegal evasion practised by the purchasers and strippers, not the vendor shareholders. Yet now, in an extremely arbitrary way, it is proposed to recover the unpaid tax from the innocent vendor shareholders. It is likely that the guilty purchasers and strippers, because they were fraudulent evaders, will have so ordered their affairs as to escape the net. If that is fair, it is beyond my understanding.

Finally, I have examined the concept of fairness in the light of the legislation's own terms. The legislation proposed to create an artificial tax year-1 July to the date of the sale of shares-where, as I have stated earlier, a company tax liability for the current year of income did not exist at the time of sale. This destroys the limited liability protection for vendor shareholders and, in an extremely discriminatory fashion, now makes them liable for the debts of others. Against this there are numerous opinions confirming the view that existing laws are sufficient to bring to justice those persons who have committed criminal or civil offences. Fraudulent and illegal evasion of tax may be subject to recovery through sections 47 (2B), 231 and 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and sections 124, 295 (2),367B and 374D of the Companies Act. Fraudulent and illegal evasion may constitute offences under the common law provisions regarding the cheating of the Crown under section 231 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, section 86 of the Crimes Act and sections 124, 374C (1) and 374C (2) of the Companies Act. We are overturning law and the rule of law to create a new retrospective liability on shareholders when existing law to cover the fraudulent and illegal evasion of tax remains unused. I cannot accept that this is fair.

In conclusion, I do not think that the proposed law can be supported on any objective criteria. It is no comfort to argue that we are only recouping an outstanding liability. It must be recognised that the power to tax is the power to destroy. When a liability is retrospectively imposed on persons who have hitherto had no such liability there will undoubtedly be a destructive effect on innocent individuals. When that is realised retrospective regret will be useless .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government's inaction over a number of years has now resulted in a situation where large amounts of revenue have been lost to the Commonwealth. People involved in bottom-of-the-harbour tax evasion schemes now hold considerable amounts of money which rightfully belong to the Australian people. The growth of such schemes as bottom-of-the-harbour schemes has meant that while pay-as-you-earn taxpayers have been contributing a growing proportion of tax revenue, paying tax has been optional for rich property owners and the very wealthy. Under the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill (No. 2) and the other Bills which are being dealt with cognately, the Government is proposing to recover only company tax and undistributed profits tax lost through bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. It is ignoring completely the income tax lost through dividend stripping and lost sales tax. Those two types of lost revenue probably account for double the amount lost through the types of schemes covered by this legislation. The Government hopes to recover about $580m. This means that it is ignoring $1.5 billion to $2.5 billion. Following this Government's inaction and ineptitude between the years 1977 and 1980 and between then and the introduction of this legislation it will now forfeit about two-thirds of the tax evaded and avoided through these schemes, that is, the wet and dry Slutzkins. This legislation is a most inadequate attempt to recover vast sums of money lost on this enormous tax rip-off.

SPEECH.PARA: The circumstances surrounding the deplorable tax avoidance and evasion mess centres, of course, on the Slutzkin case in the High Court of Australia in 1977. The occurrence of this High Court case marked the beginning of a massive surge in the growth of tax avoidance in this country which, in the words of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, rivalled the heady days of the Victorian gold rush. The High Court case dealt with what is now known as a dry Slutzkin involving a dividend stripping operation which avoided income tax for the original vendor shareholders. In the High Court case three justices presided, the Chief Justice, Garfield Barwick, and Justices Stephen and Aicken. Unanimously they decided that section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act could not be used to counter the activities occurring in the Slutzkin case. This case was one of a number in which Chief Justice Barwick had an opportunity to pursue his most peculiar view on tax avoidance which was that a taxpayer has the right to organise his affairs in such a way as to minimise his total tax bill even though the arrangement may have little or nothing to do with genuine commercial or business practices. The sole aim, of course, was to minimise tax liability. Despite the unanimity of the judges sitting on the Slutzkin case, Barwick's view on tax avoidance and the effect of section 260 of the Act, the general anti-avoidance section, was quite singular. The Privy Council has already disagreed with the Barwick view in connection with the Keighery case in 1957. In the early 1980s Justice Murphy took an opposite view in the Westraders case. Prior to this case Murphy had not sat on a major case involving tax avoidance. Decisions on tax avoidance were dominated until then by the Barwick view. The decision of Barwick gave a great comfort to the tax avoidance industry and has one of the elements leading to the vast growth in tax avoidance from about 1977.

The dry Slutzkin tax avoidance schemes, as we all know now, quite simply converted a dividend which was subject to income tax into a capital gain which was not subject to tax. Wet Slutzkin schemes were, I suppose, given the crooked nature of the people involved, a logical extension of the dry Slutzkin operation . These schemes not only provided this dividend stripping but also were extended to allow for evasion of company tax on current profits and Division 7 tax on accumulated profits. Vendor shareholders sold their company to a tax evasion promoter for 10 per cent to 20 per cent less than the value of the company's assets without deducting the tax liability. This 10 per cent to 20 per cent, of course, became the promoter's fee. The promoter then used procedures such as collapsable loans to enable the reduction of company assets to a level where the taxes could not be paid. Having stripped the assets of the company in this way the promoter then either sold the company to the men of straw or simply destroyed the company's papers-vis-a-vis the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes-so as to destroy the records of the company's activities. But it was the deliberate act of evading the company's tax liability that made wet Slutzkin schemes illegal-it became illegal tax evasion instead of avoidance-while the dry Slutzkin schemes were legal, according to the Barwick High Court decision and, therefore, were only tax avoidance schemes.

These evolving company-stripping tax-evasion activities which flowed from the Barwick High Court decision were not stopped by this Government. They should have been. This flourishing of tax evasion cost Australia dearly in lost tax revenue. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) has said that he expects to recover $580m from this piece of legislation-$470 in unpaid primary tax I think and $110m in unpaid Division 7 tax. However, the total cost to Australia of bottom-of-the- harbour schemes is much greater than this. This legislation ignores the income tax lost through avoidance by vendor shareholders in both wet and dry Slutzkin schemes. In addition, it does not provide for collection of sales tax lost through the use of the straw companies. That is an outline of the development of these deplorable practices.

I move on now to examine why there was this inexcusable delay on the part of this Government. It has been clearly demonstrated that at least two avenues were open to this Government long before 1980 and long before this legislation. Firstly, Mr Costigan has pointed out in the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union that existing law was sufficient to launch charges against these people. Secondly, the Commissioner of Taxation has been warning this Government-as the record shows- for a number of years that, if existing law was not adequate, new legislation should be enacted. Going back to my first option, it is now common knowledge that the Brinsden opinion of, I think, 1976, which was mentioned in the Costigan report, outlined that either individually or collectively the company taxation Act, the Crimes Act and the Income Tax Act contained sufficient powers both to charge the perpetrators of the schemes and to recoup the finance involved.

Why was there a delay? According to documents tabled in this House on 22 September by the Treasurer, letters written by the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr O'Reilly, how and why legislation should have been enacted to combat these practices was outlined on no less than 30 occasions between 15 July 1977 and October 1980. Yet we have seen nothing but a litany of government incompetence, delay and deliberate obfuscation which has cost workers and tax payers billions of dollars. Statements by Taxation Commissioner O'Reilly and other members of the Australian Taxation Office demonstrate the extent of these schemes. In June 1978 the Commissioner told the Treasurer, in the documents I am referring to, that the stripping of 389 companies in three States by one promoter had cost over $9m. In October 1979 the Commissioner told the Treasurer that about 1,230 companies had been stripped by one promoter in three States involving the loss of another $21.3m. Again, in October 1980 the Commissioner told the Treasurer that a Sydney operator had stripped 733 companies involving the loss of $128m in tax. As a sort of coup de grace the Commissioner told the Treasurer that nearly $9m worth of shares had been traded by the chief straw company operator in Sydney in two days just prior to the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 coming into force. As if these amounts were not bad enough the Commissioner had pointed out on 15 November 1979:
. . . write offs are only the tip of the iceberg-in most straw company cases it has not been practicable to debit the tax.

The Commissioner of Taxation was uncertain as to the total cost of all these schemes because naturally the promoters did not declare the amount of the evasion and avoidance. If the Commissioner was right about these write-offs being only the tip of the iceberg then we could expect the total loss to be ten times the amount which I have mentioned. The total cost of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes could be around $2 billion to $3 billion. Yet we are looking at picking up only something like $580m in this legislation.

What was the Government's responsibility in the face of this massive haemorrhage of revenue? Obviously its first responsibility was to act as speedily as possible to stop the loss. It demonstrably did not do so. It could have done so under existing law, as the rebels on the opposite side of the House are so keen to point out. But it did not do that. It could have legislated in the way in which the Commissioner of Taxation pleaded with it to do but it did not do that. There were almost four years of inexcusable delay and this country lost almost $3 billion in revenue.

I want to digress slightly and put this on the record: Use of the existing law could have recouped this money. If it could not, against the advice of Mr Brinsden and outlined in the Costigan report, legislation could have been enacted much earlier. The job could have been done by means of those two avenues . But, as has been pointed out by the Press scribes, there was another way in which to do this. These schemes, particularly the dry Slutzkin schemes, were effective only because of the lack of a workable, just and fair capital gains tax. If Australia had a capital gains tax, the dry Slutzkin schemes would have been negated and the illegal wet Slutzkin schemes would have been less effective than they have been as a means of avoiding tax. Where company tax was not paid, in a sense a capital gains tax would have still partly negated the wet Slutzkins . A capital gains tax would not have recouped as much tax as company tax plus income tax on distributed profits but it certainly would have been better than nothing. Of course that is what this Government got-nothing.

After four years this Government finally decided four weeks ago to make a virtue out of necessity. Perhaps in a hopeful early election situation the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) decided that the may as well attack some of the friends of his own party, to make an appeal over their heads directly to the electorate and to say: 'We have been caught out by the Costigan report. But now we have the Special Prosecutors Act; we will set up this National Crimes Commission and we will introduce this tough retrospective legislation to attack all these people such as Horgan and company. That shows you how fair and how fair dinkum we are'. Of course that is what he has in mind-to attack his own party and his own people and appeal over their heads to the electorate. But the electorate is going to say: 'Well, you should have done this years ago. Why was there the need for retrospective legislation when you could have used existing law or legislated years ago or implemented a capital gains tax?' Now the Government is introducing this legislation, and that is what Government rebels are bitching about. After four long weary years four weeks ago the Government brought in this legislation. Of course it suddenly became too strong for it so it had to have a significant watering down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the capital gains tax issue get too strong for you? What is your position?
—Now we see that five changes have been made. Some we support, others we do not.
—Just tell us about the capital gains tax.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, if you cannot control the apes opposite I suggest you ship them off to Taronga Park where they belong.

—I suggest that the honourable member's voice is quite loud enough to drown the interjections if he takes no notice of them. Nevertheless, as the matter is worrying the honourable member, I call the House to order. Interjections are becoming too prevalent.

—The Government has made five changes, some of which we support and others of which represent a significant watering down of the legislation. The Government is going to try to make the promoters liable for 20 per cent of the company tax and the undistributed profits tax which have been evaded. That is fair enough. I support that. The Government is going to give the identified vendor-shareholders one year to pay instead of 30 days. Quite frankly, I do not think they deserve that.

SPEECH.PARA: The third change is that the Government does not want to identify those who fail to pay the recoupment tax despite the fact that they have had the benefit of the money all this time. If they do not pay they are still not going to be named in the annual report of the Commission of Taxation. The fourth change is the one that I think is the most serious change. Vendor-shareholders of some 700 companies whose promoters tried but failed to avoid liable company tax via a tax avoidance scheme are now not going to be liable. That is a very serious loophole because it will let many of these vendor-shareholders off the hook simply because a promoter's own avoidance scheme has failed. The fifth change, as I understand it, is that all vendor-shareholders, where possible, instead of just one, are to be served with a company assessment notice. I think that is fair enough. I support that. I want to conclude with a quote from Kenneth Davidson writing for the Age. He discussed the John Reid case. He implemented-not a wet Slutzkin but a dry Slutzkin.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the Moore case, too.
—This is the Moore-Reid case. Let me tell honourable members what Davidson said. I think he is right. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most profoundly disturbing elements in this little sub plot of the whole tax avoidance saga is the claim by Mr Moore that if the $90,000 of profits had been distributed so that income tax of $43,000 had been payable, ''we would have exposed ourselves to the beneficiaries. They would have been able to say ' why did you lose us $43,000? We're going to sue you'.''
What a deadly confirmation of Professor Mathews' claim that paying tax is optional for the rich.

We support the legislation as far as it goes, but with the amendment-as moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand. What it seeks to do should have been done years ago; the Government had the opportunity-it lost the money. It will take a long time getting it back. Many of its supporters have been engaged in these schemes and the people of Australia will never forgive the Government for its failure to protect the Federal revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bungey Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the comments by the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) illustrate very clearly some of the fears I have about this legislation. He talked about a capital gains tax and the implications of a capital gains tax. If we think of retrospectivity being applied to a capital gains tax we realise just how horrendous it is. It does not matter whether members of the Australian Labor Party profess it openly or covertly, they are in support of a capital gains tax. That is very clear. Secondly, even though I oppose the legislation I cannot agree with the point made by the honourable member that the legislation has been watered down. To some extent concessions have been made which I think have converted very bad legislation into just bad legislation. That is the best and most complimentary comment I can make about it .

SPEECH.PARA: I oppose the legislation. I oppose also the amendment moved by the Opposition to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2]. My opposition is based on several grounds. Firstly, I find retrospective taxation in all forms absolutely abhorrent, unjust and unnecessary. Secondly, I agree with some of the comments which have been made by members on the opposite side that there has been inaction by the Government-if not by the Government, at least by the bureaucratic element of the Government. It puzzles me that people have not been taken to task for this inactivity over a long time. Thirdly, I oppose the legislation because I believe that the current law has not been adequately tested in any way. In fact, if we analyse it there has been no testing of the current law at all. Fourthly, when I made the comments on capital gains tax I pointed out quite clearly that I am worried that this will set a precedent for future legislation by either a Liberal or a Labor government. Legislation by a Labor government based on this precedent really sends shivers down my back. I am completely scared of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't know why.
—You are not guilty, are you?

—Those interjections are typical of the hysteria surrounding this debate. It is necessary that I clarify a few points. This debate has a degree of hysteria and a degree of panic in it. Some of the accusations that are being thrown around are very unjust. It is necessary in that case to outline and justify my situation. It should not be necessary in a Parliament such as this for Opposition or Government members to attribute to honourable members improper motives for their comments or views. In 1978 I voted against a previous retrospective taxation legislation to outlaw Curran schemes. I was one of six who voted against it, so I am completely consistent. I have no truck with tax evaders at all. In fact, if honourable members check with the Treasurer (Mr Howard) they will learn that I have forwarded details of three or four schemes of evasion and avoidance to the Treasurer so that action could be taken. I support very strongly the efforts the Government has made without introducing retrospective legislation to counter tax evasion schemes. The record of the Government in this area has been quite good and I have supported it. I cannot support retrospective taxation legislation for the reasons I have given. It is unjust that we have a degree of hysteria in this debate. It should not be necessary to explain one's views or say that one is not associated with, paid by or a confederate of any tax evasion firm.

SPEECH.PARA: Some comments have unfortunately been made by both the Treasurer and to an extent by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) suggesting that the legislation is not retrospective. I cannot go along with that at all. In a report in the Australian Financial Review of 26 July 1982 the Treasurer, in referring to this legislation, is quoted as saying:
It is not retrospective in that it does not create a tax liability for the first time. The liability was always there but the tax has never been paid.

A Press release by the Acting Attorney-General (Mr N.A. Brown) on 12 October stated that if it was retrospective it was only a teeny bit retrospective. I cannot go along with that in any way at all. I prefer to take the view expressed by a Queen's Counsel from Western Australia, Ian Temby, who was a Labor candidate in a recent by-election. He stated:

What the Treasurer announced late last month is not legislation having retrospective effect to the date of the announcement, but rather truly ex post facto legislation: persons will become liable to pay tax on the basis of acts which when performed did not attract taxation consequences. Furthermore, and this is true however hard the press release tries to gloss over the fact, it will create a new liability. The individual shareholders were never under a possible liability in relation to the taxation obligations of limited liability companies in which they held shares. Now they are to become liable.

There is a new debt and a new taxation liability created where they did not exist before. In that respect the legislation is truly retrospective. I agree with Mr Temby's remarks in respect of the legislation. Let me say that when I was elected to this Parliament I supported fully the platform of the Liberal Party. Let me just quote several aspects of that platform in relation to taxation. Since we are not permitted now to have certain material incorporated in Hansard-I would have had this whole section incorporated-I just pick out several sections. The platform states:
5. The rights of the taxpayer are guarded by
(d) ensuring that taxation adjustments do not have retrospective effects.
We then go on in the Liberal Party policy platform to say:
9. Taxation avoidance schemes will be eliminated.
10. Tax evasion is a crime and will not be tolerated.

I think this very clearly shows the genuine platform of the Liberal Party in this matter. It disturbs me that people are now saying that this is a once-only effort, that we can forget our platform this time, that we can forget our philosophy this time. Let us not forget-the National Party would have done well to remember this at its recent conference-that this is not the first time we have legislated for retrospectivity. The first time was in 1978 with the Curran scheme when we legislated retrospectively in relation to taxation. So this is not a once-only thing; it is a second performance of such legislation. There is no way in which we can say that this is a once-only effect; this is the second time; we are making a habit of it. If Labor got into government, God forbid, it would make an even greater habit of it. We will be the ones to blame. We will have no justifiable philosophical opposition to the Labor Party's actions in that regard. Members of the Labor Party spelt out quite clearly not only in 1978 but also today that they will do this. We Liberals have fallen for the trap. We have made it easier for them. All our excuses cannot say otherwise.

I think the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) spoke very clearly on several aspects that I wanted to speak on including the certainty of law and the effect of retrospective legislation in that it imposes uncertainty for business planning and business investment decisions. How can anyone in an entrepreneurial or business situation be expected to anticipate the decisions of governments in, for example, 10 years' time? It is quite unreasonable. It is completely against the whole concept of our coalition parties' views on the free enterprise economy.

The other point that I wanted to speak on very briefly, because we are limited in the time that we can speak, is the fact that current law has not been tested. The report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union which has been referred to tonight ad nauseam and a number of other prominent legal authorities have pointed out that the current law is adequate to meet these cases where fraud is involved. We are told by a number of Press releases that in this legislation we are dealing with fraud . I believe that the Government has not tried to use the current law in any way. The previous speaker from this side of the House, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), mentioned in detail a number of aspects of the law that could have been used but which have not been used. Basically this comes down to conspiracy, which is dealt with in the Crimes Act, provisions in the current income tax laws and the Companies Act. There has been no attempt to use that legislation in any way. If fraud is the trigger for this legislation, as the Government maintains, fraud obviously is a criminal offence and can be punished under current law.

Just the other day the Treasurer admitted that even for the Curran scheme retrospective legislation may not have been necessary. He pointed out that under the then existing law some of those offenders were being successfully prosecuted . If there had been more effort I am sure that more prosecutions could have been successful. I just mention as an example the Gold Coast area where some 4,000 files were recently seized under current legislation-not this legislation. There had to be justification for this action. Those files were seized under section 10 of the Crimes Act. This was done by a reference to the current law, not to retrospective law. I am sorry that this Government and the bureaucracy which it controls have not had the resolve, the energy or the drive to prosecute in these areas of fraud and criminal intent. For this reason I would have thought that one of the gravest tests that a non-socialist government would apply to legislation such as this is whether the current law was deficient. In no way have we tested and proved that the current law is deficient. That would be an absolute necessity, I feel, for an argument for retrospective tax legislation.

In summary, because the 10 minutes I have to speak is up, let me reiterate that I am opposed to the legislation; I am opposed to the amendment moved by the Opposition. I am disturbed that the Government has not acted much more strongly in the past on these actions. To that extent I can support some of the less colourful statements made by the Opposition. I feel that action should have been taken. It was necessary that the current law be tested before we even contemplated a law as repugnant as the one we are now proposing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel it appropriate in this debate on the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2] and associated Bills for the House to hear now from an honourable member who will support the legislation, even though the Australian Labor Party supports it with many reservations and intends to press a number of amendments. I draw the attention of the House, particularly Government members, to a comment made by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his second reading speech. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The only tax to be recovered under the legislation is tax that was legally payable, and the payment of which has been illegally evaded. This follows from the provisions in the legislation that make recoupment tax payable only where company tax legally payable remains unpaid, former owners having had the opportunity to contest the Commissioner's contention that company tax is payable .

I have listened to Government speaker after Government speaker attacking the legislation. I was astounded that the last speaker, the honourable member for Canning (Mr Bungey), said that the retrospective legislation, as he calls it, is unnecessary. On the Government's own assessment, this legislation will bring in $580m of fraudulently unpaid company tax. I think of what this money could do for Western Australia, for some of the Aboriginal fringe dwellers suffering from leprosy who I saw. I think of what this money could do for some of the schools in the Kimberleys, Broome and Turkey Creek that I visited during the parliamentary winter recess-those very depressed places in Western Australia. I think of what $580m could do to assist the lot of these Australians living in the twilight zone, these people who are very poor and very disadvantaged. I am appalled that Government members could say that the legislation is unnecessary. I feel that they are totally unable to comprehend that this money is owing. In their own Treasurer's words, the tax is legally payable at all times. The honourable member for Canning is distressed and has cold shivers about this precedent. He will not be in this House after the election. The Labor Party candidate, a very charming young women from Western Australia, will be representing that electorate. She will be a very competent member of this House.

The Treasurer's speech deals with the history of the tax avoidance scheme. He talks at length about the problems of whether a secretary is a shareholder in a company. I believe that the expression 'bottom-of-the-harbour' emanated from the problems in New South Wales with a certain Cabinet Minister named Arthur in the 1950s who was found to be involved with a promoter named Doyle. Doyle was promoting companies.

Apparently Mr Doyle was uncovered when his share scrip was found floating in Sydney Harbour. Twenty years ago, in the early 1960s, I was working for the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney. We were trying to recover many debts for the Australian Taxation Office. I remember one case of an entrepreneur bringing second-hand aeroplanes into this country-history repeats itself-selling these aeroplanes and avoiding tax by transferring the directorships of his company to an office secretary. Vast sums of money were owing to the Commissioner of Taxation at that time, yet only now has the Commissioner, through the Treasurer, bestirred himself to act to stop this loss of revenue to the Treasury, this stealing of money owing to the nation. That is the only way it can be put. In the legislation the Treasurer has somehow tried to accommodate people such as office secretaries who find themselves running a company, but these people have to follow a rather convoluted, involved procedure. An application must be made to the Federal Court of Australia seeking a declaration that the person is not in the promoter class but is really only a simple soul who signed the documents and became a director of the company and, therefore, should not really accept any liability.

This whole sad saga of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes is unfolding in the House today. It has disclosed a terrible trail of sadness, misfortune and financial distress which is just starting. From personal contact I know how distressed and disillusioned are the staff in the Commonwealth Attorney-General' s Department. I know that the people in this Department who are hard-working officers were stunned by the revelations of the Costigan report. They have borne the brunt of many jokes since and they have lost heart. Their spirit has been destroyed. Basically, the reason for this loss of heart has been the policy of the Liberal-National Party Government, which has been in power in Australia since 1975, to cut the numbers in the Public Service, to emasculate the great Australian Public Service so that it cannot perform its job. This Government has been seen to be incapable of handling the situation in the case of those government departments.

In the Perth office there is a very serious inference that this situation was not caused just by a shortage of numbers but that there is some other explanation, of a corrupt nature or otherwise, or one involving political influence. I believe that many people will be finacially destroyed by this whole exercise. Vendors-shareholders will sue their accountants and the people who gave them advice. There will be cross-actions, court proceedings and bankruptcies. In my opinion, the whole scenario is a most distressing one which will go on for years. I believe that in the wash up, very little of this $580m the Treasurer is talking about will be recouped.

One aspect of this legislation and of this whole bottom-of-the-harbour scandal that concerns me is the failure of the Commissioner of Taxation anywhere in his many reports to Parliament year after year to refer to the problems he was having with the Perth office of the Deputy Crown Solicitor. There was $580m worth of stolen taxes involved. The brief sat in the bottom drawer of some officer in the Department for five years, but never once did the Commissioner inform Parliament. Parliament is the highest court in the land. If Parliament is not told that all is not well in the office of the Commissioner of Taxation and in the office of the Commissioner's solicitor, that is a very sad indictment of this Parliament and what we are all doing here. We are wasting our time if senior public servants, the senior men advising the Treasurer, and the Treasurer do not inform Parliament of what is happening with the collection of company tax in this nation.

The Commissioner of Taxation may have been exonerated by Mr Costigan but he has not been exonerated in my opinion. He has pursued and hounded small taxpayers, school teachers and people with petty claims. He has forced these people to go through extraordinary procedures to lodge appeals, and there have been years and years of delay before appeals have been heard. Yet the Commissioner of Taxation has not reported to Parliament. He did not have to give details of promoters or of people involved in tax evasion. I believe he is hiding very skimpily behind section 16, which he claims prevented him from disclosing just what was going on in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Western Australia and in regard to the evasion of company tax.

The Parliament would never have heard of this whole sorry saga if it were not for the Costigan report. The Costigan report was meant to tip a bucket on the Australian Labor Party. It was the bright idea of the Federal Liberal-National Party Ministry and it totally backfired. Unfortunately, the report came along at the same time as the Lafranchi report and it showed just what disarray the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth was in. The most incredible story went around the world. People could not believe what had happened in the DCS Office in Perth. After all this, I believe Parliament should be more serious in its attempts to scrutinise what is occuring in the Public Service. The fact that this matter was never revealed to this House is, I believe, shameful. I believe that all members of this House must take cognisance of the fact that the Commissioner of Taxation could go on, year in and year out, failing to tell the House of this appalling evasion and of the fact that he could get no action out of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office. The matter was allowed to float on year after year, and nothing was done about it. This is a most serious aspect of this whole sorry saga.

The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) talked about the rule of law, and he can be excused for getting this whole matter mixed up. The Treasurer has said that the taxes are owing and they are the only taxes that are being recovered. I put it to the honourable member for Tangney: Were these the actions of a prudent businessman or businesswoman? Were these the acts of conscientious accountants? Were they the acts of the family solicitor? Would the family solicitor advise a family with a company to destroy its documents? Is this what the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia tells its members to do-to burn the documents , to put them in the bottom-of-the-harbour, to destroy them? If that is what those people do our nation is in a very serious situation. Are these the acts of the wise, small entrepreneur, the small business people who form the backbone of our nation, the people who employ most of the labour in this country? I do not believe they are. I believe that these people are scandalised by what they read about bottom-of-the-harbour schemes and the millions of dollars that have been taken out of the economy.

When all the inquiries are completed I am sure we will find that nearly $1,000m has been taken out of the economy. I very much regret that only a very small amount of this money which has been stolen from the taxpayers will ever be recouped. I trust that after all this the accountants will look at their ethics. Countenancing the destruction of company records is an illegal act in itself. Provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act state that records must be retained for a certain number of years. I am sure there are similar provisions in the companies Acts in all States. It is a tragic situation that accountants coldly advise clients to go along their way merrily destroying documents, destroying all tax returns and tax records, so as to take part in one of these appalling schemes of tax evasion.

I come to the matter of the recovery of $580m. I put it to the House that many of the people involved may well be dead. Many of them may well be overseas. I note that in the Bill the Government has set out all sorts of schemes for joining people and has made provision for joint and several liability. There is also a provision for time to pay. There is an incredible loophole in the whole scheme. The Treasurer has been forced by his recalcitrant back bench to introduce this notion that the recoupment legislation will not apply where there was a pre-sale avoidance scheme which, though ultimately shown to be unsuccessful, might reasonably have been expected to have worked. This is quite an incredible loophole. It will cost taxpayers millions and millions of dollars. Nevertheless the Government has the task ahead of it of recovering this money.

I now get to the nub of my argument on recovery. We have an assurance that the taxpayer has the right to appeal. Any honourable member who has ever been involved, or who has had a constituent who has been involved, with the appeals system at work in this nation, appeals from decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation, is in for a surprise because the system has ground to a halt. It is clogged with appeals. It now takes years and years to get an appeal dealt with in the office of the Commissioner of Taxation or a Deputy Commissioner of Taxation. The number of staff in the office of the Commissioner of Taxation and all his State offices have been cut so much, particularly in the appeals sections, that it now takes up to two years to even have a file or an objection assessed. Objections, quite rightly, can be made by lodging a $2 fee. The procedure is that the objection to the assessment is heard before a board of review. The boards of review themselves are crying out in anguish; they cannot handle more appeals. They are totally overworked. No costs are awarded so it is an encouragement-and it should be-to the taxpayer to try his or her luck before the Board of Review.

Most of the cases dealt with by the Board, as published in tax cases and all the other taxation journals in this country, deal with small claims. A lot of them seem to eminate from teachers who say that part of a room was their study. A lot of claims relate to public servants and professional people who have gone on overseas trips. A number even emanate from members of Parliament in relation to election expenses. The people-I might even say the unfortunate dupes-who have gone into bottom-of-the-harbour schemes now have to go through this procedure of appealing; else they go to a supreme court or a federal court and lodge their appeal. Of course if they are objecting to an assessment in court they lose their anonymity; their names are published, their cover is blown, unfortunately. So most of them, I should imagine, would go to a board of review.

This Government has let the system of appeals to taxation boards of review grind to a halt. It has failed to ensure that this long established traditional system of appeals from decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation will work any longer. It just does not work. I have seen questions on notice by honourable members concerning the tragedy that is occurring before the boards of review in each State. If any taxpayer wishes to proceed with an appeal against a decision of the Commissioner of Taxation he is being denied justice. Justice must not only be done but be seen to be done. It was not done before a board of review for a very long time. The pay-as-you-earn taxpayer in particular has already paid the tax but he or she must wait possibly five years before a decision is made on that claim.

The Board of Review situation is one that worries me but I know that an insensitive government will do nothing about it. The policies of this Federal Government are the reasons why the Public Service, the boards of review in each State and taxation offices have come to such a sorry position. This Federal Government has cut staff ever since it came to office. It has some sort of churlish belief that public servants must work harder. My experience is that senior public servants work very hard. They earn their pay; they carry their load;. they have the responsibility and they are conscientious. One cannot run any business or undertaking, particularly something like the Australian Public Service, by cutting staff.

The essence of the prosecution in Western Australia in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office, and the essence of any prosecution under any Federal or State Act, is that it must take place quickly. Many Acts of Parliament have a statute of limitation written into them. One must launch a prosecution within six months or a year. I do not believe that the prosecution in the Perth Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office could have been allowed to remain in that bottom drawer for five years. It was not just litigation dreamily moving along; it was a prosecution. The Government and Treasury had senior counsel's advice that a prosecution should be launched. I cannot understand, with my experience working in the government and in private enterprise as a solicitor, how a prosecution can drag on. Germane to the whole matter is the fact that witnesses disappear, evidence disappears and people forget. I believe that we really have not got to the bottom of this whole question of what happened in the Deputy Crown Solicitor 's Office in Perth and how this matter was allowed to run on. Much good will come out of all this. I believe that many of the schemes directed at retired people for avoiding tax to get pensions will at least fail from now on. People will be aware that avoiding tax is a very risky business; that one just cannot avoid one's responsibilities by hoping for capital gain.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and Acting Attorney- General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Last week, the Government introduced the National Crimes Commission Bill. The Bill which I now introduce is a complementary measure directed to ensuring that royal commissions have effective powers and procedures so that they may carry out their important functions.

In its proposal for establishment of a National Crimes Commission, the Government of course did not have in mind doing away with royal commissions. Each type of body will have its special function and use. The primary purpose of the Crimes Commission will be to assemble the evidence for prosecutions in difficult cases of organised crimes and the like. By contrast, the basic purpose of a royal commission is to ascertain the facts as to a particular matter or matters and, where appropriate, make recommendations to Government for future action. However, as the Bill now before the House recognises, royal commissions can vary somewhat in objectives, and powers that may be appropriate for one royal commission may not be appropriate for another.

The Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ships Painters and Dockers Union-the Costigan Commission-in its Interim Report No. 4 made recommendations for certain amendments to the Royal Commissions Act. The first was that a royal commissioner should be empowered to issue a search warrant where he believes on reasonable grounds that a person has documents relevant to the terms of reference of the Commission and there is a reasonable likelihood of the destruction of the documents. The Commission pointed out that mere service of a subpoena to produce documents will, if the person has something to conceal, result in the destruction and non-production of documents. The subpoena, the Commission said, acts as a warning to such a person of the Commission's interest . The Government broadly accepts this recommendation subject to the qualification that the warrant should be granted by an independent judicial officer. It has also concluded that the application of the provision should be limited to royal commissions whose Letters Patent indicate an intention that the provision should apply. Proposed new section 4 so provides.

The next recommendation of Mr Costigan was that the procedures and remedies available to a royal commission to deal with witnesses who failed to attend or answer questions should be strengthened. Existing powers and penalties were, it was said, inadequate. Reference was made to the equivalent provisions of the Victorian Evidence Act. The Government again broadly accepts this recommendation . The procedures provided under proposed new section 6C for dealing with such witnesses are broadly based on this recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under this provision, a witness who fails to take an oath or answer questions may be referred to the Federal Court or the Supreme Court of a State or territory. That court may order the person to comply with the relevant requirement. Failure to comply would be punishable as contempt of court. However , these provisions will be limited to royal commissions with Letters Patent indicating that intention. In further consultations with Mr Costigan the need emerged to put beyond doubt the power of the Commission to communicate information and documents to a Special Prosecutor, the National Crimes Commission or Attorney-General of the Commonwealth, State or Northern Territory and law enforcement bodies generally. This doubt is removed by proposed new section 6P.

INTERJECT.PARA: Since 1912, section 6DD of the Act has rendered statements or disclosures by a witness before a royal Commission inadmissible in evidence against him in any criminal or civil proceedings in any court except proceedings for an offence against the Act. Because of the existence of this section, it was the view for many years that, on the proper construction of the Act, self-incrimination was not a lawful excuse for the failure of a witness to answer questions or produce documents. However, the decision of the High Court in Hammond v. The Commonwealth (1982) 56 ALJR 767 cast doubt on this construction although the majority formally reserved judgment on this point. The actual ground on which the majority of the Court granted an injunction restraining the Royal Commission in question from continuing its examination of Mr Hammond was that questions were being put to him by the Commission as to facts directly relevant to issues in criminal proceedings already commenced against him.

I must emphasise that the present Bill would not affect that ground or the result of any future similar proceedings but, given the fact that section 6DD protects a witness against use of evidence given by him to a commission in other proceedings and the need for a royal commission to establish the facts of a particular matter, the Government has concluded that the doubt as to the construction of the Act arising from the High Court decision should be removed and that it be made clear that, in the special circumstances of a royal commission hearing, self-incrimination is not an excuse for failure to answer questions or produce documents. I mention that the reverse is intended to apply under the National Crimes Commission Bill on the basis that the primary purpose of that Commission is to obtain evidence admissible in a court for a prosecution where appropriate. Thus, under the Bill self-incrimination is an available excuse-subject however to an indemnity having been given by the Attorney-General -and there is no prohibition on use in a court of the evidence obtained by the Crimes Commission.

A final feature of the present Bill is the provision made in proposed new section 7AA which is intended to remove doubt as to the capacity of a Commonwealth royal commission to accept powers and functions given to it by a State government in the form of a parallel commission. When special circumstances arise calling for the establishment of a royal commission to inquire into a particular matter, it is in the interests of the nation that the body should be clothed with all necessary powers and given effective procedures so that it can fulfill its important task expeditiously and effectively. The present Bill is directed to this end and the new powers and procedures provided under the Bill will greatly enhance the ability of royal commissions to discharge the many and varied functions for which they are established. I commend it to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FIFE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aviation and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

To assist the consideration of the Bill I might apprise the Committee of developments since the Bill was last considered by the House and the amendments moved by the Government and accepted by the Senate. The Public Service Acts Amendment Bill was first introduced in the Budget session last year. The Bill was the culmination of a number of projects undertaken to update the employment provisions in the Australian Public Service. The major changes proposed were to abolish divisional structure in the Public Service, revise the procedures for promotions and appeals, and revise arrangements for the recovery of outstanding debts from the salaries of public servants.

When the Bill was debated in the autumn session this year, the Government moved certain amendments to the Bill. These amendments were to provide a greater degree of autonomy to Parliament in determining its staffing arrangements- arising from the Jessop Committee report into the staffing of Parliament; to provide for the furnishing of reports giving reasons for decision in relation to promotion matters; and to provide for the dual appointment of permanent heads. During the winter recess the Public Service Board has had extensive consultations with the unions representing public servants. As a result of these consultations, and other developments to which I will come shortly, the Government has decided to move further amendments to the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill. These amendments were considered in the other place last night and the Bill as amended was passed.

Over the last few years there have been a number of court judgments which have affected the promotion and appeal processes in the Australian Public Service. Prior to the introduction of the Bill in the Budget session last year, there was an important judgment on a promotion appeals case which indicated that the established procedures of the Promotion Appeals Committee were deficient. The judgment cast appeal proceedings into an adversarial framework requiring a far greater degree of legal formality than the Government considered desirable. For this reason the Bill contained specific provisions which would have had the effect of allowing Promotions Appeals Committees to determine their own procedures and therefore continue with the less formal arrangements that had existed before the judgment.

Since the introduction of the Bill there have been a number of judgments which have stressed the importance of personnel management interests involved in the promotions appeal system. The effect of these later judgments has been to largely offset the effect of the earlier judgment. The Government, in the light of these developments and opposition from the unions, moved amendments to the Bill in the Senate to omit those provisions detailing the procedures to be followed by Promotions Appeal Committees. The amendments moved by the Government also delete from the Bill special provisions for the giving of reasons for decisions in relation to promotion decisions. These special provisions were inserted by amendments moved by the Government and passed in the House in the autumn session. They had the effect of replacing section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The Government was of the view that these provisions were necessary to protect the privacy of public servants involved in promotions and appeals. It was feared that the application of section 13 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act would have forced decision makers in the Public Service to reveal confidential information about other parties to a promotion or appeal to an applicant. This would have had detrimental effects on individuals as well as jeopardising harmonious working relationships in the Public Service. The effect of the recent judgments mentioned, as well as developments in the legal processes for providing reasons for decisions, has been to minimise the problems of privacy in providing reasons for decisions. The Government has therefore decided to delete those special provisions.

The Government amendments include a provision giving expression to the merit principle. This provision reflects the Government's commitment to promoting efficiency in the Service and concomitantly precluding patronage, favouritism and unjustified discrimination. This amendment originated from an Opposition amendment which was supported by the unions. As a result of the discussions between the Public Service Board and the unions the Government has included a number of amendments which I understand will remove the remaining points of possible contention. In the other place an amendment was accepted which will clarify the responsibility of the departments of Parliament in presenting annual reports. The Government recommends to the House that the amendments to the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill be accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill came before the House in February this year the Australian Labor Party had a long list of amendments. The debate was gagged before we had the opportunity to outline the reasons for our proposals and the Bill was rammed through in the most dismissive manner. I draw to the attention of honourable members the manner in which this legislation was rammed through this House. I can recall that the debate began at 12.30 one morning and that the Bill was passed through this House, with hundreds of amendments, in 20 minutes. This was an example of how the business of government should not be conducted. In sharp contrast is the way in which it was handled once it reached the Senate. The Government, for whatever reason, found itself in a position where it had to consult with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Public Service Board over the provisions of the Bill. By the time that consultation had finished the substance of all the amendments except one that we had proposed in the House had been accepted by the Government and they were included in amendments proposed by the Government in the Senate last night. We congratulate the Government on its good sense in this matter and suggest that this sort of co-operative approach might be a fruitful way for it to conduct its affairs in the Parliament in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: One matter which we and many members of the Public Service hoped would be included in this Bill was an anti-discrimination provision. This was not accepted by the Government. I personally am quite disappointed about that because there is no doubt-I hope that the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife) will acknowledge this in his reply-that a great problem with discrimination in the Public Service, particularly against women, exists today just as it has existed for years. I draw to his attention the Public Service Board's annual report for 1981-82. In that report the Board cites the employment figures for men and women in the various divisions in the Public Service. There are 28 First Division officers, all of whom are male; there are no women. In the Second Division there are 1,245 men and 27 women. TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT BILL 1982 [No. 2]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem about this debate on bottom-of-the- harbour schemes is that it creates a credibility gap of over four years. That is a pity because the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has taken some notable scalps in his tax avoidance battles. However, retrospective collection of avoided tax was not contemplated from the day the Treasurer was informed of these practices in 1978 until the publication of the McCabe-Lafranchi report this year. The consideration of the legislation is not just a question of having regard for a principle of opposing bad legislation that forever casts doubt on the rule of law and the fundamental certainty of commercial action. It must be studied in the light of the unbridled evasion of taxation by greedy individuals, of innocent people caught in the net of advice offered by taxation professionals and of the failure by Ministers to act upon advice offered to them by their advisers.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are that from 1974 to 1978 the Attorney-General's Department was quite incapable of safeguarding the interests of the Commonwealth by proceeding upon competent legal advice against those who evaded tax by fraud. Costigan has well documented those failings. He entitled a particular part of his interim report No. 4 'The Lamentable History of Non-Prosecution'. Because of the failure to prosecute it became accepted as fact by government that no case could be made against those involved in company stripping under existing law. Therefore the Commissioner of Taxation began his requests for new legislation to prevent bottom-of-the-harbour activities.

The Treasurer was informed of these matters in February 1978. He introduced remedial legislation in November 1980. It took 33 months from the date the Treasurer was first notified officially of the operation of straw companies until he introduced into Parliament legislation to suppress them. In all the voluminous documents tabled by the Treasurer there is no satisfactory answer for the delay. It took five months from the date of the publication of the McCabe- Lafranchi report by the Victorian Government on 27 May 1982, detailing publicly for the first time the extent of company stripping, for the Treasurer to get legislation into the Parliament. Obviously the entreaties of the Commissioner of Taxation over nearly three years warning of these practices robbing the pay-as- you-earn taxpayer had a painfully slow effect in prodding the conscience of the Government into action. Yet a short five months of public revelation and political attack were sufficient to galvanise the Government to act against its own principles to collect retrospectively that which it had previously not even thought worth collecting through 1978, 1979 and nearly all of 1980.

With the Commissioner of Taxation as the sire, the Treasurer's gestation period was 33 months. When McCabe-Lafranchi forced the issue, it took five months. The Costigan reports and the McCabe-Lafranchi tabulation of company stripping make doleful reading for the honest taxpayer. The repetitive evasion of huge taxation liabilities by well-known businessmen highlighted the attack on Commonwealth revenue. Costigan sheets the blame home to government, and his criticism rests not on the absence of the sort of law we have before us but on our failure to use the law which we already had. It is a strange and devastating fact that although these schemes were picked out in the early 1970s and the Treasurer, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) all refer to them as illegal, no case in law has been brought against the vendors or the promoters concerned in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. We cannot therefore assume that prosecution and recovery would be unsuccessful. The Treasurer himself confirmed this when he spoke in the House on 25 August. He said:

I would have to say that events may well prove Mr Costigan to be wrong because until such time as the validity of prosecutions under the pre-1980 law is tested by the courts of this country, who is to know whether Mr Costigan is wrong.

Since then we have enacted special legislations to set up the prosecutions under the pre-1980 law. It would be much better for the future certainty of the rule of law if we took the Costigan road first. The Government now wants to recreate the conditions of 1978 to enable it to remake its decision, but in setting out retrospectively to alter the law it does not intend to give those affected by it the chance to alter their decisions. We must consider also innocent people who may be caught by this legislation. It would seem that those who sold a company with its tax unpaid before the end of the financial year may simply be involved in a lottery. If losses were injected into the company after the sale all will be well. If it was stripped they will have to pay up. Their responsibility is determined by action taken by the purchaser after the vendor had severed all connection with the company.

I happen to have a constituent in this position, and although it would have been difficult to match losses with the company he sold by the year 1977 that is what he believed would happen. With this legislation in prospect he does not know whether he will be liable because he does not know what happened to the company he previously owned except that it was liquidated some years later. In fact, a leading accountant told me that he thought the promoters had a legal way of handling the current year profits they purchased. He said: 'If I was unaware of their methods, how would a businessman off the street know the position?' Just last week I received a letter from a constituent who was a shareholder in Metro Industries Ltd. The question put to me was: 'Where do I stand?' It is on this point that the Government's position is somewhat hypocritical. Many people are involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes because they were advised by experts. Yet this is the advice that the Government offers in a publication headed 'Taxation-Managing the Small Business', Series No. 16. This publication, which is currently in the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops, contains advice on taxation matters. It states:

Most businessmen do not have the expertise to carry out the complete accounting and taxation functions which are an integral part of their business activities. Even those who are proficient in accountancy frequently find that it is better to place the preparation of final accounts and taxation returns in the hands of specialists.

That is the advice which the Government gives to the small businessman. Apparently we now qualify that advice and our attitude by saying in this Bill: ' The advice we may have advised you to get previously is no longer the advice we now would have you accept'. I again refer in passing to the current advice to the small businessmen from this Government which is to put their affairs in the hands of professionals.

This Bill is retrospective not only in calling in back taxes. It is also obviously retrospective in a political sense. As documentation shows, pressure was building up, departmentally, at least by 1974. From 1978 it took nearly three years for the Treasurer to enact blocking legislation which, when passed, gave no indication that retrospective collection was in his mind. In fact, he gave no early warning signal that this would be the case at any time during his lengthy consideration of the issue. If he had made a positional statement of intent in 1978 he would most likely have undercut the major throughput of the schemes before they peaked. Those still operating from that time until 1980 would have been quite legitimately subject to tax.

The absence of such a declaration and the inaction during all of 1981 and the early part of this year confirm beyond reasonable doubt that there was no intention to proceed as we are now until political pressure was assessed as being utterly compelling in its urgency. In this way, therefore, it is easy to recognise that we are following Labor's policy. The Bill is here because Labor forced the issue, and it will pass because of its coalition with the Government. The Australian Labor Party gloats at the prospect of legitimising its future retrospective actions, while we run along in fear behind it. Because of a partial retreat, a sharp distinction has been drawn between dry and wet Slutzkin schemes; yet it is difficult to see the difference in terms of morality in relation to the payment of tax avoided. The principal difference seems to be in the quantity of tax avoided.

In the wet scheme no tax was paid on current year profits. In fact, the companies were sold before the end of the financial year and had not yet been assessed for tax. The tax obligation passed to the new company owners. In the dry case company tax was paid but no personal tax was paid on dividends or on undistributed profits. The responsibility for the latter tax also passed to the new owner. Critics can therefore ask this question: 'If vendor-shareholders are made responsible for the fate of the company which has passed from their hands in the case of wet schemes, why are they not made responsible in the same way for the actions of the new owners in relation to dry schemes?' As a matter of fact I am pleased to be on all fours with my electorate committee on this issue. That committee, without any prompting from me, considered this matter at some length and regretted deeply the evasion and avoidance of taxation but said collectively with almost a unanimous voice-not quite, but almost unanimous-that we should not as a party destroy the certainty of the law by retrospectively collecting tax even though a large sum of money was involved. The committee prefers the Government to proceed in the case of any suspected fraud on the laws existing prior to 1980.

Some measure of positive direction will come out of the wrong turning respresented in this Bill. Firstly, from now on governments will be more diligent. Ministers will know they cannot ignore imperatives put to them by their senior advisers, and those who would cheat the system will know that they will always be subject to retribution. On the darker side, company structures are much less secure, political necessities may force retrospective alteration of previously valid law and individuals will know that they may be buffeted by decisions far removed from their own knowledge. On balance I prefer that those who acted fraudulently should be charged with those offences. I have no brief for them. I oppose this Bill as a desperate move boding ill for the future, put forward by men who found their consciences very late in the argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a nation all Australians are quite well aware now of the appalling extent of the tax avoidance industry in our country. Thanks to the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the Costigan report on the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the speeches of members of the Australian Labor Party in both Houses of Parliament, and thanks to the vigilance of our staff and the media, some of the leading villains in the tax avoidance industry have been exposed. The Australian Taxation Office now admits that at least 6,200 companies are involved in tax avoidance schemes, but even that figure is open to debate. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) puts at $530m the revenue lost due to these schemes, whereas some say it could be three times that amount. Whatever the correct figure is, it is till an incredible amount of money. It may well be lost to the Treasury for all times.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation (Upaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2], and the other Bills which are being debated cognately, recognise the phenomenal growth of the tax avoidance industry in Australia and attempt to do something about recouping tax owing. For that reason I applaud the Bills. However, the public must not be misled into thinking that the Bills are a cure-all for tax avoidance in this country-far from it. The Bills are grossly deficient in recouping hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes and in deterring tax avoiders from future indulgence in tax avoidance schemes. The Bills seek the payment of company taxes avoided through bottom-of-the-harbour schemes but they do not require payment of the individual income tax also avoided under them. These unpaid taxes amount to millions of dollars. Further, other tax avoidance schemes, amounting to hunderds of millions of dollars in lost revenue, are not included in these Bills.

Last weekend I received a phone call from a businessman in my electorate informing me that certain tyre companies have been avoiding paying sales tax on imported truck tyre cases. He claimed that the companies have made false representations on Customs and shipping forms, thus avoiding the taxes due on imported tyre cases. He also claimed that other tyre companies were avoiding paying taxes due by importing truck tyre cases through a central figure. I understand that the Taxation Office has caught up with one of the companies and has assessed that it owes the Taxation Office $1.3m in avoided taxes. The businessman also claimed that the company had offered to pay the Taxation Office $750,000 but it refused to accept that amount, saying that it wanted the full amount. If these accusations are true I expect the Treasurer to take immediate action to gauge the extent of this type of sales tax avoidance and stop the fraud continuing. Who knows how far-reaching the scheme is throughout Australia and in how many other capital cities in Australia this sort of fraudulent activity is taking place?

The innocence clause in these Bills makes a mockery of the attempt to reclaim unpaid tax. The clause was added due to pressure from Government back benchers who sinisterly oppose retrospective tax legislation. The clause includes the provision for a claim of innocence because of the intent to avoid rather than evade tax when entering an artificial scheme. The existence of this innocence clause will make the legislation unworkable and lead to protracted and expensive legal battles which will clog up our courts. Let me pre-empt those legal battles with some very elementary thinking. It seems to me that the intent of a criminal does not make any difference to the severity of the crime of theft, and that is what tax avoidance is. It is the theft of revenue rightfully owing to the Government, and indirectly it is theft from pay-as-you-earn wage and salary earners. A thief receives a fine. Fines and the cost of repayment of stolen articles will always exceed the value of the items stolen. However, there is no provision for penalties in these Bills except for late payment. The generous repayment arrangements of a 25 per cent deposit and 12 months to pay must surely seem one of the most attractive loan conditions these businessmen have ever seen .

In the most recent issue of the National Times there is an article which quizzes several leading businessmen on retrospective legislation. It is interesting to note the astute observation of Sir Keith Campbell of the Hooker Corporation Ltd. He points out that the tax evader has had the benefit of the tax money plus the opportunity of its investment value. However, he is asked to pay back only the avoided tax and even then he is given plenty of time in which to do so. Meanwhile, and without penalty, he has the use of the money owing to the Government. It is nothing short of an interest free loan with highly attractive conditions of repayment. If the repayment attracts penalties they are at the rate of only 20 per cent. That is not too much more than the normal interest rates we have today. I hardly feel that the repayment arrangements included in these Bills will make for a deterrent to tax avoiders.

It is obvious that with these arrangements tax avoidance in this country will continue. Unfortunately, it will continue unchecked. That is a further enticement to the tax avoiders and an encouragement to continue their practices. Tax avoidance will continue unchecked because of the staff ceilings in the Taxation Office and the Australian Federal Police. The razor gang wrongly recommended that staff in the Taxation Office be reduced. The number of staff was reduced by 167. Most of those who lost their jobs because of the dreadfully misguided and false economies of the razor gang cut-backs came from the tax avoidance area of the Taxation Office. Each of those sacked from the avoidance area was responsible for the reclamation of $500,000 a year in unpaid taxes. The result of that staff cut has been the cancerous growth of tax avoidance in unprecedented proportions.

Royal commissioners Costigan and Woodward have both complained of the staff ceiling levels and training standards of the Federal Police. They have also indicated that staffing and training deficiencies have led to investigations being seriously and adversely affected. It is therefore obvious that, unless the Taxation Office and Federal Police staffing levels are increased, tax avoidance will continue to flourish. It will be the aim of a Labor Government to increase staff ceilings in these areas to make avoidance investigations more effective. Under these Bills tax avoiders who are caught will be able to debate their innocent intent in the courts or plead guilty and pay back their taxes without penalty and with the benefit of the use of that money. I support the amendments which oppose these favourable repayment arrangements and legislate against all tax avoidance schemes rather than merely elements of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hyde Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will endeavour to be brief. The issue before the House is complex. I believe that very few people could reasonably see it in black and white terms. I regret that the legislation has been introduced as quickly as it has. The time required to get such a difficult matter straight is more than we have had. It is more important to get it right than get it fast. The Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2] is retrospective and, as such, it offends the principle of certainty before the law. To that extent I agree with the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) and the honourable member for Eden- Monaro (Mr Sainsbury), with whom I agree on most matters. However, I part from them on two points. First of all, I believe that the proscription against retrospectivity is a proscription against penalty applied retrospectively. It depends on the imposition of penalty not merely on the fact that it is retrospective. I will come back to that. The other matter with which I disagree is that I believe that the prohibition of retrospectivity is not the only principle that a parliament must take into account. There ought not be a penalty . In my judgment this Bill should merely recoup those moneys that have been received by a person. Whether that person knew that those moneys had been received is not the issue that worries me most. It is whether that person did or did not receive them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before the House worries me in that, as far as vendor-shareholders are concerned, it goes some way beyond the point of recoupment and some way beyond the benefit received in that it charges to the vendor-shareholders the whole amount of the tax owing by the company that was later stripped though they would not normally have received that whole amount. So to some extent, in the case of vendor-shareholders, this legislation goes beyond recoupment. To that extent I have a reservation about the Bill. The Bill before the House-although I am hopeful that there may be changes to it-certainly goes much beyond recoupment in respect of some classes of people who are collectively referred to as promoters. Not all the people involved in promotion were involved in company stripping and not all the people who were in that chain knew all the steps further down the chain. Of course many did. A distinction needs to be drawn.

I believe, for another reason, that penalty ought not be inflicted. I have discussed the issue of justice. A penalty ought not be inflicted because we need a bulwark from which to defend the principle of the rule of law in future. It is an important principle. I think some rather extravagant things have been said, condemning those who have spoken entirely from this principle. As far as the arguments of those who spoke from this principle went, in my judgment they were right. But that is a question of judgment.
