However, if we impose a penalty, where do we then draw our line? What will be our bulwark against indiscriminate abuse of certainty before the law? In my judgment, this or any other legislation ought not go any further than to recover those benefits that have been received. That is an important underlying principle that ought not be offended.

The question of guilt or innocence does not arise. This is a tax Bill. The loose language that has been used by Opposition speakers and Government speakers in this Parliament and outside it impugning people's motives is unnecessary and damaging.

TALK.START.PARA: —But correct.

—The honourable member is in no position to assert that it is correct. In some cases it may well be correct. However, that is the sort of thing that a court of law, not a star chamber, must decide. The use of the word 'un- Australian' worries me. It reminds me of the use of the word 'un-American' at the height of McCarthyism in the United States of America. At that time communism was a threat to the free world, as it is today. What Senator McCarthy sought to do was, in my judgment, right. The methods he used, in my judgment, were very wrong. The same applies in respect of this legislation. Those people, on either side of the House, who make loose remarks about other people's motives and moral standing are, in my judgment, committing the same offence and offending the same principles that Senator McCarthy committed and offended in the United States. It is wrong and the method used does matter. People's motives are not matters that ought be brought into question by this legislation. This legislation is a taxing Bill, which is designed to recoup moneys that in my view should be recouped. But I object strongly to slanderous attacks on people's reputations. I object to them strongly when people are named, as they have been in this House, or when attacks have been made in general terms as they have been made outside this House. It is the same offence that Senator McCarthy committed in the United States, and it is wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: There will not be the vast sums saved that some people suggest will be saved through this legislation. Nonetheless the sum is appreciable-possibly about one per cent of the total taxes raised by the Commonwealth Government. The important thing about the legislation is that it will place the tax laws in a position where they are seen to be fair so that much money that is now being lost to the revenue through petty evasion-the cash economy surely involves more vast losses than were ever involved in sophisticated avoidance arrangements-will be paid. I think that is very important. The legislation is protecting the whole tax base. That is what it is all about. It is putting in place an appreciation of fairness that will stand well by the whole tax system.

I turn now to the cause of draconian tax laws. The cause is excessive, wasteful expenditure, and let no one forget that. I have sympathy with those people who have constantly criticised governments for their waste of money and who now find this legislation offensive. I have considerable sympathy for them. I do not agree with them but I have a lot of sympathy for their position. I have no sympathy at all for those profligate, big spenders who would now take away the Government's tax base. I think we should distinguish between the two groups. People such as the honourable member for Tangney and the honourable member for Eden-Monaro have mounted an argument with which I disagree. But it is an argument from principle that needs to be taken seriously. It needs to be remembered because the principles it enunciates are important to the whole system of government from here on as they have been in the past.

The tax revolt is brought about by perceived waste and by too much reliance on the income tax base. I draw the attention of Opposition members to the fact that we rely so heavily on the income tax base that a tax revolt is almost inevitable . If we are not able to broaden the tax base in the one area on which it can reasonably be broadened-that is, to tax the transfer of goods and services in the community; a sales tax or a retail turnover tax-we will face a reliance on a single tax base that cannot be sustained. Finally, there is the question of legislated loopholes such as films, gold and tax averaging for farmers-the sorts of things that are placed in the legislation deliberately. Those are the things that reflect badly on the Parliament because they were put there deliberately. Let us get this legislation through. Having done that, let us bend our minds to cleaning up the tax Act itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has moved an amendment to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2] 1982 which I support. Of course we would not have had the present Bill before the House if it had not been for the revelations of the McCabe-Lafranchi report to the Victorian State Government and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Since the beginning of 1978 the Commissioner of Taxation has been urging the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to take action. However, because of pressure from influential supporters, officials and parliamentary members of the Liberal Party the Treasurer did nothing and allowed one of the biggest and most scandalous examples of government maladministration since Federation to occur. One has to study the philosophy and morality of the Liberal Party of Australia to understand why the Treasurer and other members of the Government procrastinated on the matter for so long. Their philosophy is one which extolls the virtues of the financier, the money persons, the person who, with a stroke of genius, buys and sells companies which represent the accumulated profits of working people. The capital tax free profits they gain amount to hundreds of thousands of dollars, in some more notorious cases, amount to millions of dollars. This buying and selling of companies is of course a legal activity. The capital gains acruing to the financier are quite legal. There is unfortunately no capital gains tax involved and, providing company taxes and profits taxes have been paid, the financier is not involved in anything illegal. In fact, some of these people have been depicted as the heroes of our society, as great captains of industry, when, in fact, what they really represent is wealth and power of the most obscene kind.
—They get knighthoods for it.

—That is right. As the honourable member has indicated, they get knighthoods. It is but a small step for the less scrupulous of these financiers to look into ways and means of avoiding and evading their taxes. These people resent the intrusion of government into their financial affairs. Members on the Government side of the House espouse the cause of small government, or preferably no government regulation at all. Why should the Federal Government be slugging them from company taxes, dividend taxes and sales taxes? Is it not rightfully theirs? Did they not earn it by the sweat of their brow? Or at least they instructed somebody else to earn it for them with the sweat of their brow. So there has developed a new brand of creature, a hybrid of the financier, called a promoter whose ingenuity was turned towards clever schemes of tax avoidance and evasion. These promoters were aided and abetted in their bottom-of -the-harbour schemes by the views of the High Court of Australia under the leadership of Sir Garfield Barwick. This is the same man-
—Who?

—Sir Garfield Barwick. Honourable members will remember him. This is the same man who advised Sir John Kerr and the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to dismiss a government in an infamous legal coup. Not only did he use his influence to obtain a dismissal of the legitimate government, but he was also prepared to aid and abet people who tried to avoid their financial liabilities to society.
—Rubbish!

—I quite agree with the honourable member. This learned judge made it quite clear in various judgments that so far as he was concerned all potential taxpayers had the right to so arrange their financial affairs that they minimised their tax liability. The promoters needed no further encouragement and , legitimised by the 1977 High Court decision, dividend stripping schemes known as dry Slutzkin schemes multiplied. Selling off a company to a promoter in a way in which, whilst company tax was paid, the payment of any dividend tax was avoided, was not good enough. Both vendor-shareholders and promoters became greedy and developed the wet Slutzkin schemes involving the avoidance of both company tax and dividend tax. I am not going to detail exactly how these schemes worked because it would take up my time. My colleagues on this side of the House have already explained the sometimes rather complicated steps involved in tax avoidance and evasion.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make is that many members on the Government side of the House do not believe that any wrong-doing has been committed in the case of dry Slutzkin schemes. They have also, even in the case of the more blatant schemes involving the avoidance of both company tax and dividend tax, attempted to argue that the vendor-shareholders who sell their company to the promoter are innocent . What nonsense this is! Do Government members really think that the average Australian who has paid pay-as-you-earn income tax for many years will accept such humbug? What about the miners from Wollongong who were here in Parliament House yesterday protesting at the loss of their jobs? Will they accept that humbug-that the shareholders are innocent? Of course they are not innocent. Australians will not accept that because they know that when these vendor- shareholders received a price for their shares in their company which was way above the normal market price, those shareholders must have suspected that something crooked was going on. Those shareholders must have known that they should be paying dividend tax or, in more blatant cases, company tax and dividend tax, and that the price they were receiving for their shares represented the unpaid taxes.

We had both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister hypocritically saying that some of these people are innocent because there was no tax liability when they sold their shares. In case there is some misunderstanding, I want to make it clear that I am not confused about the difference between dry Slutzkin and wet Slutzkin schemes. I realise that the former is considered legal according to the law of the High Court and that the latter is illegal. But one cannot get away from the fact that both schemes are immoral. It was a criminal attempt by shareholders to avoid their just taxation dues. The shareholders and promoters are equally guilty and should suffer the full weight of taxation law. The reason for the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) is to ensure that the shareholders who so many Government members consider are innocent pay the taxes which they knowingly and willingly avoided. Why should these people get away with it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they are in the Liberal Party.

—That is right; they are their friends. Why should these people get away with it when they received a price for their shares which was above the normal market value? Unfortunately it is not enough for legislation to be passed in the Parliament to recoup the taxes avoided by the friends of the Liberal Party. The Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was passed belatedly at the end of 1980. Since that time there has not been any prosecutions against these blatant tax offenders. Let me say that again-there have been no prosecutions against these blatant tax avoiders. The Government has had two years to prosecute. Why has it not taken action? I wonder how long it will take the Treasurer and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to ensure that there are prosecutions in relation to the present legislation?

SPEECH.PARA: Another hypocritical charge made by both the Treasurer and the Government members is that the 1972-1975 Labor Government failed to take action on tax avoidance when it was in power. Incidentally, with three elections in three years and a hostile Senate, was the Australian Labor Party Government really in power during that period? The truth is that tax avoidance and evasion during that period had only just begun to operate. It was only a shadow of the estimated $3,000m per annum which taxation experts have stated is the magnitude of the problem in the last financial year. The Government was aware of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes as far back as the beginning of 1978 and yet it has delayed taking action for five years. Such inaction is inexcusable but it is also indicative of the immoral activities of a government, many members of which have a sneaking regard for the shrewdness of the promoters of these schemes.

Although the ALP is not opposing the legislation, we consider that it is an inadequate response to the tax avoidance in bottom-of-the-habour schemes. The evaded company tax may be recouped, but what about the accumulated profits and sales taxes which have been evaded in many of these schemes? The Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2] is only a beginning and when the Labor Party wins government, which will be very shortly, we will ensure that these crooked tax avoiders and tax evaders make their just retribution to society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The history of this legislation goes back some four months to the release of the McCabe-Lafranchi report and subsequently the Costigan report on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. It appears from those reports that despite the many and positive actions taken by this Government to block loopholes which over the years have been discovered in the Income Tax Assessment Act, a further and more damaging tax evasion practice was being undertaken. The Costigan report outlines in detail the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Whilst I believe the report has many inaccuracies and in many respects is inadequate, I wish to quote from paragraph 3.93. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: From time to time there have been suggestions that there is something clever or novel about these types of schemes.
He was talking about the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The paragraph continues:

The truth is that they have been known to the law for many years and the law has developed the remedies for them. In the case of companies those remedies lie in the misfeasance proceedings. As long ago as 1820 it was determined that where directors improperly invest or pay away companies' monies they are liable in misfeasance and that has been re-affirmed many times over the last one hundred years.

So says Costigan. Despite this advice the Government believes, presumably on the basis that such action as proposed by Costigan may not be successful and in any event would involve a long and arduous process through the courts, that legislation is therefore needed to recover the outstanding tax more rapidly. This legislation is the means whereby that goal is to be achieved through the mechanism of a recoupment tax.

The object of the legislation is to recover evaded company tax from the principal beneficiaries of the earlier evasions. The legislation is to operate on untaxed profits which were stripped from companies between 1 January 1972 and 4 December 1980 when the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was implemented to overcome this and other tax evasion practices.

Before dealing with the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2] in its retrospective effect I shall make a few comments dealing generally with the lead-up to this legislation. There is no doubt that many people, including me, felt justifiably incensed about those who had undertaken fraudulent activity to evade tax, thereby indirectly increasing the tax burden borne by the rest of the community. However, in the course of what became a rather heated and at times irrational debate, many others by inference or association were erroneously included in that group. At times the debate and some proposals for action appeared to be motivated more by a lynch mentality than a reasoned, rational and fair response. Accusations were made both inside and outside this place-I particularly refer to allegations made by the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Hayden) and a select number of his colleagues who have done irreparable damage to this institution by their crude, base, unfounded, Star Chamber-like tactics. They deserve the scorn and contempt which the community has heaped upon them.

I deal now with retrospectivity. I have often expressed my opposition to retrospectivity both in this place and outside. I well recall the Curran debate when the legislation affected only people who had entered into the scheme during that current financial year. It had the effect of putting them back into the position they were in before they entered the scheme. During that debate some argued on the basis of Lord Hailsham's views that 'a man cannot be punished or penalised for doing something which is lawful at the time it is done'. 'Penalise ' is defined in the Concise Oxford Dictionary as being 'to subject to penalty or comparative disadvantage'. In my view the Curran legislation put people back in the same financial year into the same position as the rest of the taxpayers and, in that respect, they were not disadvantaged.

There are many other reasons why in general I am against retrospective legislation. Of course, those reasons include my belief that people are entitled to certainty as to the state of the law. Unfortunately, my views are not shared by the members of the Opposition, who have repeatedly stated that they would have no reservation in enacting retrospective legislation in circumstances which I believe to be abhorrent. Given the stated intention of the Government to legislate retrospectively and the Opposition's support for that action, my purpose has been to endeavour to ensure, in respect of vendors, that those caught by the legislation are only those who benefited from the scheme and that the subject sale was made without appropriate inquiry and without reasonable and appropriate arrangements being made to ensure that the subject company's liability would be met. I have also tried to ensure that in line with the company tax liability now imposed on vendors they ought to have similar rights under the Income Tax Assessment Act to those they would have had if they had continued to own the company. This is why I have recommended and supported many changes to the Bills. I would like to thank my colleagues, especially the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and Cabinet, for their patience and flexibility in all but one or two matters. I believe we have a much better Bill as a result. For the members of the Opposition to criticise the changes merely indicates their irrational and emotional reaction and a complete lack of regard for natural justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —And their ignorance.

—And their ignorance; quite right. The Treasurer, in his statement to the House on 23 September when he introduced the original legislation, made it clear that a number of changes had been made. I believe they were substantial changes that went at least part way to making the legislation more acceptable. Firstly, I refer to the fact that the vendor-shareholder will now have an opportunity to contest the basic assessment of the company tax which is subject to recoupment. Clearly, after the vendor had sold his company he was not in a position to contest any tax liability which may have been assessed on that company. If we are to require him now to pay that tax it is essential that he be given the opportunity to contest that assessment if he so desires. Secondly, the penalties which have applied to the company tax which was payable some years ago by the purchaser will now not be incurred by the vendor who is subject to this recoupment tax but rather the obligation of the former owners to meet any penalty owing by the company will be measured from the date that would be the due date for payment if the company assessment had been served on the day that the copy of the notice of assessment is sent to the vendor-shareholders. Further , the Bill now provides that the service or reissue of a company assessment notice is to be served where possible on all former shareholders, not just one. Also, the special legislation will now not make vendors liable for tax incurred by the company in respect of lodgment of an incorrect return, a late-lodgment or a non-lodgment which would have been out of the control of the vendors.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer in his second reading speech to the amendment legislation also outlined some further welcome changes. Vendor-shareholders now have the opportunity of requesting a limited time to pay. Former owners are given the opportunity to pay the unpaid company tax in instalments over a period of up to 12 months, in which case they would not be liable for any late payment penalty nor would they be liable to pay the recoupment tax. I do not think there can be any criticism of the legislation in relation to those who have fraudulently evaded their tax liability. However, at the other end of the scale are those who entered into a legal avoidance arrangement. Both the original legislation and this amending legislation make it clear that those people will not be subjected to recoupment tax. The Treasurer has made it clear that the Government's intention has always been that the tax recouped under the legislation should be that tax that remains unpaid as a result of arrangements which have resulted in illegal evasion of tax. He has quite rightly pointed out that the legal authorities could not be seen to be part of an arrangement to leave the company unable to meet its tax liability and that they lack an element of fraud. The legislation has now been further extended to include a specific provision with the effect that, in the words of the Treasurer:

If the target company was the subject of a post-sale attempted avoidance scheme which, objectively viewed, would have had reasonable prospects of succeeding in its purpose, and the scheme is not part of the stripping arrangement so that the arrangement carried no purpose of rendering the company unable to pay, there will be no recoupment tax liability. In line with that, the recoupment legislation will also not apply where there was a pre-sale avoidance scheme which, though ultimately shown to be unsuccessful, might reasonably have been expected to have worked, if at the time of the sale the Commissioner had not raised an assessment rejecting the claims made under the scheme.

Again, I welcome the extension of the exclusions of the legislation to those two groups of people. This brings me to the point of concern I mentioned earlier. The legislation now quite rightly excludes vendor-shareholders who have sold their company to a purchaser who reduced by legal means the company's tax liability. The Bill does not exclude those who sold their company after making due inquiry to ensure that the purchaser was going to act within the law, had some means whereby he could legally use the company and that the tax would not be evaded. If, subsequently, the purchaser does not do as the vendor was led to believe, the vendor will be caught by this legislation. I intend to raise this matter together with some technical matters in relation to promoters at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) have been faced with an excruciating political dilemma. There is nothing they would have liked to have had more than an early election, with 25 September as the preferred date. But the revelations of the McCabe- Lafranchi report, followed by the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and its devastating evidence about bottom-of-the-harbour tax evasion schemes put paid to that. The December 1983 election was the least attractive option for the Prime Minister with the prospect of an economy out of control, massive unemployment, possibly of the order of 12 per cent to 15 per cent, high inflation and record interest rates. On that basis the Fraser Government would not just face defeat. It would face political annihilation-oblivion at the hands of the electors. So the Prime Minister felt compelled to adopt what appeared to be a 'get tough' policy on tax evasion. I say 'appeared to be' because it is clear that one can drive a coach and four through the present legislation currently before the House in its highly attenuated state, weakened as it has been by the attacks on it within the Liberal Party and by members of parliament in Western Australia, Queensland and Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: To have any hope of winning a 1982 election, the Prime Minister had to attempt to win back the votes of people who were on the pay-as-you-earn tax scheme-that is to say, the great majority of the electorate, the people whom the Slutzkinites of both wet and dry variety refer to so contemptuously as the 'mugs '. The people at the higher level of the income scale who made such a mockery of the concept of progressive payment of taxation are the people of whom Professor Russell Mathews said that the higher and higher up the income scale, the more voluntary the question of the payment of income tax appears to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or optional.

—Or optional, as the honourable member for Hawker says. The point is that to win back the votes of the mugs, the majority of people in the PAYE system, the Prime Minister had to adopt a very tough posture. Taking that tough position meant declaring war on the very people who in a number of States- particularly in Queensland and Western Australia-provide the sinews of war for the Liberal Party campaign chest. They are the kinds of friends the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) would know so well and for whom he has been such an effective bag man over the years in the Western Australian Liberal Party. The point was that getting tough in order to win the votes of the people on middle Australia meant that the Government lost the financial support of the Denis Horgans and their ilk who are very heavy contributors to the Liberal Party and who are also very important in the Liberal Party machine. They are very close to the--
—What about the painters and dockers?

—As the Victorian Secretary of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union pointed out, 95 per cent of the painters and dockers in Victoria vote Liberal. That statement is on record and I am sure that further evidence from Commissioner Costigan will abundantly confirm that. So the Prime Minister faced that dilemma. Even though there are not too many honourable members on the Government benches tonight who relish the prospect of an early election, the Prime Minister seems to be the one person in the Cabinet who still holds the view that he has no option, that he has to get out early with this legislation enacted. I believe the legislation will prove to be inadequate and, as I will mention in a few minutes, there will not be very much the Government can do to win back the votes of the electorate. I think it is already too late for the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that immediately comes to mind is that the whole question of getting tough with the people who have been the financial supporters of the Liberal Party really exposes the utter hollowness and hypocrisy of the Liberal Party line about its opposition to public funding of election campaigns. Good God, we have had it already! We have got it already. Where do honourable members think the money comes from to provide the Liberal Party's slush funds? The Liberal Party's slush funds have clearly come from money which should have been tax payments into revenue. The Liberal Party has simply left out the intermediate step of paying the money into the Treasury and bringing it out by way of public funding of elections. The money simply comes into Liberal Party coffers in lieu of any payment to taxation. We have had Liberal Party election bonanzas lavishly paid out of funds which never went into the Treasury's coffers . They were paid for out of ripped off slush funds.

The Prime Minister has a very narrow range of alternatives. Either he can go to the electorate now and face the virtual certainty of being done in by the electorate or he can wait on into 1983 and be done in by his own colleagues in the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party is a very unforgiving party when it sees the prospect of going down. Even the National Party is essentially more forgiving in its nature. We know that the Leader of the National Party always brings home his wounded. He does not leave them lying on the barbed wire in no- man's land. He drags them home no matter what condition they are in. That is not the same philosophy we find inside the Liberal Party. The result is that it is clear that the Prime Minister may take the view that if he is rejected in November like de Gaulle he can retire from the public scene for a while. He can retreat to Nareen-les-deux-Eglises and wait for the call of his people to bring him back again. But that call will never come. I think that whilst the principle of retrospectivity is not a principle we would like to see generally applied, it has always been regarded as exceptional in revenue cases. I will repeat the citation of the case the Treasurer referred to when he spoke in the debate on the Curran scheme. This has not been quoted so far in this debate. I will cite this in support of the position of honourable members opposite; so they should not look alarmed. I refer to the famous case of Howard de Walden v. Inland Revenue Commissioners and the judgment of Lord Greene, Master of the Rolls. Incidentally, for those who are listening on their crystal sets and want to look up the case, the citation is 1942 1KBD 389. Lord Greene said:

The section is a penal one, and its consequences, whatever they may be, are intended to be an effective deterrent which will put a stop to practices which the legislature considers to be against the public interest. For years a battle of manoeuvre has been waged between the legislature and those who are minded to throw the burden of taxation off their own shoulders on to those of their fellow subjects. In that battle the legislature has often been worsted by the skill, determination and resourcefulness of its opponents of whom the present appellant has not been the least successful. It would not shock us in the least to find that the legislature has determined to put an end to the struggle by imposing the severest of penalties. It scarcely lies in the mouth of the taxpayer who plays with fire to complain of burnt fingers.

The fact that the section has to some extent a retroactive effect again appears to us of no importance when it is realized that the legislation is a move in a long and fiercely contested battle with individuals who well understand the rigour of the contest.

One of the other factors, apart from the feebleness of the legislation before us , is the fact that clearly the Taxation Office is not well placed to exact what should have been paid by defaulting taxpayers. The structure of our administrative system in the Taxation Office is a shambles. I draw attention to the last report of the Commissioner of Taxation. I will not have time to read the relevant part in full. It pointed out not only that $973m of tax assessed remained uncollected because of administrative challenge but also that there was a shortfall in revenue due to tax avoidance schemes in 1980-81 which alone reached $310m. This is the significant point. The report states:

The number of experienced staff required to be allocated to the additional work of detecting, monitoring, investigating and contesting tax avoidance schemes continues to make serious inroads into resources available for other administrative functions.

The point was that the report shows that the total staff in the Taxation Office in June 1981 was 12,311, of whom 983 were investigating officers. The net cost of collection of income tax as a percentage of income tax revenue collected was 0.87 per cent, a decrease on previous years. In the current year income wage and salary earners paid 82 per cent of the individual income tax burden. Dr Paul Gerber, in a very important paper called 'The Functions and Procedures of Boards of Review' has pointed out the scandalous backlog of cases that exist within the Taxation Board of Review structure. I understand that in 1936 there were three Boards of Review in Australia. Now, 46 years later, there are still three Boards of Review. The population of Australia has increased three times, the number of people above the tax threshold has increased, say, 20 times, but the number of Boards of Review is exactly what it was 46 years ago.

This is a government which claims that it is serious in going out after the tax malefactor. The Treasurer, who is hastily beating a retreat from the chamber, is the head of the vigilante group, the head of the posse who never brings back the man. He goes out with his six-guns to find the people he is chasing but he never brings them back. He has a zero result in terms of scalps brought back. Dr Gerber's paper points out there are now very many thousands of backlog cases that have to be examined by the Taxation Board of Review. The period it is taking for them to be dealt with is many years. Members of the present Taxation Boards of Review have recently commented on the overcrowding of cases before the Boards. In 1981 over 24,000 cases were awaiting determination by the Board of Review. Dr Gerber also said that it appeared that Boards of Review had largely displaced the cinema as a form of popular entertainment and that since seats in the front stalls could still be purchased at pre-war prices, it was perhaps not surprising that there were queues three years long waiting to gain admission.

Let us say that the legislation is amended in the Committee stage and that it becomes a substantially stronger piece of legislation than what has been brought in by the Treasurer. We then say: 'It will be passed by the Senate tomorrow. It will be enacted by the Governor-General next week'. How long will it be before we can say that there has been an adequate clawback by the Taxation Office of the tax which is due to be collected as a result of the passing of the legislation? What kind of time lag are we thinking of? How long will it take to get the actual machinery operating?

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifteen years.
—Fifteen years, I hear a bid.
—Thirteen years.
—I think that the Minister is suggesting 30 years.
—He said thirteen years.

—If the Minister has a contribution to make we will all listen for it with bated breath. The Treasurer does not have a very long arm. I doubt whether the long arm stretches even as far as Tasmania or, as the Minister keeps calling it, the sovereign State of Tasmania. It may yet have to collect its own tax. The result is, we find, that the legislation is inadequate. I believe that the legislation has been introduced purely for the purpose of giving the Prime Minister something that looks more or less satisfactory on the surface until one starts to look at it. The horriying thing about the way this whole matter has been treated is that one realises how inadequate the whole clawback machinery of the Australian Taxation Office is. The feeble performance of the legal side of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office, certainly in Western Australia, may well be replicated in other States. That remains to be seen. It is scandalous that we have only the same number of boards of review as we had three years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point I want to make is simply that we realise when in talking to people in the Liberal Party how very deeply they are disturbed and how bitterly divided they are over the whole question of tax. One realises when one talks about money to the Liberals that one is talking about something very sacred, something which is very close to what they are all about. Talking to Liberals about money is like talking to pre-Vatican II Catholics about the Pope. It is a very sensitive subject that one does not joke about. The result is that the Prime Minister's feeble efforts in at least making some attempt to get into the tax dodgers who have occupied such an important role in Australia, who have denied the Australian people so much revenue, who have forced a very heavy burden on the ordinary taxpayer, people in the middle income group and even people in the lower income groups, have caused such bitter dissension within the party that we have a competely corrupted party, a corrupted government, and the sooner the election comes on the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to hear the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) talk about the Liberal Party's attitude towards money. The honourable member is well known for his $64m answers to $64 questions. That might have something to do with his past activities.
—I paid tax on it.

—I would not doubt that for a minute. The principles underlying this legislation and some of the Government's stated reasons for it have occasioned, to say the least, anxiety and concern amongst a great many law abiding Australians, not just the people who are likely to be directly affected but those who have an aversion to retrospectivity in any form. These Bills do not concern themselves just with those who have acted fraudulently. Indeed that is not necessary because fraud was at all material times a criminal offence and new legislation is not required to cope with criminal activity of that sort.

SPEECH.PARA: Fairness has been advanced as justification for these measures-fairness to other taxpayers who have not indulged in tax minimisation practices, having particular characteristics. Those practices which are distinguished by subsequent dividend stripping or destruction of company records by other than vendor-shareholders are to be legislated against. In this latter respect it should be noted that destruction of company records as a way to evade tax persisted for as long as it did and over such a period because those comparative few who promoted the schemes kept secret to themselves their illegal intentions and activities. If what they were doing had become generally known at the time it seems unlikely that promoters could have continued to attract customers. It is reasonable to assume that if there had been widespread knowledge of illegal dumping of records after ownership of companies had changed hands, many would have been advised by their lawyers and accountants not to sell their shares.

Alternatively, had the end result of the schemes been known at large, or to any more than the select few who had promoted them, many other unscrupulous individuals would have engaged in the same activity. The tax advantage which was attractive to vendor-shareholders was of course the motivating factor, just as the creation of income splitting devices, investment in films, contrived arrangements with certain charitable organisations, and many other legal tax minimisation schemes motivated others.

The targets of this legislation might be said to have had the misfortune to discover subsequently that they dealt with charlatans and frauds. Some of those who are responsible for this new tax may be said to be victims of the luck of the draw. I say this because it was the experience of some companies which sold more than one subsidiary to find out later that only a minor number of all subsidiaries sold were fraudulently dealt with by the purchasers of sub- purchasers. Had the great majority of vendors known the ultimate fate of their companies they may have opted for a tax minimisation arrangement specifically condoned by law, or any one of a number of other schemes which were not likely to put them in breach of any law. They may very well have chosen to do nothing if they even suspected that they may be contemplating an improper act.

This legislation proposes to erase the benefits of perfectly legal acts after the event, giving vendors no opportunity to rearrange their affairs to comply with the concept of fairness which is now proffered with the benefit of hindsight. Fairness must also surely demand consideration for people who have acted within the law. Until the contrary can be demonstrated, fair-minded people might assume that most of those likely to be taxed under this new law did not know and could not reasonably have anticipated that records of some companies would be later destroyed by the purchasers or subsequent owners, just as they could not possibly have foreseen that the Commonwealth would resort to retrospective legislation to recover from them the taxes unpaid as a result of the illegal acts of others. In short, retrospective law confers no opportunity for those affected to modify their behaviour.

To those who doubt that some people who acted innocently will be hurt by this legislation I simply say: If there are none, there will be no loss to revenue if a fairness or innocence clause is inserted by way of an amendment of the type I understand to be sponsored by my colleagues the honourable member for Tangney ( Mr Shack) and Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury). Nothing will be lost by presuming that there may have been vendor-shareholders who did not have any knowledge of the intention of purchasers or subsequent purchasers to act fraudulently. On the other hand, there is much to recommend the presumption of innocence until a guilty intent is proved. After all, that principle is enshrined in our common and criminal law. Speaking of criminal law, some of my constituents have said that provisions of this legislation are capable of imposing penalties in excess of those resulting from conviction of a criminal offence. They cite cases of promoters' agents or promoters' associates as defined in the Bill who may have conducted his or their business through a family company or trust. Not only can they be caught up in this but their wives and children are also assessable by virtue of their interest in the family company or trust. In some of these cases, and for a number of reasons, the family home will be lost. Even the families of convicted criminals are spared the loss of the family home.

Another matter confronting the agents or associates of promoters should be aired in this debate. Many associates or agents received commissions and fees from parties at or closer to the source of promotions. All have been assessed, or remain assessable, for income tax on that remuneration. Those who may have already paid 60c in the dollar can now confidently expect to pay another 20c in the dollar. In fact if the promoter cannot be found and tagged for his share, agents or associates will face a combined tax bill in excess of 100 per cent of the income they derived as a result of their involvement.

I touch now on another aspect of the Bill which deserves some passing comment. Reasons advanced by the Government in introducing this legislation indicate that those who 'benefited by the fraudulent evasion' practised by purchasers or subsequent purchasers can be required to pay the new tax calculated on income derived in a particular year of income up to the date the shares were sold. Vendor-shareholders were not the only ones to receive benefit from income derived, nor did they receive benefits equivalent to 100 per cent of that income earned. If fairness is integral to the reasons for this proposed law, the Bill's provisions should also recognise that promoters took their fee or commission and that the benefit derived by vendor-shareholders was reduced accordingly. The formula in the relevant sub-clause requires vendor-shareholders to now pay tax on the equivalent of 100 per cent of profits which will now be declared earned before the end of a given financial year. Plainly that assumed profit did not all find its way back into the pockets or bank accounts of vendor-shareholders. The promoters took their cut and this legislation may now tax vendor- shareholders on a benefit they did not receive, despite the avowed intention of the Government to take into account only benefits received by vendor- shareholders.

Having addressed remarks to some of the provisions in the Bill, I now turn to my basic reason for opposing this legislation. It stems from no sympathy for tax avoiders who have benefited, or may benefit in the future, from contrived or artificial schemes. It certainly does not relate to benefits which have accrued as a result of illegal acts. It has something to do with the Federal and State policies of my party which oppose retrospectivity. It also has something to do with extending the so-called recoupment beyond the stated intention of the Government. My opposition also has something to do with the penal aspects of the legislation. But overriding all the argument I have read and heard is my commitment to the need for community confidence in the certainty of the law; certainty that today's legal act does not tomorrow become the trigger for a penalty or obligation by law created subsequent to that legal act and applied retrospectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those who listened to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), could be forgiven for thinking that all of the tax strippers and those involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes were innocent. Our committee received a briefing from the Taxation Office. When officers from the Taxation Office were speaking to us it became very clear that those who took part in such schemes could not be innocent. This Government has become bigger than any government in our history. It takes more from ordinary people than ever before and gives less in return. Australian households stagger under the strain of the highest taxes and highest interest rates ever. The level of income tax revenue is proportionately one of the highest in the world and has grown dramatically in the last six years. This year income tax collections alone exceed all the taxes collected in the last year of the Whitlam Government, and that is without what we would have got but for the tax evasion. Real interest rates in Australia are the highest of any of the developed nations of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: As the fierce burden of the skyrocketing taxes and interest rates of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has increased, the living standards of ordinary hard-working Australian families have collapsed and the futures of many small businesses have been destroyed. For the average family to enjoy the same standard of living as six years ago would require an increase of nearly $20 a week in average weekly income. The Prime Minister promised small government and instead has created an insatiable monster. The same Government has been loth to proceed against the tax evaders whose activities have added to the burden carried by the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer. This Government was supposedly first made aware of the tax avoidance and tax evasion schemes at the beginning of 1978 . A decision was made later that year to enact new legislation against these schemes. That legislation, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, was passed at the end of 1980-after a two-year delay. Now, five years later, the Government is actually taking action. That delay is totally inexcusable.

During this period the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes mushroomed, causing huge revenue losses. The Government admits that up to $600m in lost taxes is involved although other estimates involve figures many times larger than this amount. The Government should either have proceeded with prosecutions to test the existing law or indicated, as soon as it was aware of these schemes, an intention to legislate against them back to the date of announcement. Huge amounts of tax remain unpaid. Only after the revelations of the extent of tax evaded contained in the McCabe-Lafranchi and Costigan reports was the Government forced by public pressure to act-or as one of the Government members said earlier, forced by the Australian Labor Party to act. I quote here from Bruce Pascoe, the President of the Taxation Institute of Australia, who in 1978 said:

During the past year or two, tax avoidance became big business in Australia. It became a disease which, being allowed to go unchecked, reached epidemic proportions. It is, perhaps, not going to far to say that the tax paying community in Australia almost went mad in its rush to become a party to a tax avoidance scheme.

Professor Russell Mathews, addressing the Australian Institute of Political Science summer school in January 1980, referred to the present ad hoc system of taxation which makes income tax 'a voluntary tax for the wealthy non-salary earner'. He said that the essential problem of our income tax system:
. . . is not to make the rich pay higher rates of tax, or even more tax than the poor: It is to make the rich pay any income tax at all.
The Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Bill O'Reilly, has consistently urged the outlawing of the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. An article in the Age states:
The timetable provided at the start of the 500-odd page book of documents tabled in Parliament yesterday-
That is, 22 September-
shows that Mr O'Reilly repeatedly provided the Treasurer, Mr Howard, with arguments in favour of new legislation.
As early as May 1978 he said that widespread tax evasion through straw companies merited 'very severe' laws.
In mid-1979, Mr O'Reilly said there were 900 defunct companies on Victorian registers. One-third of them represented a tax loss of $6m. Cases in other States were worth another $3.3m.
By October 1980, Mr O'Reilly-
He seems to have been fairly persistent-
was warning that tax losses had risen to $128m from 733 companies stripped by a Sydney promoter who worked on a 'production line' basis using a computer.
Still no legislation appeared, as the Government showed drafts to back benchers and the taxation advisory committee over more than a year.

Finally, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill passed through Parliament on 4 December 1980. One of the Government's speediest responses then took place: the bill received royal assent on the same evening.

Two years later I understand that only seven cases are pending under this legislation. I asked the Prime Minister in this House how many cases were proceeding. He promised to answer the question. I have since written to him about it but still have no answer so I am not even sure of the seven cases. I wish to read a little of the Commissioner's letter to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) dated 7 November 1979. He said:

I am gravely concerned to hear that there may be some question about going ahead with the planned legislation on this matter, the nature and level of penalties proposed being, I understand, a source of difficulty for some of your colleagues.
A few years later they are still having the same difficulties, which was apparent when we listened to them speaking tonight. Sometimes I cannot work out which side they are on. Mr O'Reilly continued:
May I make these points:
These activities are criminal in nature and fraudulent-they are not merely an aspect of tax avoidance.
I would have thought that would have alerted the Treasurer immediately. I will repeat those words:
. . . criminal in nature and fraudulent . . .
He went on to say:
The potential of the practices, if left unchecked, is such that legislative action against tax avoidance (including revision of Section 260) could be largely to no avail.

This activity is occurring on a large scale, daily. Although the full revenue implications are hard to estimate (because the parties fail to lodge returns and frustrate inquiries), I am having to write off large amounts of assessed income tax because companies have been stripped of assets.
That was happening in 1978, five years ago. The companies have had five years in which to continue to strip off assets. Mr O'Reilly continued:
One promoter has stripped over 1150 companies in Victoria which had income tax liabilities in the year prior to the strip totalling $14 million (23 being over $100,000).

I will not complete the reading of the letter because it is a very long one. I know that I am not allowed to incorporate it in Hansard so I will not ask to do so. In the debate tonight nobody has mentioned what could have been done with all of that money if we had collected it when it became due. Some of the money milked off by the tax cheats could have been used to build welfare homes and save countless families, including supporting single parents, the misery and despair they face now in renting in the private sector. It has been stated that:
Between 100,000 and 300,000 people are without any shelter at all; the estimates vary among those agencies who are struggling to cope with this destructive problem.
. . . they indicate a situation in which between one per cent and two per cent of the entire population have no roof over their heads.

So the tax cheats have not just taken our money; they have taken the roofs from over some people's heads. In the Age on 17 August S. Dobson, a north-west youth accommodation officer, in a letter to the editor said:

It is ironic that at a time when the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare warns that 'Government failure to combat youth homelessness will effectively nurture a skid row population in Australia'-
Further on the letter stated:

At a time of rapidly growing youth homelessness, the Government should be increasing its funding commitment to youth refuges, and to the establishment of medium and long-term households for homeless youth.

The tax cheats got off with the money that could have been used to house the homeless youth. The money has been drawn away from rape crisis centres and halfway houses by this Government. I know we have had bad economic times and that is the reason the Government has given less funding, but had it proceeded against tax cheats in 1978 when it should have we might have got that money back . There are hundreds of examples of where the lost money could have been used if the Treasurer and the Government had been as assiduous over the past five years as the Taxation Commissioner urged them to be.

What about job creation schemes? They could have flourished. During the time when the tax cheats had been ripping us off this Government has been urging workers not to press for wage increases. It has delayed pensioners' twice yearly increases-at one stage it cost $30m. Because of the Government's harsh economic policies Australian families have suffered growing hardship over the past seven years. The only industry to flourish has been the tax evasion industry while the Treasurer sat and did nothing. That makes a mockery of the Treasurer's statement of 9 March 1982 when he said:
This Government has done more to wipe out tax avoidance in this country than any Government since Federation.
Again on 14 September 1982 he said:
I believe if one examines the record that what has been done by this Government in the campaign against tax avoidance is one which could not have been equalled by any other Government.

I do not know of any other government which would have stood by for five years and let the avoidance industry grow to the extent which it did grow. This is the Government which ripped off the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer for five years while it refused to move against its mates in big business. The PAYE taxpayer has subsidised the total expenditure of the Government while the tax cheats go free. Even at this late hour the Government has given them another 12 months to avoid paying up. It is a disgraceful record which in itself indicts the Treasurer and the Government-as the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) did earlier when he declared the Treasurer culpable after 33 months of inactivity.

The saddest thing about the sorry history of tax evasion and tax avoidance is that while the wealthy doctors in Sydney are selling their debts to their wives and getting off almost scot-free from income tax, the Taxation Commissioner, who has been trying to capture the Treasurer's attention to do something about this, was diligently tracking down any PAYE taxpayer who attempted to get away with any failure to pay up. And so the Commissioner and the Department should, but the contrast is there. The Treasurer has presided over a philosophy of 'let the rich get rich at the expense of the PAYE taxpayer'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill which establishes a most dangerous precedent-a precedent that will change the whole concept and application of law in Australia. This Bill reaches into the unknown depths of retrospectivity. It seeks to go back 10 years to shift the liabilities for actions that have been performed over that period. In a democracy such as we have in Australia the order of our society is based around the rule of law. Our people base their actions on the certainty of the law and they rely on the law to protect those who have acted within the confines of the law.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill now seeks to change all that. People who have acted within the confines of the law over the past 10 years will now have their actions made illegal and they will be required to pay a heavy cost because a new law has been backdated. Such a manoeuvre by legislators must surely undermine public confidence in the law. On the surface the Bill is designed to recover company tax that has not been paid, and I am sure that all of us would agree that every citizen has a moral obligation to pay his or her legitimate taxes. However, the payment of taxes is in fact a legal obligation and not a moral obligation.

A number of Government and Opposition spokesmen have said that people who evaded tax through the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes have been morally wrong and that this legislation is necessary to correct a moral injustice. But moral standards are a mater of individual subjective judgment. What is immoral to one person may be quite moral to another. The Government is now making a subjective judgment to the effect that for the past 10 years some people have been morally wrong and it is now passing retrospective legislation to correct their sins. If such action by government is acceptable, who can say that at some time in the future a different government will not decide that the present methods of tax minimisation are immoral and therefore pass retrospective legislation to recoup the lost tax?

Businessmen now carry forward losses, farmers write off the cost of farm improvements, and parents claim the education expenses of their children. It might seem inconceivable to us that a future government would deem these or other practices to be immoral, but it could happen. The only way in which to ensure that future governments cannot make today's legal actions subsequently illegal is to enshrine the principle that taxation law will not be changed retrospectively. If that principle is not endorsed by all political parties, no person, whether he or she be in business or otherwise, can confidently claim any tax deduction, because that may be deemed to be immoral in the future and retrospectively legislated against.

This whole business of retrospectivity is so disruptive that it must be stopped before it is allowed to get started. We need to look closely at the events that led to the present unsatisfactory state of affairs. Governments of both political persuasions have known about tax evasion and bottom-of-the-harbour schemes for many years. Whilst some revenue was lost it was not considered to be serious. The earlier loose application of section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act by the High Court of Australia left little room for artifical tax evasion schemes. However, the change in interpretation during the 1970s by the Barwick High Court led to an explosion of various artificial schemes.

The Commissioner of Taxation, Mr O'Reilly, was well aware of the growing loss to revenue, but his appeals for urgent corrective legislation were not responded to quickly enough by the Government or by government departments. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wrote to Treasurer Lynch in July 1977 asking for urgent action. In 1978 the present Treasurer (Mr Howard) asked the Attorney- General (Senator Durack) for a Crown law opinion as to the adequacy of existing law. Despite several reminders from the Treasurer it took 10 months before that opinion was received. When legislation was produced other departments objected to certain clauses, which led to further negotiations and redrafting. It was not until December 1980 that the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was passed. That legislation finally stopped the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. During the preceding years Mr O'Reilly constantly pointed out the growing losses to revenue through the legitimate actions of vendor-shareholders.

Vendor-shareholders, however, cannot be blamed for the losses to revenue. Citizens in the community can act only according to the law and its interpretation by the courts. If the law is inadequately framed the fault must lie with the legislators, not with the citizens who use the law or with the courts who interpret the law. One of the dangers with this legislation is the undermining of public confidence in the High Court. People who used these tax minimisation schemes did so under the law, according to the interpretation given by the High Court. Despite the fact that they acted in conformity with court decisions, they now find that they will have their affairs thrown into confusion because of retrospective legislation. How, then, can people act in future with confidence if the decisions and interpretations by the highest court of the land can be made null and void because legislators pass back dated laws? Some people have said that there is a history of retrospective legislation in this country and other countries, but I ask honourable members to reflect on whether there is a history of retrospective legislation that overrules the highest court in the land and also changes the whole concept and application of the law.

In my view the whole sorry state of affairs has arisen because the administrative process is not working properly. Certainly it is not working the way the vast majority of Australian people want it to. It seems to me that government administration is breaking down because of the rigid discipline of the party system. That means that political expediency and point scoring override all other considerations. No thought is given to the effect on public administration. Leaders will use every opportunity to score a point or 'tip a bucket' on their opponents. Perhaps they think that that wins them public favour or support from their followers. One thing is certain: While politicians concentrate their attention on political expediency and point scoring, the administration of government will get worse.

I believe that, above all else, the Australian people expect their governments to be good, effective and efficient administrations and also that the affairs of government will be conducted honestly and with high integrity and principles. It is about time that politicians in this country started to respond to what the people want rather than what they themselves try to impose on the people. Naturally, while this point scoring battle is taking place the process of public administration is left to the public servants. Knowing that their jobs are protected by permanency, the public servants are not concerned about efficiency or giving service to the public but are much more concerned about promotion up the promotional ladder. In all of this, the constant losers are the Australian people. Revelations by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, inquiries into the Health Department, the Australian Dairy Corporation and the meat substitution scandal, all show clear evidence how government administration is breaking down and the effect that is having on the country.

The Australian people want politicians to co-operate more on a bipartisan basis so as to improve our public administration. If a good idea is put up by the Opposition-and that does not happen very often-it should be looked at objectively. Equally, if there is a problem with administration, all parties should be more concerned to make improvements rather than simply score political points. The fact that our present system is not working properly is self evident . The system needs to be improved so that we can go forward into the twenty- first century with confidence. Our present system has a long history of tradition and hard won experience. The good features need to be retained while improving the administrative processes to take account of the modern computer age.

I am in no dispute with the Government over its determination to recover unpaid taxes. But, in doing so, the Government must be constrained within the parameters of the law in the same way as any Australian citizen is constrained by the law. The Government will have my wholehearted support if it recovers unpaid taxes by using existing laws. But we can never allow governments in this country to fiddle with retrospective laws simply to suit their own convenience. The use of retrospective laws is so disruptive, so potentially dangerous and so destructive of confidence in the law that such laws should never be considered as an option for any government. Therefore, the practice of retrospectivity must be stopped before it is allowed to get started.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is this legislation being debated tonight? The proximate cause is, of course, the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I will have something to say about that aspect later. However, I believe that the cause of this situation is much more fundamental. I think that this legislation reflects serious divisions in the class which the Liberal Party and, for that matter, the National Party represent. Over a large number of years, the Government has been supporting that small 10 per cent-the upper class of this country-at the expense of everyone else in relation to taxation and the distribution of wealth as a whole. The distribution of wealth in this country has been getting worse and worse in relation to 90 per cent of the community vis-a-vis the top 10 per cent. Of course the Government, unlike the governments of many other countries, does not provide figures on the distribution of wealth but some have been compiled by sociologists recently. I will refer to some of those figures because I think they are very relevant to the whole question. A study carried out by Phil Raskell determined that the top 10 per cent of the community own 58.5 per cent of the wealth of this country. The next 40 per cent own 33.57 of the wealth. The next 40 per cent own 7.66 per cent of the wealth and the lowest 10 per cent own 0.27 per cent of the wealth. In other words, half of the Australian people own less than 8 per cent of all the wealth of this country and the top 10 per cent own more than the other 90 per cent put together.

SPEECH.PARA: It is in this context that one might ask the questions: Why is this so? Why has it happened? How has it arisen? One of the major ways in which it has arisen has to do with the deliberate policies of conservative governments over the years to do absolutely nothing to collect properly taxes from the wealthy of this country . It is because there has been no concern with collecting taxes from the wealthy , in the form of either wealth taxes or proper income taxes that this situation has arisen. There has also been a failure to prosecute companies. This was revealed quite clearly in the Costigan report. In some cases companies simply disappeared and were not heard of for years. All a person had to do was to turn himself or his earnings into a company, put the letters 'Ltd' after his name and the Commissioner of Taxation would not bother about him. Why were so many companies not investigated by the Commissioner of Taxation when individuals were ? Mr Deputy Speaker, if you or I do not put in our tax returns what happens? We get a note from the Commissioner of Taxation pretty smartly asking where they are. But if somebody represents his income as company income, other things will happen. He will not be pursued.

The Government cannot convince anybody in this country that this has not been a deliberate decision of a government which represents the wealthy and the top 10 per cent of the people to whom I referred. Not only has this situation prevailed but also massive tax concessions have been given to companies and corporations. These concessions increased in the 1981 Budget by 56 per cent to over $1,000m. The 1982 Budget allocated nearly $2,000m in concessions to companies and major corporations. But that was not enough in providing ways of avoiding taxation or providing taxation concessions for these extremely greedy people. They could not even be bothered to use the so-called legal tax avoidance mechanisms. They went to the point of total and utter corruption in the sense that they used illegal schemes because they were simpler. That is the whole point. They could not even be bothered appointing their accountants to use so-called legal tax avoidance measures; so they went as far as using these totally illegal and discredited schemes.

Why has this distribution of wealth been allowed to continue for so long without something being done in the area of tax avoidance? That question has been asked time and again. People have referred to the incompetence of the Government. People have said, including honourable members on the other side of the House, that something ought to have been done earlier. The fundamental reason is this: The interests that represent the Liberal Party and the National Party are tied to those interests which stand to benefit by these tax avoidance and evasion measures. That is the fundamental point that must come out of this debate. What has happened as a result of this failure to persist in examining these schemes? The result has been that the other 90 per cent of Australians have had to pay much more in both direct and indirect taxation. That burden was imposed by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) at a time when he was doing very little to stop these other schemes, very little to investigate them and, in particular, very little to have the offenders prosecuted.

When we speak of the lack of prosecution we should not blame just the Treasurer . What about the Attorney-General's Department? What was it on about? What about the Australian Federal Police? There has been so little in the way of prosecution in this whole area, especially in relation to these totally and blatantly illegal schemes, that one must ask whether there has been massive and utter incompetence or, as has already been established in the course of other inquiries initiated by this House and in other ways, corruption in the sense that there have been deliberate attempts to frustrate legal process.

One might then ask: Why has the Government, after all these years, finally brought the matter to a head? That it has done so has created considerable division within the ranks of the conservatives. Costigan showed that the greed had gone beyond any kind of rationality, beyond any kind of acceptable behaviour , even in a context in which the wealthy were allowed to get away with massive tax evasion. It was only at the point at which Costigan revealed the extent of the illegality that the Government was forced to act. But there was another reason, an economic reason. It was that the Government, as a result of its disastrous economic policy, had not been able to come to grips with the increasing Budget deficit and its need for revenue. Even though it had imposed massive income taxes, had derived $3,400m from petrol tax, and had imposed other indirect taxes, it still had not been able to deal with the fundamental problem of this economy-the fiscal crisis of the state and its inability to pay for its own services.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do, socialise it all?

—I will talk about that on another occasion, do not worry. I am not intimidated by that question. There are many answers to such a question. To return to the issue at hand, that fiscal crisis has created a division within the conservatives. There have been those who have said: 'We have to do more to collect this money because it has gone beyond a joke; it is now a ridiculous situation. We cannot even sustain a minimal level of services'. The Government tried cutting quite a few services but found that it had to dish out more and more in allowances to the upper class and to the big corporations. In the end the Government needed more money and the Costigan inquiry provided it with the excuse it needed to try to collect some of the back taxes owing. Of course, not everyone agreed. Some had friends who were going to be required to pay back these amounts of money. Events have unfolded in two stages. There have been incredible debates and fights within the Liberal and National parties. As a consequence, the Treasurer has given in to various interests in regard to important clauses of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall refer to two of the clauses which clearly show that he has given in to those interests to a considerable degree. The first concerns the fact that one can now pay, over 12 months, the taxes owed. There is no requirement to prove that one is in need, that one cannot pay. The right to pay over 12 months has been made automatic. We would have considered reasonable a clause which said: ' If you cannot pay in 30 days you can put a case to the Commissioner of Taxation and see whether that case stands up. In that instance he might be able to give you an extension of time'. That was not good enough for the friends of the Government. It was necessary to provide a full period of 12 months to pay.

I remind honourable members that these schemes have been denounced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), by the Treasurer, and by most of the front bench and have been described as being morally totally insupportable. The people who are responsible for these schemes have now been told that they can pay over a period of 12 months. The Government, with its Budget deficit, cannot afford this 12-month period. The whole nation is going bankrupt. If that is the period which this Government wants to put forward, why does it not give ordinary people 12 months within which to pay their taxes? I also remind honourable members on that point that people do not have an onus to prove that they need 12 months. It is automatic that they will get it.

A further absurdity in another clause I think clearly illustrates the general point I have been making about the support of the upper wealthy class by this Government, which does not represent anybody other than the top 10 per cent. I wish now to say something about that second clause in the legislation. There is now a clause to exempt companies that might have gone through a tax avoidance scheme in the first instance. If it can be proven that the promoter to whom a company was sold was intending to carry out some form of tax avoidance-even if that so-called legal tax avoidance was not accepted by the Commissioner of Taxation-then the person can claim that a genuine sale had been made. In that situation the person may be able to escape the tax. This is an extremely serious loophole in the legislation which was introduced as a backdoor way of allowing a substantial number-probably up to one-quarter of the people who were involved in these schemes-to get out of paying their recoupment tax. I believe it is a further example of where the true philosophy of this Government lies, of where the Government's heart is, even though it pretends to us now that it is really into punishing these people by recouping the tax.

I wish to say one other thing about this matter. Those honourable members opposite who are opposing this legislation on the retrospectivity principle are talking as if the Government were imposing some kind of criminal penalty on these people. All that the Government is doing is collecting taxes; it is not imposing a criminal penalty. I remind honourable members that, as far as the Opposition is concerned, the fourth clause that is relevant in this legislation is that in which the Government has tried to stipulate that even if a person refuses to pay back taxes that person cannot be named by the Commissioner of Taxation. In other words, there is virtually no sanction against him. There is no criminal sanction. A similar situation exists where we think that our tax repayment will be $1,000 and the Taxation Commissioner sends us a note saying: ' I am sorry, it is $2,000'. That is the position into which these people will be put. I believe that it is absolutely disgraceful that anyone in this House is opposing this legislation in view of what has happened and what continues to happen.

Finally, the principles involved and the causes involved reflect back on the class situation, this upper class of 10 per cent with which the Liberal Party and national Party are involved and whom they represent. It is because of this that members of those parties have had fights amongst themselves as to whether to put forward this legislation. Had it not been for the pressure of the media, had it not been for the pressure of Costigan, and had it not been for the pressure of the Opposition, this legislation would not have come forward to this House and we would still be in the position where the rich would be paying very little tax and the rest of us would have to pay more.
Thursday, 28 October 1982

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time available I should like to focus attention on two areas. I refer, first of all, to the underlying principle which this Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2] throws into relief and, secondly, to some points of fundamental concern that emerge from the existing draft Bill which is presently before the House. Much has been said in this debate about the principle of retrospectivity. Some honourable members have embraced it as though it is a principle which in some way prevents or should prevent Parliament from passing laws which have any retrospective operation. Of course, the truth is that there has never been a principle of English or Australian law that Parliament cannot pass retrospective laws. It has always been part of our law that we can. But also it has always been part of the law that there is a statutory presumption that in interpreting an Act it is presumed not to have a retrospective application by reason of the injustice that retrospective applications can bring out. But it is not always unjust to enact a law that has a retrospective application. This has been pointed out on many occasions. It was pointed out by Mr Justice Isaacs many years ago in the case of George Hudson Ltd v. Australian Timber Workers' Union.
