SPEECH.PARA: Mr Justice Isaacs said:

What may seem unjust when regarded from the standpoint of one person affected may be absolutely just when a broad view is taken of all who are affected. There is no remedial Act which does not affect some vested right, but, when contemplated in its total effect, justice may be overwhelmingly on the other side.

The power is there and, much as I respect the views which have been expressed on the other side, such as the views expressed by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), I think that on balance the decision that the Government has made is a correct one. If one looks for the circumstance that justifies the application of a retrospective operation of a law to the kind of facts that we are looking at here, it is surely this: That, at the end of the day, whether wittingly or unwittingly, vendor-shareholders-I am concentrating attention on them for the time being-obtained a benefit as a result of what in the final analysis was a stripping operation designed to leave companies denuded of assests and unable to pay tax. They may have been unaware of what was going to happen or they may have known what was going to happen. But certainly in all cases there was an actual or contingent liability that hung over the companies. Certainly this liability was not satisfied. It was not legally avoided; it was simply not met because the companies were deliberately stripped of assests and so on balance it seems to me that those who profited should make good what was lost.

It is on that point that I part company with some of my friends on this side of the House. Simply put, an avoidance scheme does not involve illegality or evasion, but the schemes covered by the Bill involve at the end of the day illegality or evasion and that is the fundamental distinction between avoidance and evasion-between what is legal and what is illegal. That having been said, and that in my view being the justification for the legislation in terms of principle, I should like to say something upon some points of fundamental concern. In making the comments that I am now going to make, I will make it perfectly clear that I am not being critical of the draftsmen who have had a most complicated task, nor am I being critical of the Government's efforts to meet the views of a number of us who have thought that there were areas of the Bill which threw up what might be called unintended consequences. The Government and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) have been more than open and more than willing to meet the constructive criticisms that have been put.

That being said, let me just touch on a few points. First of all, if one goes to the definition of 'eligible promoters class' one sees that this covers a wide number of people. I know that the very word 'promoters' is one which engenders almost an hysteria from some of the members of the Opposition. But if one looks to the definition one will see that it includes not only people who would be promoters but also others who are agents, who are brokers, who may have one share in a company which was a purchasing company or who may have been a director in a company which was a purchasing company and who by reason of a variety of other associations can be brought in as part of the eligible promoters class. What then happens? Those individuals are subject to a joint and several liability which is either 20 per cent, or in certain circumstances 100 per cent, of the taxable amount, that is, the unpaid company tax. In principle it seems to me that that is unjust for the reason that the 20 per cent cannot be regarded as a calculation of an estimated benefit. Certainly the 100 per cent liability cannot.

Let me give one instance of cases where the 100 per cent liability will apply. That is made perfectly plain on page 57 of the explanatory memorandum where it is pointed out that cases within the 100 per cent liability for the eligible promoters class include 'schemes under which the vendor-shareholders were all individuals and all those persons died before any assessment to vendors recoupment tax was made'. In short, the state of health of other individuals determines whether a person in a class has to pay 20 per cent or has to pay 100 per cent. That seems to me to be fundamentally wrong.

I pass on to another point. Those who are jointly and severally liable, once they become within the class, unless they can be excluded under clause 11, which as presently drafted is a somewhat cumbersome provision, are liable to the extent provided for under the Bill, whether or not they had an intent to benefit improperly or illegally. That seems to me to be fundamentally contrary to principle.

On a somewhat different subject, it will be noted that if one examines the Bill there are provisions relating to beneficiaries. It is perfectly plain that in certain circumstances beneficiaries-that is, beneficiaries who are beneficiaries of a trust and who are children-can become liable to recoupment tax. We all know how trusts can operate where parents control trusts and as a matter of convenience distribute to children notionally but, in fact, the money goes into a business or into an investment which is controlled by the parents and which may, of course, fail. What we are seeking to do in certain circumstances is to charge children with a liability for a benefit that they never received in circumstances that they could not control. I am bound to say that does not seem to me to be a just approach to the kind of problem that we face. I hope the Government will take that point as it has taken a number of other points that have been put to it and see what can be done to overcome that sort of problem.

I pass on to one or two things said by members of the Opposition. The things which have been said reveal very clearly the distinction between the approach taken by the Government parties and the approach taken by the Opposition. First of all, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) made the position quite plain. He said he was looking forward to fully retrospective legislation. The honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) said that he did not need a precedent. It is perfectly plain that if a Labor Government were in power it would not be troubled in the least by any injustice, nor would it be troubled in the least by the prospect of setting aside transactions which were legal in the past. It would apply palm tree justice. Secondly, it would seem from what the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) said-if he has any influence upon the affairs of the Australian Labor Party-that we can look forward to a capital gains tax if that party ever gets into power.

Thirdly, I come back to the question of exposure-the concept of trial by Parliament or by the media. Much criticism was levelled against the deletion from the Bill of the provisions which require or confer a right on the Commissioner of Taxation to report those who have failed to pay recoupment tax. That is symptomatic of the McCarthyism of the Left that this Parliament has suffered from for quite some time now. It is a very good thing that that provision has gone out of the Bill. One thing that emerged very plainly is that there is a refusal to acknowledge or an incapacity to understand that there is a difference between what is legal and what is illegal. Whatever one's views may be about tax avoidance, there is a fundamental difference between what is within the law and what is outside the law. It is that fundamental difference that it is perfectly plain the Labor Party does not intend to observe should it ever get into government. That is the fundamental difference which this legislation does observe.

I conclude on these points: It has been said by the honourable member for Tangney that the rule of law is central to our society. It most certainly is. Our law, in terms of the application of laws passed now to events from the past, has always admitted of exceptions where the circumstances were sufficiently special, sufficiently compelling, and where the public interest was sufficiently important, so as to outweigh the damage that laws which have a retrospective operation can do to the general administration of justice. It is always a fine judgment. I am bound to say that the views that have been put from my side of the House to the effect that there can never be a breach of this principle are all too black and white. Quite often it is a question of weighing grey against grey. It is always a question of making a very fine judgment. If there is one thing that this debate has illustrated it is the importance which the Liberal Party and the National Party attach to the principle of law. The debate that this legislation has evoked outside this Parliament and within the Liberal Party and the National Party-with the exeption of some obviously self-interested parties-has been a debate of principle between people who are concerned with principle. That is the strength of our coalition parties. I hope that this is the last time we will have to debate in this Parliament the application of this principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we have seen an array of the back benchers who are in revolt. One could call them the revolting back benchers. I think that the reason they have toed the line in relation to this legislation is connected with the story that has been circulating in the Press Gallery, the lobbies and anywhere one goes in Parliament House-that the Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, will be calling a general election for 4 December. There is no doubt that he wants an early election. It is convenient for the Prime Minister at this time to pull his revolting back benchers into gear.
—They are revolting, all right.

—They are totally revolting, as my colleague says. They have fallen for the three card trick. If the Prime Minister sees a crack of light no doubt he will have a go; he will bolt. The revolting back benchers will find that they are out on their ears sooner then they had anticipated.

SPEECH.PARA: I join the debate on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2] and associated Bills because of the last speaker, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). I am sorry that I cannot match his eloquence. When I went to high school I was not taught to speak with a plum in my mouth. I cannot quite copy the technique that he has mastered. No doubt Hansard will help those who cannot follow my particular accent. I want to try to bring this debate back to basics. We have the Government-the Liberal Party and the National Party- upholding the virtues of the white knights, the shareholders, the people who support industry and who, in fact, keep the country running! Let us get down to basics. A shareholder is just like a punter.

TALK.START.PARA: —A speculator.

—He is a speculator, just like a punter. Those who follow that sport will know what I am talking about. The shareholder is the one who runs up and down the bookies' line, looking at favourites, and looking at the best price that he can get. That is where he will put his money.
—What is wrong with a punter?
—There is nothing wrong with a punter. I am glad that the honourable member raised that point. Australians have a tradition of being bloody good punters.
—This is getting down to basics.
—We are getting down to basics. There is another one with a plum in his mouth.
—Order! The honourable member will address himself to the subject.

—Let us get to where shareholders fit into the industrial scene here in Australia. They put money on and transfer money to where they will get the best price. They are portrayed by this Government and the people who support it as the people who keep industry going. There is no place for them on the other side of the punting scene. We can look at the jockeys. They try their hardest. They have to do all the hard work. Shareholders run around putting their money on the best bet they can get and the jockeys have to take all the risks and do their hardest. Jockeys have hard taskmasters. They hope that they will bring home a winner and get a bonus. Even a bonus is often contested.

SPEECH.PARA: If we bring this debate down to the punting scene we really expose these shareholders who Government members would have us believe are the backbone of industry. They are bloody punters out for the best price that they can get. They will change from horse to horse as the favourites go up and down on the bookies' board. Their loyalties lie where they can get the best price. They do not give a damn whether their money is on General Motors-Holden's Ltd, Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd or whatever as long as they can get a good price for it. That is what they want. They do not care about the people who work in the factory and produce the winning result, the end product. They regard people in the factory as industrial fodder. I am glad to see the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) walking out of the House because that is where he should be-right out. He will be right out soon.
I return to a number of issues that have been raised tonight. Retrospectivity is an issue that the revolting back bench is on its heels about. We get double standards; we get bloody double standards-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Hindmarsh will withdraw.

—I withdraw. The back bench has double standards. Government members mention Lord Hailsham in their argument to say that retrospectivity is wrong. It is strange that someone on the Government side should raise that. When I came into this House I did some research into a speech made by Sir William McMahon, the former member for Lowe. I recall as a union official hearing over the radio a speech made in this place in which Sir William McMahon extolled the virtues of Lord Hailsham-another one of the Government's class-about retrospectivity. It was important to me at that time because the Government was talking about the Curran scheme and the evils of retrospectivity. He and others in the Parliament at the same time agreed to retrospectivity in other areas, such as in regard to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I was a victim of that retrospectivity. Legislation passed in this House by this Government forced me, as a union official, into another election following an election that I had already won. The union rules were registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, the same as all companies have to have their rules registered. It was an officially registered organisation. We had to obey the rules of the organisation. I went into a ballot because I could do nothing but follow the registered rules of the organisation. I won the ballot, and the hypocrites of this Government passed retrospective legislation which said that it did not matter what I had done in the past, I had to comply with a particular regulation which said that there had to be a court-controlled ballot. I had already won the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had been cooking the books.

—Does the honourable member for Mitchell want to say that outside? He does not have the guts to say it. I had won the election, but because the Government passed retrospective legislation, I think on 21 or 22 November of that year, it meant that I had to go into another election against the same candidate.
—That is terrible.

—No, it was not terrible. It was wonderful because that same candidate said he did not want to be in the election. But the Government's retrospective legislation said he had no choice, he had to be in it.
—Did you win?

—Of course I did; I did win the other election. So the back bench has double standards in regard to retrospective legislation. I now refer to a matter that is a bit nearer to the bone, which comes to the issue and really exposes what this Government stands for. I begin by referring to a very important statement by the Prime Minister. In one of his many election promises he said: ' We will establish a sound basis of economic responsibility'.
—Who said that?
—John Malcolm Fraser.
—Order! The honourable member for Hindmarsh will refer to the Prime Minister by his proper title.

—The current Prime Minister, John Malcolm Fraser, said that. He did not go on to say that he would establish it at the bottom of the harbour. He went on to say a number of things about Medibank. He said that there would be jobs for those who wanted to work and that there would be no international safaris by members of parliament. That is a real joke, is it not? We know about those promises. Honourable members opposite will have to front up to them regardless of whether the Prime Minister has called their bluff about 4 December. The Prime Minister's Government promised to establish a sound basis for economic responsibility. In fact, his policies have resulted in a massive increase in the amount of tax paid by the pay-as-you-earn wage and salary earner. This is confirmed in report No. 4 of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. On page 90 the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is of some interest to note the comparison between the growth in taxable incomes of individuals compared to the growth in taxable incomes of private companies during the period 1966-1980 . . . Whereas with inflation there has been a great increase-sixfold-in the taxable incomes of individuals, there has been only a slight increase in the taxable incomes of private companies.

That says it all. The people whom members of the Liberal Party represent have been paying less and less in taxes. The Government appointed the Costigan Royal Commission; the Government supported it. The Government did that to try to get at the unions and it backfired on the Government. Now it is in trouble and it does not know how to get off the hook. It will not get off the hook. Pages 89 and 90 of the Costigan report refer to the failure to prosecute in cases where asset stripping has been identified. The report states:
The statistics for this type of operation-
That is, pre-tax profit stripping-
of the scheme, which is fraudulent, are:
1973 27 companies throughout Australia
1974 65 companies throughout Australia
1975 117 companies throughout Australia
1976 104 companies throughout Australia
1977 507 companies throughout Australia
1978 242 companies throughout Australia
1979 622 companies throughout Australia
1980 1412 companies throughout Australia
1981 121 companies throughout Australia
The year 1977 was a good year; 1979 was a really good year; and 1980 was a bonanza year. Costigan's report goes on to state:
It is fair to assume, and I do, that had this prosecution been brought in 1975, or 1976, or even 1977, it would have inhibited the growth of these schemes.

I think the record speaks for itself and shows that this Government had the opportunity to move and recover those moneys that the people whom honourable members opposite represent have ripped off the taxpayers, the workers in the factories, for many years. We must remember that the Fraser Government has tried and will continue to try to shift the focus of blame for tax avoidance and evasion on to the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Perhaps it is an irony that a report which set out to investigate the painters and dockers, most of whom vote for honourable members opposite-a report whose results were eagerly awaited by the Prime Minister and his gang-has instead exposed the Government. Now the Prime Minister is trying to redirect the attention of the electorate to the union but he will not succeed and neither will any honourable member who tries to support him.
At page 3 of the Costigan report, it is stated:

I think I should say something about the range of the Commission's inquiries. As I indicated in the Third Interim Report the Commission, to the surprise of many, found itself investigating the evasion industry. Such investigation arose from its discovery of the use being made of-
I emphasise the word 'of'-
Painters and dockers by-
I now emphasise the word 'by'-
the promoters of tax schemes.
That is what was said in the Costigan report, an inquiry which was set up by the Government. The Fraser Government, the present Government, has well and truly been hoist with its own petard.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that mean?

—I will explain that to the honourable member for Calare later. I know he faces many difficulties and I have some compassion for him. I want to go on to expose the depth of this particular rotten and corrupt government-it was born in corruption-of which the honourable member for Calare is part. Where are the Government's prosecutions against tax evaders and avoiders? Let us examine figures which surely illustrate the false standards applied by the present Government. The present Government's prosecutions in the social security area from June 1979 to June 1981-you opposite should listen to this and squirm-for age pensioners were 11; invalid pensioners, 37; widow pensioners, 224; unemployment beneficiaries, 3,310; sickness beneficiaries, 102; and other beneficiaries, 13. In that particular two-year period prosecutions totalled 3, 697. In the same period not one prosecution was carried out against tax avoiders and evaders. That exposes the Government and you can damn well live with it.

—Order! The House will come to order. Before calling on the honourable member for Braddon, I ask the honourable member for Hindmarsh in future to be a little more zealous in meeting the requirement that he address the House through the Chair. I was reluctant to interrupt him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--
—It was a lovely communist speech.
—An honourable member opposite interjected and I think he should be asked to withdraw.
—The Chair did not hear the comment.
—I heard it through the sound system and it came from an honourable member opposite.

—I have decided for reasons which I will explain that I cannot support these Bills. First, I want to say that I believe that private members have a duty and a right to speak out and to voice their opposition if they believe that the Government is presenting unreasonable and unfair legislation. I consider that this is such an occasion. I realise that the Government is under considerable pressure from the public to act against tax evaders. We are all aware of that. I believe that the Government's response in the form of this Bill is bad both in principle and in form. Clearly the Government has a responsibility to make certain that tax cheats do not prosper. I am sure that we would all agree with that. It must ensure that we have effective laws in place to catch them and see to it that those laws are properly enforced. But in dealing with this evil of tax evasion it is vitally important that the Government does not disregard fundamental principles. John Locke, the great political theorist, published his famous treatise on civil government in 1690. I believe his words are worth remembering tonight. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Who ever has the supreme power of any commonwealth is bound to govern by established standing laws, promulgated and known to the people and not by ex- temporary decrees. There must be independent and upright judges, who are to decide controversies by those laws. And all this is to be directed to no other end but the peace, safety and public good of the people.

Locke was speaking of the rule of law when he said that any commonwealth is bound to govern by established standing laws promulgated and known to the people . There is no doubt that the Bills now before the Parliament offend against this basic democratic principle which is based on the belief that it is unjust to punish a person or impose imposts on him for conduct which was not contrary to the law at the time that conduct occurred. The injustice inherent in retrospective law has been recognised from the time formal laws were first created. Laws were pronounced, published and made known to the people so that they had an opportunity to act according to the law.

Past conduct cannot be influenced by subsequent law. This is such a trite legislative principle that it should be unnecessary to cite any authority to support it. Suffice it to say that of the great legal authorities-Cicero, Coke and Blackstone and respected modern jurists such as Dixon, Hailsham and Denning to name a few-have all appreciated the dangers inherent in retrospective laws. Further evidence of concern can be found in our common law rules of statutory interpretation, which have been referred to earlier, pronouncements by the United Nations and in the constitutions of the United States of America and France. The Liberal Party platform specifically warns against retrospective tax laws when it states:
The rights of the taxpayer are safeguarded . . . by ensuring that taxation adjustments do not have retrospective effect.

Although the great bulk of legal authority warns against retrospective legislation, an attempt has been made to justify the present legislation by quoting comments made by Lord Greene and Howard de Walden's case. The honourable member for Labor (Mr Barry Jones) made reference to that case in his speech earlier in this debate. The real fact is that that case did not deal with retrospective legislation as such but merely with the retroactive application in 1942-during the war years-of the provisions of the Finance Act of 1936. The legislation that we are now dealing with is very different from the legislation that was dealt with in that case.

These Bills are plainly retrospective. They seek to impose a new tax liability on persons not previously liable and to backdate that liability so that it applies to transactions which occurred as long ago as 1 January 1972. How does the Government justify acting against this well established principle that laws imposing new imposts should not be made retrospective? There has been an attempt to justify it firstly on the basis of fairness but this is a vague concept. Fairness is a very vague concept. When is something fair and when is it unfair? Is it fair to allow tax deductions for a business lunch or for a business visit overseas but to impose duties on a paraplegic who might import a wheelchair into this country? What about family trusts, partnerships or companies which were formed for the purposes of lessening a person's tax liability? Are these arrangements fair on people who cannot take advantage of them? Will we now have legislation to set aside such arrangements to take effect from some arbitrary past date? It has also been suggested that people acted immorally or unethically some years ago and so, because of that, we should now act against them by invoking this legislation. But it is dangerous to speak of morals in this way. Who decides what is moral and who decides what is immoral? I commend to the House comments recently made by the Law Council of Australia in a submission to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on this very legislation when it said:

Whilst it is appropriate to pass laws to overcome what are considered to be immoral or obnoxious practices or practices contrary to the public interests so as to make illegal those practices in the future, it is not in our submission proper to legislate to make conduct now determined to be improper or contrary to the public interest because of changed public opinion, and relate that changed opinion back to the time when the conduct was undertaken. That desire for change should not be given effect so as to make unlawful acts which were lawful at the time they were undertaken.

Does the Government justify the legislation on the basis of the guilt of shareholders affected by the legislation? Apparently not, because the Government has made the point that it is not concerned about the question of guilt or innocence; it is simply a matter of collecting tax from those individuals who were shareholders in companies and promoters. Is it because of the amount of money involved? The question then is: How much money does one need to lose as revenue before retrospective legislation can be justified? Is it $10m, is it $ 20m or is it $100m? What price tag does one put on a principle such as this? Or has this legislation been placed before us because of politically inspired Australian Labor Party pressures which have undoubtedly built up since the McCabe-Lafranchi report of May 1982 and the report of July 1982 of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union? I regret to say that I think that that subject is closer to the mark.

It is worth recalling that when the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill was debated in December 1980, when we knew that many millions of dollars had been lost to revenue, the Government appeared then not to be willing to consider the retrospective collection of lost taxes. During the debate the Treasurer said:
Quite obviously it is objectionable to have any retrospectivity regarding the penalties.
Again there are some words which are not relevant. He was responding to a question put by an honourable member from the other side. He continued:
That means that the recovery of the back tax, even if that were an acceptable thing to attempt, would involve an entirely separate set of proceedings. I think that is the immediate problem.
Obviously there was then a reluctance to travel down this dangerous track of retrospective legislation.

The Public Service does not come out of this whole episode very well. It might be unfair now to criticise the Commissioner of Taxation and public servants who have a responsibility to protect the revenue because the public perception and the public mood have certainly changed over the last few years. But it should not be forgotten that the Commissioner of Taxation has a very special responsibility to ensure that tax evasion does not occur. Indeed, under the Income Tax Assessment Act the Commissioner has a commission from this very Parliament to properly administer the Income Tax Assessment Act. Officers of the Australian Taxation Office and of the Attorney-General's Department clearly failed to act with proper determination and keenness some years ago when they knew that millions of dollars were being lost as a result of bottom-of-the- harbour schemes.

Many people learned in the law are of the view that there were laws in existence at the time which could have been used at least to deter people from entering into these schemes. An alternative approach would have been for some statement or warning to have been issued at that early time. No doubt the public servants will continue to defend their position and will say: 'Yes, we had laws. We had conspiracy laws, we had provisions of the companies Acts and we had section 231 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, but the problem is that we did not have the evidence to back up our case. The problem was in the lack of evidence'. But they had advice from Mr Brinsden, Q. C., given at the end of 1974, and I believe it is clear on the evidence that that advice was not pursued with proper vigour. If officers were then concerned about the state of the evidence they may or may not have had to support their cases, they should have sought further advice from senior counsel on the evidence rather than write off Mr Brinsden's opinion as theoretical. It is clear that some very costly omissions were made at that time.

Reference has been made to the opinion of Mr Arthur Webb Q.C., of the Melbourne Bar, given in September 1978. That opinion was part of the papers which the Treasurer tabled in response to the motion from the Senate. That opinion, I believe, tends to confirm the criticism directed at departmental officers rather than to refute it. Why should we go over this ground? I believe we should go over this ground because this lack of diligence is very relevant to the propriety of this retrospective legislation. The failure of the Public Service to act with reasonable speed and the failure of the Government to act at an earlier point in time do not show a long-standing and serious degree of concern which should have been present if this legislation could have been justified. In other words, we now throw our hands in the air and say: 'This is dreadful. It cannot be tolerated. We must have retrospective legislation'. The fact is that the Government or its officers failed to stop the practice though they knew about it for much of the 10-year period which is covered by these Bills.

In asking the Parliament to pass retrospective law, the Government should satisfy honourable members that the law is necessary and that existing law is and was insufficient. The legal opinions that have been tabled in this Parliament to date suggest that existing laws were sufficient to stamp out these schemes. Of course, I recognise that it is much more convenient to collect tax under a strict type of legislation rather than to have to establish some form of liability. Regrettably honourable members have been left in the dark about the state of the existing law. We do not have the advantage of opinions from the first or second law officers of the Crown, from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) or from the Solicitor-General, on this important question. Some senior counsel have given opinions that section 231 of the Income Tax Assessment Act would catch the guilty parties involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes and would enable much of the tax to be collected. This section provides, in part:

Any person who, or any company on whose behalf the public officer, or a director, servant or agent of the company, by any wilful act, default or neglect , or by any fraud, act or contrivance whatever, avoids or attempts to avoid assessment or taxation shall be guilty of an offence.

Penalty: Not less than $50, or more than $1,000 and, in addition, the Court may order the person to pay to the Commissioner a sum not exceeding double the amount of tax that has been avoided or attempted to be avoided.

In the case of a company, that section may catch only the company. However, section 5 of the Crimes Act, which covers people who aid, abet, counsel and so on, would cover vendor shareholders 'knowingly concerned in' the commission of the offence by the company and, in consequence, they could be convicted of the principal offence. Again unfortunately, that section was never put to the test. Had those provisions been enforced, many people may have been deterred from entering into these schemes and the loss of revenue could have been very much less.

I want to make an important point relating to practical government administration. Retrospective legislation could be used to cover up neglect and inefficiency in administration and may encourage those charged with the responsibility of collecting revenue and enforcing the law to believe that they need not proceed quickly but have an abundance of time in which to act. After all, the Government could always legislate retrospectively to overcome any problem. Much has been said about the involvement of innocent people in these schemes. When we speak of innocents we really need to define our terms. ' Innocents' can mean so many different things. Do we mean by 'innocents' people who did not know that the company would eventually go to the bottom-of-the- harbour, do we mean people who did not know that the company would not pay all of its tax, or do we mean people who honestly believed they were acting within the law? Many states of mind are involved in these transactions. However, I strongly believe that there are people who could properly be said to have acted innocently and who will be caught by this legislation. Because tax evasion is so bad, it is easy to believe that everyone who benefits is guilty. But many people who are shareholders may not take any real interest in a company's operations. Some may be wives or mothers, others sons or daughters of the principal actors. They may merely sign forms. In infant and trust situations there were many innocent people. Other people took advice and were assured by respected advisers that these schemes were approved by the High Court in Slutzkin's case.

No doubt some promoters and some of the shareholders had a guilty state of mind when they became involved in the schemes, but equally I am sure that decent and cautious people were enticed into the schemes on advice given by professional people that they trusted. It is said that the legislation will not penalise anyone because it is only requiring them to repay the money that the company should have paid. But when people organise their affairs according to the law, they obviously suffer if they are asked to repay the money years later. These people may have invested their money in their business and perhaps taken on more employees, or they may have paid off a debt or spent the money in some other way . In most cases the money would not be just sitting idle in some bank account.

Who will benefit from the money that will be recovered under this legislation? We have heard about fairness and the need to be fair to pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. I agree with all that. But will the beneficiaries of this legislation really be ordinary PAYE taxpayers? Frankly, I doubt it. Perhaps the Government will give a guarantee that it will earmark funds recovered for redistribution to PAYE taxpayers. But the real result will simply be a transfer of funds from the private sector to the public sector, with the Public Service absorbing the additional revenue to finance its continuing expansion.

As I have said, I do not support tax evaders and tax cheats. They are parasites on the community. But this legislation is not the appropriate way to overcome the problems. In fact, this legislation is so complex and so clumsy that I suspect that it may ultimately prove to be ineffective and a major setback in our efforts to stamp out tax evasion in this country. There is a real danger that this legislation may harm innocent people, may encourage inefficiency in the Public Service and may cause the community to lose confidence in our system of law. I am most concerned about what the Australian Labor Party will do with this precedent. I know the point has been made that this is not setting a precedent for the Government, but it is setting a precedent for the Labor Party. I am disappointed that we are walking arm in arm with the Labor Party on this issue. I recognise that the Government has made efforts to overcome tax evasion, but I believe that this legislation is inappropriate. For those reasons I cannot support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of retrospective legislation has become a divisive matter within this Parliament and within our community. Despite what would appear to be majority support for the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill (No. 2), there are many members in this House who are greatly concerned at the major precedent that the Bill is establishing. I am one of those who are concerned. I recognise that there are strong arguments and legitimate arguments on both sides. Eventually these arguments have to be weighed up and a decision has to be made. My decision, after a great deal of thought, is that I cannot support this legislation. Most people recognise clearly that there is a responsibility on all people to bear their fair share of the taxation burden. Those who fail to shoulder their share of the burden should be called to account.
—Did Brian Maher tell you to do that? You represent him. He is one of your constituents.

—I was waiting for someone to make a remark like that; it would have to be the honourable member. I thought that he would be the first. At the same time , no one wants to pay more tax than he has to pay. There are few people, be they businessmen or pay-as-you-earn taxpayers, who do not try to minimise their tax within the limits of the existing law. The problem is that some people have managed not only to minimise their tax but also to avoid it altogether. The cry then goes up to get them at all costs. It is a legitimate cry. But the cost is that of seriously interfering with the rule and certainty of law, the very foundations on which our society is based. That cost will prove expensive for Australia in the long run.

SPEECH.PARA: There are few Australians who favour retrospective legislation, but many have reluctantly come to support the Bill as a once only Bill to ensure tax justice. I am not one of those supporters. The argument against retrospectivity is, on balance, too strong to be disregarded, whatever the merits of the arguments in favour of it. First there is a basic principle to be considered, which can best be summed up by saying that those who break the law shall be subject to penalties in force at the time. Therefore it follows that no person should be punished for doing something that was legal at the time. Whatever the moral arguments may be in favour of this Bill, many people who are now to be penalised , acted in good faith, on the best professional advice and certainly within the law. If they did not, why are we introducing this retrospective legislation? If the existing law had been fully tested and found wanting it could strengthen the argument for retrospectivity, but it has not been tested. Furthermore it is pertinent to quote Article 15 (1) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights to which Australia is a signatory. It states:
No one shall be held guilty of any criminal offence on account of any act or remission which did not constitute a criminal offence under national or international law at the time it was committed.

It can rightly be argued that the matter we are dealing with here is not a criminal matter. Nevertheless the principles of fairness and justice hold just the same. The Australian Labor Party is firmly committed to retrospectivity. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), and other members of the Opposition have stated this on many occasions. I quote from a speech made by the shadow Treasurer on 28 April 1982. He said:
Careful and selective use of fully retrospective legislation will put an end to tax avoidance once and for all . . .

That is not the voice of a party which wants a once only retrospective Bill. There speaks a party which will use retrospective legislation at any time it wishes, again and again, as more than one ALP speaker clearly indicated tonight. What we are doing here in fact is introducing ALP legislation. Regrettably we are doing the Opposition's work for it. I have no wish to be a party to passing the first major piece of retrospective legislation through this Parliament and so set a major precedent. If and when the ALP ever again governs this country and pursues its retrospective legislation program, who will then speak against that program? It will certainly not be those who support this Bill.

This Bill goes back 10 years-not just a few months, but 10 years covering the periods of both the Whitlam and Fraser governments. During that time the attention of the Government's concern was drawn to various tax avoidance schemes on many occasions. To my knowledge no major offender has been successfully brought before the courts. I say it again: The existing law has not been tested. It is a point which Commissioner Costigan makes quite clearly and it is a point which cannot be ignored. Furthermore, even after the Slutzkin decision in 1977 and subsequent well-publicised correspondence between the Commissioner of Taxation and the Government from 1978 onwards, it was not until 1980 that the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act became law and it was 1981 before the more general anti-avoidance provisions were passed. These measures effectively stopped the schemes which allowed people to avoid tax.

Until 1980 these schemes had been validated to a large extent by decisions of the High Court of Australia and by commercial usage in the full knowledge that the Government was aware of the schemes and had made no move to stop them. In view of this many reputable accountants and solicitors had come to the conclusion that they were obliged to advise their clients as to what was legal at that time. Many vendor shareholders accepted this professional advice in good faith and acted accordingly. It is difficult, perhaps impossible, not to believe that many of these shareholders are now being caught and penalised because of government inactivity over a long period. Furthermore, when the Crimes Act was introduced in 1980 there was no question of retrospective legislation, nor was there any public demand for it. The Government was not blamed at that time. In fact it was congratulated for closing these loopholes.

What has happened then between 1980 and 1982? Quite simply, some reports have been published and the Labor Party has succeeded in applying pressure to have this measure introduced. We should reject these pressures and stand firm on the successful action taken by the Government in 1980 and 1981. The loopholes have been closed. We should now be looking forward and not backwards. In the context of looking forward it is appropriate to quote from a letter to the newspapers by R. A. Bauman of the Department of History of the University of Sydney. In his letter Mr Bauman quotes an extract from Plutarch's Life of Cato the Younger. I quote:

When Pompey proposed a law inflicting heavy penalties on those who had already bribed the people Cato urged him to ignore the past and concentrate on the future. It would not be easy, he said, to fix the point at which the investigation of past offences would stop and if penalties were fixed subsequent to crimes, it would be grossly unfair to those who were punished in terms of the law which they had not contravened when they committed their crime.

During the last few months of this debate, arguments have been put forward about the morals and the ethics of tax avoidance and business practices. This is a very dangerous argument. Everyone has different moral standards and these standards vary on every issue. Two people may have a similar moral view on, say, the subject of abortion, but the same two people are unlikely to agree on the ethics of business or marriage, on parental responsibility, on taxation or on any other subject. The point is that in due course other parties and leaders will come to power-and it is fair to ask what their moral standards will be. We can be sure that their standards will be different from those that are being used as the norm today. Morality is a variable issue. The only certainty we have in this matter which is common to all Australians is the law. We are now in the process of destroying that certainty. We will be destroying public confidence in the rule of law. That is the tragedy of the Bill. It is not about collecting money in my view. In the long term it will be seen as a fundamental blow against the rule of law, and will set a precedent which will make it easy for others to use as a justifiable excuse for further retrospective legislation.

I acknowledge that the Government-particularly the Treasurer (Mr Howard)-has worked long and hard on this Bill and has, since its inception, made considerable concessions to those who have been opposed to all of it or to certain parts of it. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), the Treasurer and other Ministers have said often that here there are conflicting principles at stake. It is not surprising therefore, in a close-run decision, that there will be members of this Parliament and the community who have come to a conclusion which differs from that conclusion reached by the Government. In the final analysis I place the principle of the rule of law above the short term expediency of retrospectivity. There has been in recent years a developing cynicism about the value of holding to certain basic principles. In short, some people would argue that expediency and advantage would overwhelm any argument about principle. I do not.

It is clear that this Bill will be passed and I regret that I find myself in the position whereby I cannot support my own Government. It is not a unique situation but nevertheless it is one we would all prefer to avoid. If there is one lesson to be gained from this divisive issue it is that the time has come to look long and hard at our taxation laws and our administration of them. Our present laws are not only causing people to spend too much of their energies avoiding tax, both legally and illegally-the cash economy is a prime example of this-but also destroying initiative and incentive in this country. In many cases they are destroying the will to work. We can ill afford this at any time let alone at a time of great economic difficulty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak for a few brief moments in support of the amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill [No. 2] moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). In doing so I speak in favour of the Bill. During the last 40 minutes we have heard excuses, from the honourable member for Braddon ( Mr Groom) and the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) as to why they are not prepared to support the Bill. In fact all they have done is to outline the shortcomings of this Government and the shortcomings of the Treasurer (Mr Howard ). They are apologists for tax avoiders. The situation is that we are looking at massive tax avoidance.
—Burglary.

—Yes, burglary. I have been in and out of the chamber since the debate on these taxation Bills started this afternoon. I have noticed that there have not been very many people in the gallery; in fact, there is no brave soul there at present other than our good policeman. One really cannot blame people for not listening to the debate at 1.20 in the morning. However, earlier in the evening when we looked around the gallery we should have seen it overflowing with all of those people who have written to me and every honourable member of this Parliament. I have some of the letters here. For example, some chartered accountants wrote to tell me why I should not support this legislation. Where are all those people now? Where are the accountants and tax managers, the so- called promoters of these schemes? I ask the two Government members who just spoke, and who are apologists for those people, where all those people are? Why are they not here to support them? They are not here because they are hiding. At the present time they are probably trying to get their books in order.

SPEECH.PARA: We are looking at massive tax avoidance. In fact the ordinary wage earner has been hit to the tune of up to $30 a week because these tax avoiders have got away with it for so long. Of course, the only reason that the Government is bringing in the legislation at present is because it is looking for an early election, as many speakers on this side of the House have mentioned previously in the debate. If this were not so we would not be able to drag the Government to the barrier on legislation such as this. But the legislation does not go far enough and that is why I support the amendment. I believe that too many people will still get out under the escape clause contained in this second version of the legislation.

It is strange not to see Government members supporting their own Government. It is amazing when we see where some of these honourable members come from. Obviously they have many friends who are involved in this tax avoidance industry . We all know, of course, that many of the people involved in the tax avoidance industry are not only supporters of the Liberal Party but also members of the Liberal Party. It serves Government members' purpose no good at all for them to oppose the legislation because it puts them right on the line as to whom they support. As I mentioned earlier, they are apologists for the tax avoiders and promoters. If they cannot stand by the Government on this issue they should resign from their party. Not that that is going to matter very much of course, because in a very short time Government members will be scourged from office. For the first time in seven years we will have a decent party in government, one which will bring economic justice to the people of this country. We will catch the tax avoiders. Although this legislation will not catch them all I assure honourable members that a Labor Government will bring down legislation to catch all of the tax avoiders. I entered this debate with the express purpose of saying that I support the legislation before the House. I did not think it right that speaker after speaker on the Government side was opposing the legislation. I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Gellibrand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —During this debate on retrospective taxation we must not lose sight of the need for overall reform of the taxation system. We need in this country a tax system that people will wish to opt into rather than out of. We must cure the malaise of tax avoidance in the nation. One of its causes is that personal rates of taxation are too high. The Government has a creditable record with its restructured three-tiered personal tax system and its efforts to widen the indirect tax base through sales tax. I was pleased to see a recent statement by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on the need to reform fundamentally the Australian tax system. I fear that as every day has gone by in this debate which is coming to a conclusion tonight we have lost a day in the cause of reform.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is to be congratulated on the steps it has taken in the past to stamp out tax avoidance. I am pleased to have supported legislation such as the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. The Government's record stands in stark contrast to that of the Australian Labor Party when in government between 1972 and 1975. When the taxation avoidance industry was just starting to grow the Australian Labor Party did absolutely nothing at all. I am, however, troubled by this legislation before the House tonight for a number of reasons. It is quite clear that the Parliament has power to pass retrospective legislation. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) spoke eloquently about that matter. I shall quote from a work entitled Statutory Interpretation in Australia by Pearce dealing with the power of Parliament to pass retrospective legislation. Page 151 states:

This fact was alluded to by Higgins J. in R v Kidman . . . 20 CLR . . . where he pointed out that while there are plenty of passages that can be cited showing the expediency, and the injustice, in most cases, of legislating for the past, of interfering with vested rights, and of making acts unlawful which were lawful when done, such passages do not raise any doubt as to the power of the legislature to pass retrospective legislation, if it sees fit. The case is of considerable importance because it was held . . . that the Commonwealth parliament had power to pass retrospective legislation.
I shall quote from the judgment of Mr Justice Higgins at page 453 of 20 Commonwealth Law Reports.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members might learn something if they listen to this because I am talking about principle; they do not understand principle. Mr Justice Higgins said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is admitted that the Parliament has power to make retroactive laws as to specified subjects of legislation, such, e.g., as 'naturalization'; and it would need a violent straining of the wide words of the power to make laws for incidental matters if we were to read into them a prohibition of retroactive laws designed for the enforcement of the substantive laws. If we did so, we should be adding to the Constitution, without express words, the prohibition of ex post facto laws which is expressly contained in the American Constitution.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer Opposition members who interjected to the American Constitution because that Constitution, as I understand it, contains a provision that no 'Bill or attainder or ex post facto law shall be passed.' This shows that it is a matter of great principle, as it is included in some constitutions. I shall also quote Pearce in relation to the retrospective operation of legislation. At page 194 he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The courts generally assume that legislation is not intended to operate retrospectively . . . This presumption is most strictly applied to Acts creating an offence because of the manifest injustice that the alternative approach would bring about.

This shows that retrospectivity is a matter of great principle. As a matter of principle I am against retrospective legislation of this type, and the Liberal Party platform supports my view. I believe in certainty before the law, the rule of law, the basic freedoms under the rule of law, and that certainty of transactions should be guaranteed.

I have been consistent in my approach to this subject. Even before the Government announced its intention to pass this legislation, in my annual report to my electorate which I distributed in the middle of this year I stated to my constituents that I do not believe retrospective tax legislation is appropriate as it is contrary to principles of fairness and equity. I have copies of the report with me if anyone would like to read it. I would be happy to table a copy . I am in the practice of reporting from time to time to my electorate and stating where I stand on particular issues. I commend the practice to honourable members opposite. As I said, I made this statement to my electorate and to my recollection I received not one objection to it at the time. I believe that I have an obligation to my constituents to be consistent. As a matter of conscience I feel bound by both the Liberal Party platform and my statement in my report to my constituency.

Of course I do not support bottom-of-the-harbour-type behaviour. It is totally abhorrent. I totally condemn the practice, to which I think the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher) referred, of elderly citizens being given bottles of whisky to sign company records. I condemn totally disappearing company records, sham directors and disappearing directors. I believe that action should be taken against the people responsible. Those who have fraudulently evaded their liabilities must be caught up with and brought to account. The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) earlier tonight told the House how he believed the existing laws should be applied against such people.
I still need to be convinced that this legislation is necessary. If the law can be proved to be inadequate to cover what currently is believed to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I have 100 copies of this speech, Roger?

—If the honourable gentleman just listens, he might learn something. If the law can be proved to be inadequate to cover what is currently believed to be illegal activity, there is perhaps a case for retrospective legislation. I would need to be convinced that the existing laws were found to be wanting before I reached such a decision. I have great respect for the views of my colleagues which are different from the ones I hold. I respect the views of the Government when, on the balance of fairness to all Australians, it comes down on the side of retrospective legislation. I respect the views of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), who earlier tonight said that there was a fine balance involved in making such decisions. He and I come to different sides of the scales on weighing that balance.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a difficult issue for the Liberal Party. There has been a debate on principle within that party and the Government parties. Members of the Government parties have queried and questioned the legislation. We have seen substantial changes made to it. I pay tribute to the way in which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has conducted himself in this matter. The debate shows the strength of the Government parties. It proves that the Government parties-the Liberal Party, to which I belong, and the National Party-can accommodate diverse views. This is in total contrast to the Australian Labor Party's position. Free speech is not tolerated within the Australian Labor Party.

Let us look at what the Labor Party would do. The Labor Party has signalled total retrospectivity in the tax area. No taxpayer will be safe. Every businessman will be concerned by the Labor Party's policy. The Labor Party will hound everybody; it will establish a police state. It has indicated that it would enact draconian and far-reaching legislation to change the existing tax laws. No taxpayer will be safe from the Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party in office would set aside legal transactions and create commercial chaos if the unfortunate tragedy of Labor coming to office were to occur. I say, like the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), that it is clear that this legislation will be passed. I have the regret that he has. When I vote tonight, I will vote on my own account, exercising my own conscience for the reasons that I have expressed to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very disappointed at, but I can understand, taking the late hour of the night into account, some of the noise that has been expressed here tonight. We are debating a very fundamental issue in this House tonight. I think people should take that into account. A number of matters about this legislation concern me very greatly. Firstly, a great deal has been made of the words 'evasion' and 'avoidance'. We have heard a lot about them during the debate here tonight. We should be quite clear that tax evasion is illegal and is punishable at law. Tax avoidance is not illegal.
—It is just crook. There is no morality.
—The honourable member should hold his tongue and listen to what I have to say.
—Honourable members on my left have had their early morning canter. I suggest that they now remain silent.

—We may hold very strong views about the morality of tax avoidance schemes but the essential point to be made is that many were not illegal and are , therefore, not subject to criminal law. We are all-honourable members opposite , me and everyone else-whether we like to admit it or not, tax minimisers. None of us likes to pay more tax than he or she is legally required to pay. If clear cut deductions are allowable to us as individuals, we all claim such deductions. All of us are then legally avoiding tax which otherwise would be paid.

SPEECH.PARA: This, of course, does not deal with the morality argument applying to what have been described as highly artificial schemes designed to avoid a great deal of tax. Whilst I have some sympathy with the morality argument, it is a difficult one to sustain in the tax area. Let me deal with it briefly. If it is immoral to avoid paying tax by the use of 'highly artifical schemes', why is it not immoral to avoid paying tax through the use of more time honoured practices such as family trusts, income splitting, investment allowances and the like? If it is the highly artificial nature of the schemes which makes them immoral, I believe that that justification is very unconvincing. After all, the purpose of the time honoured schemes, as well as the highly artificial devices, is to achieve the same result-that of reducing taxation liabilities or avoiding tax which would otherwise be payable. If it is immoral to avoid a lot of tax, surely it is just as immoral to avoid a little tax? The amount should be of no concern in relation to the morality or otherwise of a person's actions. Those in the community, the Parliament and particularly the Australian Labor Party who speak so passionately on the issue of taxation morality are in so many cases guilty themselves of selective indignation. If taxation avoidance is immoral, all taxation avoidance is immoral regardless of the scheme or the amount.

I am not a lawyer but I strongly believe that taxation law is a question of legislation and legal interpretation. Only if this approach is adopted can the community achieve the degree of certainty that is required if the orderly conduct of business and individual affairs is to continue. That is not for a moment to argue against a moral attitude in the conduct of business. A strengthening of business morality and ethics is certainly needed. What is also needed in regard to tax law is a moral attitude backed very strongly by the certainty of the law, as enacted and defined. We are told that this legislation is necessary because companies have been put into a situation in which they have been left unable to pay their taxation liabilities. People have gained amounts of money that they would otherwise not have gained because artificially high prices have been paid for companies with cashed-up assets.

As the law stands, it is said, vendor-shareholders are not liable to pay tax upon the sale of shares. The companies are unable to meet the company tax payable and therefore action had to be taken to recoup the tax which would have been collected if the companies had been delat with in a proper manner. This, I believe, begs a lot of questions. Firstly, was the action of the vendor shareholders in selling cashed-up companies, legal or illegal? I am told that it was legal except if the sellers knew, at the time of sale, that the companies were to be dealt with in an illegal manner. If it was legal, this legislation is imposing a retrospective taxation penalty on an action which legally did not attract a tax impost at the time it was carried out. If it was illegal it should be dealt with under the appropriate laws governing such illegal actions and, theoretically, there should be no need for this legislation. I say ' theoretically' because, obviously, there is a very real doubt as to proceedings which could be taken successfully against the promoters and others involved in the schemes covered by the legislation.

It seems then that the real justification for this legislation, when stripped of all the rhetoric, boils down to the fact that the existing laws for dealing with the situation were cumbersome and uncertain and that the delay in dealing with it over a 10-year period encouraged the escalation of a procedure which resulted in a great deal of money not finding its way into Consolidated Revenue. In this legislation, in my view the Government is introducing a very dangerous precedent. It is undoubtedly retrospective in its application. It is based largely on the argument that morally people should have paid tax on the money received. It breaks down the protection for corporate shareholders that was put in place for the very soundest of reasons following the disaster of the South Sea Bubble and other syndicates. Undoubtedly, the socialists in our midst, should they come to power, will use this legislation as a stepping stone to much more unacceptable retrospective legislation. The Stamp Duties (Further Amendment ) Bill being dealt with in New South Wales at the moment offers a shining example of how legislation such as this will be used. The Government, in deciding on this particular course of action to deal with the problem facing it, has undoubtedly grabbed the tiger by the tail. None of what I have said should be taken as evidence of any support whatsoever for those corporate crooks in our community who have deliberately, selfishly, wilfully and knowingly sought to defraud the revenue. They have done an enormous disservice to themselves, to the community and to the cause of private enterprise. They have given the socialists an ideal weapon with which to clobber the concept of private enterprise. They should be dealt with utilising the full force of the law. If that were done, they would have the opportunity to defend themselves, to state their case and, properly, to be regarded as innocent until proven guilty.

That brings me to my final point. This is undoubtedly uncertain legislation. It is immensely complex and difficult to understand since its full effects have yet to be fully determined. In fairness to the Government, it has been responsive to the views of those who sought to tidy up the more obvious problem areas and the legislation, in its present form, is very different from that which first saw light of day some weeks ago. But it still does not give vendor shareholders an opportunity to put a case on their own behalf. It still does not allow for the possibility that they could have acted in the most honest good faith, on the soundest of advice and in the stated belief that the company they were selling was going to be carried on according to the law. We must all remember that it was possible for companies with cash assets to be used legally and properly in such a manner as to render them not liable to pay company tax.

A provision obviously should be included which would allow vendor-shareholders to defend their actions with the onus of proof being on the shareholders. We have heard a great deal about morality and fairness in this debate. What could be more moral and what could be more fair than to allow vendor-shareholders the opportunity to defend themselves? If they failed they would have to pay any penalty which developed during the proceedings when they were taking that defensive action. To deny them this right is to make a mockery of the concept of fairness upon which this legislation is said to be based.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say just a few words in reply to those honourable members who contributed to this debate. This legislation, of course, raises a number of very difficult issues. The first thing I want to say is that the criticism voiced by members of the Opposition about those colleagues of mine who felt unable to support this legislation being friends of the tax avoidance industry is as shallow as it is patently absurd. The legislation does raise considerations of principle. I can say, speaking for myself and, I know, for a great number of people on this side of the House, that it has not been an easy decision to arrive at. I, as a lawyer and a Liberal, do not regard the enacting of retrospective legislation with any great enthusiasm.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that demonstrates for a moment a lack of concern on the part of this Government to bring about tax justice in the community. It does involve, as has been said on so many occasions, the putting into balance of a principle generally adhered to of non-retrospectivity against a principle of the overall fairness of the taxation system and the perceptions in the community about the fairness of the taxation system. We have sought as a government to draw a distinction between the tax benefit enjoyed as a result of the evasion that took place in these transactions and other arrangements which have involved all through the transactions a purely legal avoidance of tax. In that sense I believe that the Government's action in respect of this scheme can be separated from other schemes which have been the subject of comment by the Opposition.

During this debate a number of total misconceptions have been exhibited by Opposition speakers. The first of those is their total inability to understand that when one is talking about the collection of tax one is not talking about prosecuting people in a criminal sense. So when the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) comes in here and says: 'Have there been any prosecutions under Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act? Are there going to be any prosecutions under this Bill?', he frankly does not know what he is talking about. Neither of those pieces of legislation has anything at all to do with criminal liability. If the great anti-tax avoidance zealots on the other side of the House really knew anything about the taxation laws of this country they would know that anti-tax avoidance legislation is concerned with blocking loopholes in the taxation legislation. It is no measure of the success of anti- tax avoidance legislation to know how many people have been put in gaol. That is a measure of the success of criminal legislation. That is the first total and utter misconception that I believe the Opposition has exhibited during this debate.

I think it would be fair to say that over the last four or five months there have been more speeches in this Parliament and more debate in the community on the subject of tax avoidance than at any other time since Federation. One of the interesting things I find when I look back over all of the debates that have gone on over the past four or five months is that at no stage has any evidence been advanced by the Opposition to demonstrate that the combined effect of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act passed in December 1980 and Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act passed in May 1981 has been anything other than an outstanding success in stopping blatant tax avoidance practices in this country. We have heard all the windy rhetoric about the $35 a week. What the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) is really saying when he talks about $35 a week is that $10,000m to $15,000m is still being lost on an annual basis, according to that figure. Yet not one of his colleagues has been able to point to a tax avoidance practice that is still going on in defiance of those two pieces of legislation.

That is the second misconception. If someone came from another country and listened to what members of the Opposition have said tonight, he would imagine that these practices were still going on in a totally unchecked and unhindered manner. Yet the Opposition knows and the great majority of people know that the legislation we have passed has been particularly and conspicuously successful. That is the second misconception that I believe ought to be laid to rest in respect of this debate.

Can I say one final thing in respect of the concerns that have been voiced by my colleagues on this side of the House about the legislation and its retrospective effect? In the course of the debate we have heard a proper concern expressed about the rule of law in our community, we have heard a proper concern expressed about certainty under the law, and we have heard a proper concern expressed about the need to avoid confusing morality and legality. I have to say that in general substance the concept that was advanced by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) was that it is a very difficult and a very subjective thing to talk about morality. But governments, in all the decisions they take, have to take into account a number of considerations. They have to take into account legal considerations. They have to take into account economic considerations. They have to take into account social considerations. Let us all be frank about it, they also have to take into account political considerations. No government worth its salt pretends that it does not take into account political considerations. Of course it does.

One of the very important things that the Government had in mind in deciding to bring in this legislation was that, no matter how successful had been the legislation to which I have referred, no matter how successful had been our campaign to eliminate tax avoidance practices in this country, there can be no doubt that, because of the publication of the McCabe-Lafranchi report-not that it dealt with any new tax avoidance arrangements; it dealt with an arrangement that we had struck down in December 1980-and because for the first time names were published and identities were associated with particular practices, the public perception of tax avoidance in this country was changed in a very significant way. I believe that one of the things this legislation does is to establish in the minds of people in the community who have perceptions regarding the fairness of our taxation system a demonstration of the determination of this Government to legislate for the benefit of the great majority of Australian taxpayers.

I do not wish to rehearse the arguments that have gone on time and again during this debate about the essential justification for this legislation. I say again that the legislation is not criminal legislation. It does not seek to say whether somebody is guilty or innocent. It is not legislation imposing an offence. In my view it is not legislation imposing a penalty. It is legislation purely and simply concerned with recouping an unpaid taxation liability albeit not from those who legally incurred that liability in the first place but from those who have enjoyed the financial benefit of it. Therefore I believe with respect to those of my colleagues who have argued otherwise that many of the precedents on which they have drawn so far as retrospectivity is concerned are more relevant to criminal legislation, are more relevant to legislation imposing a penalty and are more relevant to legislation imposing some kind of retrospective offence. After all, parliaments have in the past passed retrospective laws. This Parliament in 1977, not on the Curran scheme but in respect of the loophole revealed by the Victorian Supreme Court regarding the accrual of long service leave, voted unanimously on that occasion to pass that amendment to the taxation law. As it turned out a subsequent decision of the Federal Court of Australia retrospectively proved that that amendment was not necessary. The fact nonetheless remains that if one is looking at the absolute principle of retrospectivity this Parliament and those who are concerned about it should on that occasion have indicated that point of view. Of course then there were different considerations and perhaps different merits, but the principle remained nonetheless the same.

The only other thing I would like to say is that this particular Bill has raised important considerations in principle. I well understand why a number of my colleagues, in fact a great number of my colleagues, have reservations even to the point of opposition to this particular legislation. As far as I am concerned, the Liberal Party of Australia is the stronger for being able to accommodate within its ranks a healthy and honest debate on matters of principle . I think it will be a very poor party that cannot embrace that kind of debate, that kind of difference of opinion and even though there may be some differences of opinion within our ranks there is one issue on which we are absolutely united in this debate-that is, to totally reject the smear of the Australian Labor Party that the Liberal Party is the friend of the tax avoiders of this country.
