QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he receive representations during 1982 from the Defence Manufacturers Association of Australia wherein that Association sought clarification (a) on the guidelines used to assess the level of significance of defence strategic or high technology implications of defence procurement, which give preference to Australian firms and (b) from the Government whether it will give consideration to the direct support of export sales to approved countries of defence equipment manufactured in Australia, as is done by the Governments of France, Great Britain, Israel, The Philippines, Singapore, Sweden and the United States of America.

(2) If so, did the Association also indicate that it felt that the Defence Industry Committee was in no way representative of the Australian defence industry, as current industry executives, other than from the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, are not members of it.
(3) What has been his response to these representations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes.
(3) The Defence Manufacturers Association of Australia has been informed that:

The Government has decided, because of the broad criteria involved, that rather than identify defence strategic or high technology industries, Commonwealth purchases, in respect of which preference policy applies, will be evaluated on a case by case basis.

In relation to the high technology category, the Government decided that particular characterisics would be taken into account when assessing the applicability of the preference policy. Consideration is given to the Industrial Research and Development intensity, product innovation, advanced production processes, the extent of technical skills employed, and use of newly developed materials.

As far as the defence strategic category is concerned, the principal criterion is the contribution that the project makes to the strategic aims of self- reliance for the Defence Forces. Such contribution may take either a direct or indirect form and may establish, maintain or enhance those capabilities of importance to the existing or planned forces.

Export of military equipment is a complex question that requires the Government to balance the benefits of larger markets against our international image and relationships. Support is given through the offsets program and through administrative assistance and, where exports have been approved, they have been eligible for the Assistance accorded commercial exports.
The suggestion that the Defence Industry Committee (DIC) is exclusive to BHP and is not representative of Australian industry is not correct.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Attorney-General's answer to question No. 4218 (Hansard, 6 May 1982, page 2507) relating to the need to set up a Sentencing Council, what response has the Attorney-General received from the respective State and Northern Territory Attorneys-General as to its establishment.
(2) When will this constructive reform be implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Only a minority of Attorneys-General expressed support for the proposal to establish a Sentencing Council.

(2) As a Sentencing Council could operate successfully only if adequately supported by the States and the Northern Territory and as the requisite measure of support has not been forthcoming I regret that there is no prospect of the Council being created in the near future.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Visit of the Israeli Minister for Communications

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports in the Sydney Morning Herald of 9 September 1982 that his Department protested to the Israeli Government at the behaviour of the Israeli Minister for Communications, Mr Zipori, during his visit to Australia last month?
(2) Are the reports correct; if not, what are the facts of any inter- governmental exchange concerning Mr Zipori's visit; if so, what were the grounds of the Government's objection?
(3) What representations have been made on this matter to (a) the Israeli Embassy in Canberra, and (b) the Israeli Government through the Australian Embassy in Tel Aviv?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) I have seen several Press reports regarding the Government's attitude to the visit of the Israeli Minister for Communications, Mr Zipori, on which I do not wish to comment. It is true that the Government was not happy when Mr Zipori's visit, which was to be private, acquired a public character. Representations on the matter were therefore made both to the Israeli Embassy in Canberra and to the Israeli Government through our Embassy in Tel Aviv.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 21 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the fact that the Minister's answers to 2 detailed questions on notice (question No. 5103, House of Representatives Hansard, 20 October 1982, page 2488, and question No. 2395, Senate Hansard, 19 August 1982, page 379) have been answered in the briefest possible way with little or no reference to the individually numbered parts of the question and the answers sought therein, does this indicate that the Minister regards (a) the recent major re-organisation of the Department of Veterans' Affairs and (b) Australian-U.S. relations on matters related to Vietnam veterans, as (i) potentially politically embarrassing and (ii ) not appropriate subjects for scrutiny by this Parliament; if not, will the Minister now provide the Parliament with complete answers to both of those questions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) and (b) (i) Not at all; (ii) As I indicated in my answer to Question No. 5103, the re-organisation of the Department was discussed in Senate Estimates Committee G on 16 September 1982. The answers to these questions provided information about the re-organisation and about a proposed visit which, in fact, did not take place.
